Wrong. There was never any treaty granting Palestinians a "partition" based on the 1967 border, which is actually the armistice lines of the 1948 war. Palestinian leadership demands that any peace negotiations start at that border. which is simply a sneaky way of saying let's go back to 1948.

Please get your facts straight.  There was no "1967 partition."  Mr. Stephens refers to Israel without the West Bank and Gaza - the area that all supporters of a two-state solution agree would remain in the hands of Israel.  The fence is between this area and Gaza.  One can argue with Israel's military tactics but one cannot argue that Israel is doing something other than defending its borders against demonstrators who are led by Hamas in chants of "A million martyrs marching on Jerusalem"

I agree that shooting unarmed protesters doesn't play  well (and is wrong) but its important to differentiate between the civil rights protests in America and what is going on now in Gaza.  Martin Luther King and the civil rights marchers mostly believed in non-violence as a philosophy.  King never carried a gun and paid with his life at the age of 39.  The civil right marchers never threw rocks or bottles or Molotov cocktails.  The Gaza protesters are using nonviolence as a tactic - because suicide bombings that slaughtered innocent Israelis didn't work.  They are mostly being used by Hamas, which is a totally violent, terrorist group.

The schisms within the Jewish community itself makes this "complex stuff" even more difficult to deal with. The prejudices that you have dealt with are shameful and disgraceful. With a growing ultra-orthodox culture that is vehemently anti-Israel buttressed by the clueless J-Streeters on the left, one wonders how long the center can hold. That center needs as many decent people as possible because, like you, since Trump, I have seen people openly embrace aspects of extremism that I never thought they would. So, I disagree..... your point is not minor. Not anymore.

Ross, perhaps what is really keeping you unsafe are the ethnocentric attitudes of men like Benjamin Netanyahu. What did you think was going to happen when Jews expelled Palestinian Muslims from their homes and there land during and after 1948? Oh yes, remind me that this was the Jewish homeland.
Israel was not founded as a theocracy.  It does not require all citizens be Jewish, or to practice a certain form of Judaism.  That is in contrast to the requirements of many Muslim countries.
Not sure if Jefferson should get the credit but I take your point.

I agree that 2 wrongs don't make a right and certainly the Palestinians have a right to their own state.  But since my armchair is in Jerusalem and not in Arizona, I wonder what Israel can do after the Palestinians were offered almost all of the West Bank and Gaza for their own state at Camp David and Yasir Arafat refused and started the Intifada where hundreds of Israeli civilians were slaughtered by suicide bombersl  Maybe the Palestinians could do much, much more

But if they did rush towards Hamas, they, including women and children among them would be slaughtered without mercy and the massacre would receive less attention than Israel's actions.  Look at what is happening in Syria.

Can you also tell me why they breached those borders in the first place? Could it possibly be that they were about to be invaded and destroyed? Could there strike have been the smartest thing they could have possibly done to survive perhaps?

Also when has any nation followed what the UN asks? Isnt there a dictator named Assad that runs a murderous regime in Syria on the Isreali border that has ignored about 50 UN resolutions?
Oh yes and Syria has twice been in the UN Security Council. Israel????
Perhaps a semi-parallel is that self-styled “Romans” practicing Roman law etc stuck around for over a thousand years after they’d lost the piece of turf called Rome.

"the Israelis have a state, the Palestinian Arabs do not."

The Palestinian Arabs have a state. It was part of Palestine and was renamed Jordan.
Isn’t the anti-Semitism “clearly on the rise in Europe” mostly Muslim anti-Semitism?
I'm a Democrat. Unfortunately, many in the party are anti-Israel. It's not really surprising that Israel looks to the Republicans for support.
And as a Democrat, a Jew, who voted for and liked Obama, he was cool and not sympathetic toward Israel. Not even as a candidate.

Interesting question, Victor.  My take is that a liberal or progressive Democrat who believes in inclusion and equality is much more likely likely to be troubled Israel's treatment of its Arab citizens and Palestinians in the West Bank than Republicans who believe in a state based on ethnicity and religion and the prioritization of security over civil and human rights.  The Israeli right looks at the world in a similar way as the American right and has similar values.   My guess is that Netanyahu (who has lived and worked here, and is a student of American politics) realizes this, and has concluded that it is in the Likud's long term interest to align with the Republicans (who, unlike the Democrats, have a religious and nationalist base and do not have a civil rights constituency).   He is probably right in doing so.
Israel would give up most of the settlements as the price for peace.They gave up Sinai and Gaza.There will be no peace until Hamas ,PLO accepts the Jewish State.

"Jewish people are not naturally warriors.  We are scholars ...."  Nothing marks nonsense like a racial or ethnic stereotype.  Bruce R. has soiled is generally reasonable comment with ethnic stereotyping.  If ethnic stereotypes are true, Israel would be filled wall-to-wall with banks, and Africa would have a basketball hoop every 30 feet or so.  And Ireland ....

serban:

Did you read Bret's column? This is happening increasingly throughout Western Europe. It never stopped happening in Eastern Europe. And, not to be too delicate on THIS side of the pond, it's increasingly happening HERE again.

"...a situation where two very alien peoples want the same land is not likely to end well from historical experience."

Indeed -- ask American Indians (it wasn't that long ago).They don't have a "right of return", either. I gather you think they should.

Superior firepower trumps (yes) human dignity and equality every time, but conveys no moral superiority (almost always the contrary).

Borders are political, not natural or divinely gifted. Israel's were a man-made designation imposed by the winners of armed conflict in a region that already had defined borders, not a sacred gift, and it's claim to define them as expansively as it wishes now is a political policy based on firepower, not divine right.

Jews have often been demonized and victimized. So have many others (native Americans, Africans, Rohingyas, Tibetans, to name a few). If they institutionalize and enforce the same racism they suffered, are they better human beings? Or merely better armed?

fairwitness:

No, I don't believe that native Americans should possess a "right of return". They were placed on reservations starting seriously over 150 years ago, by rules of conquest that were normal for the times. If we were to set about seeking to correct every racial injustice ever perpetrated in history by the ethical and moral standards of today, we'd simply dispossess many MORE millions of completely innocent people to suit impracticable notions of political correctness.

You might recall that Israel seized the land that the U.N. granted them, then were attacked by Arab powers. They took advantage of those unsuccessful attacks en passant to seize more land and keep it. It's not as simple as some portray it, at least not leading up to fairly recent times.

However, religious Jews in Israel, and the government they've elected, see all the land between the Med and the Jordan River as a "gift" from God to them, whether you agree with them or not. That has worsened an already-bloody mess that has appeared intractable for a long time, since it's clear that they're defending that notion regardless of the cost to Palestinians.

It still comes down to two peoples wanting the same land, a reality that rarely if ever ends well for the weaker of the two.

Dear jwh - to quote a previous comment, you're just another "armchair corporal," reveling in your so-called "superior" understanding and self-righteousness. I'm betting if you were born in Gaza, you'd be the first person to volunteer to dig one of those tunnels into Israel. Because they feel just as victimized as you do - the only difference is they are *really* victims, and you're just an armchair corporal.
The first attack was the Arab blockade of Israel.  That was the act of war that started the conflict.

Israel has condemned itself (and the world) to a forever, low simmering war to protect its perceived need to prevent the establishment of a Palestinian state. The root of the problem was the original idea to establish a Jewish religious state in the middle of a land with many people of a different religion. Religious states of any type are a bad idea. They inevitably lead to conflict. Jews could have remained in the countries they lived in after the war and fought for their rights like blacks did in America. Another Holocaust would not have been possible at that point with the great powers of the world watching. But the world has paid the price for that mistake for the last 70 years as the conflict has worked to disrupt the Middle East. The only solution at this point is a two state solution, but right wing forces in Israel have prevented it. So the world will continue to watch this human disaster slowly unfold, all underwritten by the American taxpayer. And maybe we will finally get that Armageddon that many believe is prophesy.

Golda:

You conveniently gloss over the role of Israel's brutal expulsion of a million or more Palestinians from their fields, homes and places of worship in fueling the rise of that extreme Islamist ideology. That ideology is a direct result of Arab shame and despair at their inability to protect their fellow Muslims from Israel's aggression. It is not unfair to say that -- in large part -- the Islamic extremism that now plagues the world was "made in Israel."
Now more than ever - we sane, rational folks who want to live together, whatever our differences must speak up against all prejudice and for co-existence and rationality.

PL, thanks for engaging. I'm going to give that some thought.

Somewhat parallel to the pre-Israel situation of the Jews is that of the Roma, a people with a long history and no territory of their own, or even an "old country" to long to return to.

This is the single most overlooked historical fact about the Middle East.
Maybe because it's an inconvenient truth?
HH: It's called the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.  Palestinians are not Hashemites.
PL: That's only a part of it.  There are lots of skinheads and neo-Nazis lurking on the streets of Berlin and elsewhere.
It's a part of it, especially in France. However, Britian's Labour party and Corbyn are virulently anti-semitic and much of it in Hungary, Germany, Poland,  etc. is from the white nationalists.
you may have misunderstood what Obama and Kerry were doing (vs what they said ), their moves were more nuanced and telegraphed than the caveman-child-bully ...
"His reputation falls far below his desert." - Alexander Hamilton.
As letters editor of The Times, I fielded many reader complaints as well. I used an explanation from a grammar website - not nearly as eloquent as Mr. Corbett.
How about horse-ing a dead beat?

Was the Times correct?

Language changes over time and writers have to bow to those changes at some point. The authority you cite to defend your choice published in the 16th and 17th centuries. Is the Times asserting that "just deserts" has been in continuous use since then? We know that is not the case.
I was one who was misinformed. “Just desserts” never exactly made sense either. Delighted to know this!
Any headline (or metaphor) that readers stumble over -- or have to reread multiple times just to get the gist -- probably isn't working and should be reworded.

My frustration in reading articles these days, particularly on line, is a trend toward letting incorrect, intuitive spelling go by unchecked. Not just NYT, but generally. Need increased attention to detail.

I had just wanted to comment because I thought it was a terribly flawed argument, and was irritated that I could not find a comment page! The spelling briefly crossed my mind, but I was too distracted by my agitation to think about it.

I knew the words in the first part of the headline were correct -- what I took exception to was the second part.  "Beating a dead horse" is unpleasant and unnecessary.  Please don't use it.  No horses -- live, dead or figurative -- should be beaten.
Maybe people should consult a dictionary before sending in a correction.
The first part of the headline, whether properly spelled or not, was itself a gloat.  And not undeserved.
userDisplayName: The blind lady with the scales

commentBody: "Language Cops Get Just Deserts"
I understood the title however I'm confused why there's no parallel construction. Please explain.

You said, "I know that many Times readers care passionately about grammar, usage and good writing."

Yes, and some of care about the who, what, when, where, why, and how rarely seen now. Some pieces don't even have a simple date, let alone a time of day.
Not to worry; the same Merriam-Webster department that OK’d “momentary” and “ambiance” should have “just desserts” covered soon.
Then there's the matter of "beating a dead horse" and the Wells Fargo logo.

I was originally intrigued myself regarding the spelling and resorted to the Oxford English Dictionary, that I grew up with, for clarification and found the following although the last line is very interesting:
If a person gets their just deserts they get what they deserve. Deserts here is related to deserve, and is spelled with one -s- in the middle; a dessert is a sweet course eaten at the end of a meal. The -ss- spelling in the sense ‘what a person deserves’ is regarded as an error, although in the Oxford English Corpus it is as common as the correct spelling

Somehow, I had the amazing (to me) good sense to Google the matter. While, for my aged brain, the path was a bit tortuous, I did see the light. I was interested  that in the correction that the editor assigned the notion of one getting what one "deserves". I am more likely to consider that "just deserts" occur when one is abandoned (deserted) deservedly or no by what might otherwise be supporters. Abandonment in this case being a forerunner to some really bad news. Thus, again, for me, the question was whether Wells Fargo is being properly or improperly "deserted" by those unsympathetic to their situation.   And, remember L. Patrick Gray, the FBI Deputy who was left to "twist slowly, slowly in the wind"? Now, that's what I call a desert. So, is this one for Ethicist?
How do you write this article and not mention the origin of the phrase "beating a dead horse"?

I didn't have a problem with "just deserts." The term has been around for a long time. I did have a bit of a problem with "beating a dead horse." Certainly clever, given the history of the company and the logo. But by the time I finished the column, I learned that things were looking up for Wells Fargo. Admittedly, the stockholders took a hit, and some execs were given their walking papers, but a "dead horse" it doesn't seem to be.
Thanks for this.  Learned something new.

Because a cafe called Just Desserts was the site of a horrific murder and thus highly publicized, the misspelling "just desserts" became so pervasive in Toronto that I was on ordered by an executive editor to forgo "just deserts" in other contexts and change spellings to "dessert."
My newspaper then became a literary desert.

The same problem occurs in Maine.  Visitors to Mount Desert Island use the pronunciation for the dry, barren region.  However, the name derives from the French word meaning deserted.  Hence, the pronunciation—Americanized—into Mount “dessert.”
I thought "desserts" would have worked too, what with the fines coming only after the main meal of public investigation, revelation and flagellation

I saw the headline yesterday and wanted to make a comment about your "mistake". But there was no comment area. So instead I looked up the phrase and discovered (to my great suprise) that "deserts" is correct and, as you say, derives from "deserve". A great lesson in language and it's sometimes suprising history!

I find the headline an awkwardly mixed metaphor, but that's another matter. What's remarkable is that so many readers were sure they were right about the spelling, without adequately researching the phrase. Just another symptom of our culture. I bet someone could start a meme with "New York Times Spells 'Desserts' Wrong" that quickly would go viral.

I did not get this this when read in the times, thought Wells Fargo opened a branch in the desert to sell dead horses! that is possible.
I am a non-native speaker but not seen this in Walt Whitman or Hemingway. The Economist no longer uses Whom, what about just keeping deserts for Chihuahua

Confusing indeed.
It looks as if the roots of dessert and desert (homophone) are the same - from "serve well', or 'deserve;' while desert (the place, or the act of abandonment) has a different lineage, from Latin for leave, or forsaken. So it would actually make more sense if the archaic spelling desert (entitlement to praise or punishment) were to modernized to dessert.

But then what would we argue about?

There are really more irritating glitches in more of the writing of late - - but not in headlines meant to draw the wrath of the observant.

Of course, there’s also the fact that “just” has multiple meanings as well. The headline just doesn’t scan well. Although I was familiar with the correct spelling of “just deserts,” at first I parsed it as “Are fines simply arid regions, or beating a dead horse?”  And that made no sense at all.
What they get wrong is not writing at a level  that is more accessible to the audience.

Chita RIvera has probably shrugged off more racial slurs than Carol Silverman has had hot meals. In any discussion of show-biz customs, traditions and terminology we should defer to the highest living authorities; no one has earned more love and respect than Ms. Rivera.
A solution in search of a problem. .....

There are lots of thoughtless, ugly little expressions we use.  We accuse someone of "welshing" on a deal.  So far as I know, the Welsh are no more dishonorable in business practices than any other group.  To "gyp" is to cheat; we smear the character of the Roma intentionally or not.  Never mind that the Travelers sometimes refer to themselves as "Gypsies."  The word is theirs, not ours.  I may call myself a queer, and another queer may refer to me a queer, but if you yourself are not a queer, beware of what comes out of your mouth.  You could end up with a broken jaw.

Goodbye, I guess, to the Gypsy moth. Hereafter to be known by its politically correct name: Lymantria Dispar Dispar.
Goodbye too to the gypsy cab and its clearly racist drivers. Or was it racing drivers.

Since the Romany people object to this label applied to them and most have stopped using it, why can't the people who call themselves gypsies in a non-ethnic, non-judgmental, proud and joyous way have custody of the word?

I dread to see the battle over the next revival of that musical about stripper Roma Rose Lee and her Mama.

Shall we then also retitle the famous musical "Gypsy"?
The Pronoun War(s) with all the righteous campaigns, random ambushes, and new rules may be one of the most insidious, pervasive and divisive distractions featured right now among the many daily terrors of just trying to get by.
Why were no members of the Roma community interviewed for this article? Shouldn't we hear from them as to how they feel about the word "Gypsy" used in this way?

What a ridiculous action to take. It's a positive reference, not a negative one. Instead of censoring the word, they could hold an annual benefit for Roma people. What's next, barring the word "traveler" or "tinker"? Over-sensitivity becomes ignorance.

So does this mean that a certain show--you know which one I'm talking about--can never again be performed? As a longtime fan (and occasional performer) of Gilbert and Sullivan, I followed the controversy a couple years ago concerning THE MIKADO. While it can be argued that there are legitimate causes for concern and complaint in both cases, *this* particular instance seems to be the PC Patrol going way beyond the bounds.

And you wonder why people voted for Trump.

I'll leave the controversy to those who know more about it, but I want to point out what the story doesn't mention -- long before the '76 Tony ceremony,  Bonnie Franklin was the lead in the production number "She's No Longer a Gypsy" in the original cast of "Applause." Bonnie was one of the most fair-minded people I have ever known. I'm sure she would be sorry to know that a term she used lovingly was hurtful to the Romany people.

Not sure how I feel, being an outside entirely.

It seems like the word "gypsy" was seized by dancers in the theater -- because they lived on the move, settling for a while where there was work, had a culture unto themselves, and felt distinct from the "straight" folks who made up their audiences - who lived more mundane and rooted lifestyles. It was a more colorful way to identify themselves - a shorthand with some flair. They were outsiders in the world at large, but at home in with their own.
So this wasn't used as a pejorative. I am not convinced that there is a need to change it as used here. Words do acquire different meanings dependent on usage.

Good news. I've long stood up to the denigration of the Roma for decades, since I had a family as clients. "Gypsy" is as disgusting an ethnic slur as ... the N word, which can't be printed. And often the response is as unintelligent as those here. "Huh? Never heard of it" or "lots of things can be racial slurs."

Thank you for this article. I am actually very pleased that Actors' Equity is leading the way in phasing out the problematic term. But I do think that without further education as to the issues involved, many members of the industry and public will indeed be left scratching their heads. One way to understand the need for change is to imagine the names "Negro Robe" or "[pick a name that Jews can use self-deprecatingly, but that is otherwise insulting] Robe." The impact of "Gypsy" or "gypsy" in casual conversation is arguably more damaging  than the above word combinations, since misconceptions about Romani cultures (and even about our very existence as an ethnicity) are so pervasive.

If a MAJORITY of people in an ethnic group find a term offensive, it is not up to rest of us to argue them out of their feelings. There are always overly sensitive people everywhere, and no one person should have the right to censor the entire language. But those of us who are not in that group do not have the right to make such judgments, because we can never know what it is like to experience that particular kind of oppression.

Precisely for that reason, however, privileged people have no business making speculations about what terms underprivileged groups find offensive. No Roma person or organization objected to this, and no one is doing them any favor by creating discord over something that most Roma probably never even thought about. For us, these kinds of discussions are merely an interesting intellectual exercise, so it is easy for us to find new things to be sensitive about. I think that most underprivileged people are just trying to get through their lives, and and are usually too worried about macro-aggressions (like the risk of being shot and abused by police) to worry about micro-aggressions.

Sexual harassment is legally defined as what would be offensive to a reasonable woman. We need to have a similar standard for all these kinds of situations, so that our standards are not defined by either one overly sensitive person, or a guilty privileged person making unfounded speculations about something he or she cannot possibly experience.
Really? This? Now?
Great first step AEA.  Next step?  Find someone to write a new libretto for the racist, sexist, and classist opera Carmen.

Tom Viola says, "Even words that may have once been intended as a slur can be, in fact, reclaimed with pride." Yes, but they should be reclaimed by the group that was actually the target of the slur in the first place. (Would Viola similarly defend the robe if it were affectionately called "the [n-word] robe"?) I would defer to the Romany people to decide if they're okay with the term "gypsy" being used, even lovingly, by non-Romany groups.

The ceremony itself is lovely, and changing the name won't change its sentiment or the sense of community it forges. The name change is simply a mark of decency and consideration for those who have said it's hurtful. It's an act of kindness and empathy that really doesn't cost anything or destroy anything. Those who complain that it's "overly PC" may be revealing that the preservation of the status quo is more important to them than hearing out the concerns of the marginalized.

Just to be clear, there were absolutely no people of the culture which can presumably still be known as "Roma", in the theatre union, that were actually offended by this, right?  It's just more misplaced white guilt.

This comment by Petra Gelbart in the article hit home for me: "the fact that the term Gypsy is so often used to denote ... traveling lifestyles has real-life repercussions for actual Romany people. We are always being reduced to ridiculous stereotypes that can make it difficult to find employment or social acceptance."
I realized as I read that - if I was truly honest with myself - that yes, I do have a knee-jerk response to thinking of a nomad (or worse) when I hear the word gypsy, as someone in their 50s who grew up with that term. Glad to hear the industry is willing to take the hard path of discussing this and doing something, rather than just kicking the can down the road so future generations have the term ingrained as well.
As for "gyp": the term "jew down" seems to have gone away, thankfully. Let's let "gyp" go too.

Gypsy is an ethnic slur? So maybe replace it with terms more acceptable to gypsies, such as Manouche or Sintí or Roma. (Joking) By the way, I’ll be taking my Gypsy Jazz guitar to “Gypsy in June” in Massachusetts to study Gypsy Jazz with REAL Manouche guitarists and two hundred other students. We revere them and their skill, but the music is still called Gypsy Jazz or Gypsy Swing.
Great! Bravo! Its time to get rid of the term! Sorry for some non- Rom harping on keeping it but you don't have to live with the luggage it comes with. Romani, Rom, Roma! Thank you!

“It is an ethnic slur,” said Carol Silverman, a professor of anthropology at the University of Oregon who describes herself as “ a non-Romany activist-scholar.” / She said she was pleased by the union’s decision: “This could serve as a model for other organizations.”

Leave it to a liberal activist scholar to want to police thought and language for her own career advancement.

If the original Gypsies are now called Roma, what's the problem with with using gypsy as it is understood now? "She's just a gypsy." A footloose traveler. "That's the gypsy in me." Moving again to explore another part of the country. "Putting on my gypsy shoes." Getting ready to move on.

Really, I don't hear anything pejorative, just description understood by all.

OK, I give up, call it the "Itinerant Robe" and the "Equity Itinerant Robe"ceremony and ban the G word from Broadway.  But why stop there: How about the problems of existing robes that would be passed on to the next show or retired to the Smithsonian and other museums?  Certainly they should be removed from public view, or even destroyed, as racist symbols of a shameful past.

This is beyond absurd. Are they going to retroactively also change Gypsy Rose Lee's name to Roma Rose Lee?

They need a new name for the robe? It should be called the "Actors Equity Politically Correct Robe."

This is beyond absurd - it's infuriating. Essentially, the word is a homonym. What would be offensive would be to call it the "Romany Robe."  Good for Equity Fights AIDS for continuing to use this cherished theater term.
In other news, Fleetwood Mac is rethinking its set list for their upcoming tour.

Apparently all things offend someone today, so do not attempt ANY award, club, joke, cartoon, symphony, play title, acceptance speech, and on and on.  The thought police are everywhere.  It is simply not worth the ridiculous circus (yikes! that too might be construed as insensitive) that inevitably ensues.
What next in the rush to cleanse anything someone thinks is offensive?  I'm with Chita!
PC run amok. I wonder how many of you lived with or near gypsies. I did, in Madrid, and they lived up to their negative stereotypes.

This is an utterly ridiculous move by some overly politically correct members of Equity who are, in all likelihood, unemployed in the theater and have nothing better to do than to dream up nonsense like this. As an Equity member, I can assure you that no one was clamoring for this. A theatrical gypsy is a term of tradition and pride, and we should all be so lucky to work enough to be called gypsies.

I think this is a mistake. The word "Gypsy" has two meanings 1) a name for the Roma people, now recognized as offensive 2) A general term for anyone who wanders and lives at no fixed address. I would argue that the fact that these two terms have a shared history should be ignored. To call a Roma person a gypsy would be offensive, because it unfairly stereotypes all Roma as wanderers. To simply refer to anyone who wanders as a gypsy is another matter. That's a tautology, not a stereotype.

Apparently no Roma have initiated protests on this issue, and the only actual Romany person that was contacted had a mixed reaction. This indicates to me that banning the word itself misses the point. Using the word only in a theatrical emphasizes that it does not have any necessary connection to the Roma. Encouraging this non-Roma use of the word actually decreases the power of the stereotype to defame the Roma.

I find this very sad. There was always something romantic about the idea of the "gypsy in my soul." Referring to chorus members as 'gypsies' made me want to be one. Something I was never able to attain. Wow! Time moves on. Old traditions die. Yeah. I agree. Maybe we should focus on more important issues.

So there is a community of Roma that live and work in our metropolitan area.  I know because I have taken care of them in the large medical center in NYC where I work.   They are a distinct culture (a group with shared language, beliefs, food, values) within our own.   When I talk to them about their health they refer to themselves as Roma and as Gypsy.  I appreciate Petra Gelbart's comments.  I wonder if anyone from Actors Equity has reached out to the Roma community here in NYC or elsewhere for guidance on this matter?  Perhaps that might be a good start.

The use of the word "gyp," as in to cheat, is much more offensive than calling a dancer a "gypsy" in a beloved theatre tradition. As the reader comment from SR notes, most people are unaware of the true meaning of the word "gyp," but it is an ethic slur because it implies gypsies cheat or swindle others.  The word was around in the 50s when I was a kid, and I have tried not to use as soon as I learned what its intended context really was.

There's also that short form of the word, "gyp", used (I think even, and far, more commonly than "gypsy" is in its contexts) like "cheat" or "swindle".  I'd often find myself using that word years ago, not knowing (or much caring) about the etymology...
Wonder what Stephen Sondheim thinks of all this. Will his 1959 collaboration with Arthur Laurents be off the table for Actors Equity members from now on?

A misguided, overly PC move that is an attack on the texture of life & history.  Was there a huge outcry among Equity chorus members to rename the robe? Yes, by all means, root out abuse -- but perhaps it is time to exercise judgement as well as justice.

“The time for small thinking is over, the time for trivial fights is behind us,”

This from the smallest of men and the champion provocateur of trivial fights.
I say this to you, Mr. President: in the United States, we pride ourselves on following those people who demonstrate character, commitment to principle, and who produce actual results. We do not follow power, we follow leaders.

Do these things: demonstrate an honest, kind character, show us unwavering commitment to -- and understanding of --the principles of our founders, and let your results speak for themselves through unvarnished facts. In short, be accountable to those you serve.

Then, and only then, will we follow you. The greatness of our country is not yours; it is OURS.

This is what I see as the general arc of the speech

1. Paint a dark and dystopian view of America, almost all of which is either false, or grossly distorted.
2. Blame that situation on the Democrats, particularly the prior administration (you know, that black guy in the White House).
3. Propose policies that will either make those problems much worse (e.g. his proposals for replacing Obamacare) or he couldn't possibly get through a Republican Congress (e.g. that infrastructure proposal). And while you're at it, mention a Justice Department task force (Voice) whose SOLE purpose is to demonize immigrants, to make sure you can keep that front and center.
4. Last, invite the democrats to join in a bipartisan effort to clean up a mess which they created but doesn't really exist. This has the added advantage of making Democrats look like obstructionists if they don't go along with even the worst of your proposals.

I found the speech extremely offensive and insulting

I heard nothing new except appeals to congressional action. Trump's speech tonight sounded like Trump's campaign speeches with the hypocrisy and arrogance of saying one thing and acting differently. Some of the executive orders and a few pieces of legislation he has signed are diametrically opposed to the words coming out of Trump's mouth tonight. Trump must think no one is paying attention, but Americans are not helped if home mortgages are harder to obtain. Americans are not helped if the financial sectors are deregulated and the coal industry again permitted to dump coal waste into rivers and streams. Americans are not helped with suggestions of health savings accounts that will likely never cover healthcare problems nor tax credits and "access" to health insurance rather than being able to afford it.

There is nothing Trump could say or do that is safe to take as a sign he could redeem himself.  The only reliable predictor of Trump's future actions have been his past actions.  I understand hope and have hope.  It is terribly unwise to gamble and that is what we have done in make this man President.  The odds a so high against a good outcome.  The man so obviously has no shame and seems to be dependent and insecure as a child.  His perpetual lying and inability to genuinely accept responsibility would not be unacceptable to me in anyone in my life.  They might stay in my life but I would have to guard against the damage they might do and protect them but not rely upon them.  I don't know what Trump is competent to do.  He seems to be surrounded primarily by manipulators and enablers.  Those are the majority of his supporters.  "l'enfant terrible" on a grand scale.

I noted the first thing he spoke about as he condenmed hatred was basically a necessary apology for blaming Liberals and Democrats for recent anti-semetic attacks. This so-called man has a lot to clean up, even as he has just begun.

I can't stand listening to the man.  I read the transcript.  Trump had one moment during the campaign as well where he sounded "presidential."  Remember?  He'll be back to his usual tomorrow; attacking the press, trashing Obamacare, boasting of his support, accusing Obama's people for the leaks and the opposition for anti-Semetic threats, crowing about his huge achievements, blaming the generals for the raid...oh wait, he did that today.  Big on talk as usual, short...no devoid...of details on how he's going to execute his wish list.

Trump did not denounce anti-Semitic vandalism and the attack on the Indian engineers. He claimed that THE COUNTRY condemns "hate and evil."

Here's the quote:
"Recent threats targeting Jewish community centers and vandalism of Jewish cemeteries, as well as last week’s shooting in Kansas City, remind us that while we may be a nation divided on policies, we are a country that stands united in condemning hate and evil in all of its very ugly forms."

The wording here is awfully ambiguous for a prepared speech read from a teleprompter. You could reasonably interpret this to mean that Trump has observed the public's reaction to this hateful violence but does not necessarily agree with that reaction himself. You could even interpret this to mean that Trump regards anti-Semitic attacks and racist killings as a way of passing judgment on groups that he hates and regards as evil.

This was another failure to clearly and strongly condemn hateful violence -- on the same day that he alleged that the anti-Semitic threats and vandalism were all part of a false flag operation.

This was not a strong way to begin.

I hope we all should know by now not to judge Trump by what he says, but by what he does.  For Trump, words do not worth much. I will follow his actions, his money and his quest for fame and glory.
President Trump is growing into this position. There is no school or courses to become President. I can see him being a two term President. He'll figure it out.

Trump's proposals are fantasyland: more military spending, no cuts to Social Security and Medicare, large tax cuts, $1Trillion in new spending on infrastructure, all without impact on federal deficit. He railed against Obama racking up federal debt; if his plan were ever enacted, Trump would make Obama-era deficits look like rounding errors.

Trump's speech was very, very solid and uplifting; the presence of Mrs. Owens finally put the spotlight on the real heroes of this country. God bless her for stepping up and representing her husband and military families despite her recent, awful loss.

Remember the goal here is to divert attention from the Bannon/Miller agenda of radical nationalism with an authoritarian cast, delegitimizing the free press, and from the investigation into the ties between Russia and the Trump campaign and administration. Trump said one thing, that really infuriated me, that I hadn't heard him say before.

It was about the FDA.

He has of course talked about deregulation, neglecting to note that ever since Reagen was elected President the size of administrative agencies, and their concommitant ability to enforce codes, has been decimated.

In any event, he specifically said, in this speech, that we will have new cures by repressing the FDA and letting drug companies bestow millions of knew pills on Americans.

As it stands now, the FDA has too little control. This was explained years ago, by John Kenneth Galbraith, in "the Affluent Society,"1957. He explained to us that the regulatory agencies are "colonized by the very industries they are supposed to regulate." Let me get concrete:
Scientists and attorneys paid by the FDA get a lot less compensation than scientists paid by big drug companies. The FDA has fine people, but they are swamped with work (As I said, since Reagen they've been firing more and more great people, ridiculed by the red state rabble as effect, petty beaurocrats). Some of them know that if they treat a corporation favorably, they can get a higher paying job with that corporation.

Recently, I have read articles about heavy psychiatric medicine being prescribed for toddlers on the basis of a "scholarly" article, written by an "esteemed" doctor, who was given 500,000 dollars by the drug company to write the article.

Trump continues with his ridiculous blame of immigrants for crime--against all evidence.  This manipulation of facts cost an Indian engineer his life.  Labs, biotech companies, engineering companies and hospitals have long sought the best and brightest Indian (and Chinese and Middle Eastern) scientists and engineers to enrich their programs.  Enthusiasm for coming to the US is understandably quickly waning.  So who will take those jobs?  The "uneducated" that Trump says he "loves"?  Some scientists my husband attended school with have started labs at Chinese companies and universities, with the promise of funding and support.  The brain drain has only just begun.  Not much chance of remaining a leader in science, technology and medicine.

The only hope I have in Mr Trump lies in the fact he is a well educated wealthy American who was raised with values which all of us understand and most of us respect.

The same may be true for his appointees, so while we as a nation may not advance at a rate similar to the more civilized world these men and women are not deaf, dumb or blind to the people and the voices which surround any of us who step outside.

Regardless he is our President and the men he appoints are our representatives.

We can only trust none prove to be scoundrels.

One of the most effective speeches ever.

Unapologetically putting Americans first.

Anyone who criticizes this principle will be on the losing side of elections for a long time.

Lip Service.

NOT MY PRESIDENT could have stood on his head and spit nickels and I still would not believe one word coming out of his lying mouth.

Although this was better than inauguration speech, Trump's theme remains that somehow America is broken and he is needed to fix it. He struck his usual populist tone, promising jobs for infrastructure projects and reducing illegal immigration. In the same breath, he mentioned clean air and building up the military. Once again, we heard the Republican BS about Obamacare, trying to paint it as forcing Americans into government health insurance plans that they can't afford and claiming that insurance will be cheaper with competition among private insurers but without the onerous mandate designed to bring healthier individuals into the risk pool. Interestingly, this topic got the loudest cheers from Republicans, indicating how obsessed they are with getting rid of the signature piece of Obama's administration (with no coherent replacement). Of course, all of the promises he's made cost money - a lot of it. While railing against increased deficit spending which started under G.W. Bush, his promises to increase spending on infrastructure, immigration enforcement and the military, combined with broad tax cuts for corporations and wealthy people, all but insures massive increases in the federal debt. As the Party that claims to be fiscally responsible, Republicans in Congress are going to have a hard time delivering without risking their reputation (whether or not it is earned). Well, being long on rhetoric and short on action is true of most Presidents, I suppose, so as with Trump.

On three occasions, I have been face to face with wives of fallen soldiers. The first wife in 2002, I did not know. Nonetheless, I remember expressing my gratitude for her sacrifice only to have her mother storm down the aisle during a ceremony.

In 2010, I lost two of my own soldiers. Both had wives, children and more friends than I could dream of having....I cried during President Trump's speech.

The guilt that comes with losing a soldier is real and Trump's words were timely and needed to be shared with the public. I assure you, his words were not pure political and he too will live with a degree of guilt from the loss.

Before Trump, the wars had a meaningless purpose and appeared to be purely designed to stimulate a fictitious economy feeding on US dollars... At least this soldier sacraficed with a clear and specific mission.
tigers don't change stripes.

Here’s the thing: those of of us that come from the business world understand that a legitimate business plan not only includes a vision but a clear objective, strategy and specific tactics to achieve that vision. The plan must include detailed tactics with measurable milestones and metrics. Without tactics, milestones and metrics there can be no accountability, no roadmap to success, no basis that the vision can be achieved.
We heard a vision from a man that has a complete lack of understanding and interest in what it takes to achieve that vision.
Looking for some sign that there is any semblance of something that looks like an actionable, achievable, affordable, logical and reasonable plan behind the empty words.

Bloated rot, phony promises of everything from universal better health care to clean environment to child care for all parents, fantasies belied by his actions to date, “impossible dreams” he claims are “within our grasp”, carnival scare tactics wildly exaggerating problems (a disastrous economy, borders anyone can enter) to justify abuses of power, shameless exploitation of bereaved Navy widow to cover up his narcissistic judgment in ordering a rash military action, calls for unity extended with a claw, all delivered in a flow of bilious threat. [2307]

Trump is a con man, a very talented and very "great" con man, but still a dishonest huckster. Nothing but rhetoric from 45. He didn't say anything very different than he did on the campaign trail. However, I disagree with Nicholas about early education being the panacea for education. It is parenting education that needs to be in the forefront. Until parents learn how to develop a child's language, our citizenry will forever be comprised. Research is strong that children who know more words once they get to school are better equipped to deal with the rigors of high level textbook/technical language. By the time a child gets to an early childhood programs, it is too late. Language exposure must begin before the first year of life.

Ah I love that kind of run in. Sometime last summer I was walking to work, on around 30th St., and saw a tiny baby shoe in the middle of the sidewalk. It was a weirdly melancholy sight, and I looked around but saw no baby carriages nearby. So I set it on a fire hydrant and kept walking. Just before I got to the next avenue, there was a young couple, with a baby carriage, looking somewhat desperately all around as they rushed along. I looked closer and sure enough the disgruntled looking baby had only one sneaker.

So I told them where the other shoe dropped, they were effusively thankful, and everything worked out fine. On the other hand, whenever I lose a glove, I tend to just set the other one down on a mailbox and get a new pair of gloves. And I never lose a shoe, somehow.

As a traditional tree-hugging bleeding heart, I have to put my 2 cents in regarding 17A: I thought it was cute! Reminded me of Bette Midler's "A View From Abroad." PDA didn't bother me either. In fact, I've yet to be offended by anything I've seen in a puzzle. My dad has always been known as Dick, and though my sisters and I tried to change it (many years ago), we finally gave up. As a theatrical tailor and costume historian of sorts, I have to object to the definition for ASCOT as "a cousin of a cravat".  That's like calling a Thorougbred or an Appaloosa "a cousin of a horse".  An ascot is a TYPE of cravat.  Not all cravats are ascots, but all ascots are cravats.

I'm really rather ambivalent on the BROAD controversy. The language changes. Usage changes. And, hallelujah!, society changes.

Nonetheless, when I got 17A (which was right away, since I start in NW), I felt as if I had been socked in the face. I wonder if it would have been easier to take if the "old-fashionedly" in the clue had been replaced by "offensively" or "pejoratively." At least that would have recognized the problem. And it isn't really the term itself that is old-fashioned. The term was always, if not overtly offensive, at least dismissive. The "old-fashioned" part is that derogatory terms for women (and others) used to be more widely accepted than they generally are today. I understand that in some circles they are still used.

I can't find any reason at all for the clue for PDA.

Other than that, a fun puzzle, and my kind of wordplay. Few stumbles, besides wondering which of the many spellings would be used for the U-turn thing. Also the crossing of ADAMA/ALDO, but at least I know that ALDO is a man's name.

The whole point of that Pythagorean clue is that a triangle with a right angle is called a "right triangle" (not a "right angled triangle").

PDA - is that Public Display of affection?
Otherwise, I enjoyed the puzzle. It was easy and a fast solve.

Entirely agree that "Study A Broad" took a bit of the joy from the puzzle--particularly as I solve on the subway, a favorite spot for the most studious among us. Broad as a word is both sexist and derogatory, despite how some might argue. The word itself comes from the word for "breed," so at best it reduces women to breeding. At best, you can trace it from playing cards to those who "turn tricks," so, yeah.

PDA was equally as bad. Why--particularly in this climate--clue in that way? What about a Palm Pilot? What about "Teens in the park"? So many solutions that would have easily avoided that pain point, whilst still resulting in the same answer. Foolish choice.

I agree with Deb that using the word "broad" to refer to a woman in a NYT puzzle is an unfortunate throwback. It offended me in large part because of the return to the public display of misogyny that has crept into our "civic" discourse in recent months. Why not stay away from such derogatory references. I wish Will Shortz, in his wisdom, had pre-empted the clue out of respect for women solvers. I don't think he would allow a puzzler to use "Pigs" in a clue like: 1960s cops, per student rebels.

Yay! I can't believe I get to be the one to post the great Danny Kaye singing about right triangles!

I wasn't really offended by the answer STUDYABROAD, but as a feisty, resilient woman of a certain age I would be upset to be referred to as a tough old broad. I don't like to be called elderly either, because I'm not.

Being called a broad is very low on my list of things that would offend me. And it reminds me of a story my firefighter neighbor told me years ago. He worked in the San Francisco fire department at the time women firefighters were starting to live in the firehouse with the men and everybody was sort of feeling their way, making sure nobody's toes were stepped on. As he was leaving the firehouse one day he called the woman who had just moved in, "Honey." She got all indignant and upset and said, "Never call me that again!" This one also tickles my linguistic funnybone, since the themers' key words represent a range of etymologies and the intermingled "a-" prefixes that have merged in English.

"abroad" and "around" show the Germanic a- prefix descended from on- / an- and meaning “at, in, engaged in.” (alive, asleep, ashore, abed).

"astray" preserves the ast- / est- word opening from Old French, presumably from Latin ex- “outside of,” but influenced in the borrowing by the English prefix a- (as above, in both senses).

"averse" shows the Latin a- prefix descended from a- / ab- and meaning “away from.” (avocation, a priori). Interestingly, none of the themers represent the Greek a- prefix meaning "not" (amoral, agnostic).

"agent" is from the ag- / act- root meaning “doing, performing.” (action, agenda, active). This themer is completely distinct from the others because the "a" cannot be separated out from the "ag." This makes the pronunciation of the pun trickier than the other four.

Yes, we used to have a lot of slang terms for women - dolls, dames, chicks, etc. - and I suppose that wasn't a great thing, but I don't see that most of them were necessarily derogatory even though they could at times be used that way. When I think of 'broad' in particular, the first thing that pops into my head is "one tough broad," which I would consider a term of respect.

As with a lot of things, it's all a matter of intent. I remember asking one of my sons not so very long ago how things were going. His response: "Ah, you know. Women. Teenagers." I may even have been guilty of saying 'women' with a shake of the head or roll of the eyes at some time in my past. I suppose it's remotely possible that some of our female commenters may have said "men" in the same way. It's not the words that are the problem; it's the intent.

I completely understand the women who felt the play resonated with their lives; the issues it raises are legitimate. The problem lies in the craft of storytelling: despite very solid performances (and an outstanding one from Janie Dee), the play is pedestrian. Many plot developments are contrived or achingly familiar from countless better plays, and the resolution of various scenarios are predictable and/or dull. Yes you root for LINDA but she is given no reasonable way out, simply smashed to bits by forces and coincidences out of her control, and ultimately the play seems to be sneering at the very prospect of pro-feminist progress.
Even the resonances--King Lear, "in the moment" cult groups, the threat of a younger woman--are just thrown in as clunky warnings and motifs. This is blender playwriting that says nothing new, and seems to delight in destroying an admirable central figure. Janie Dee deserves better. So does a theatregoing audience.
just awful despite the compelling performance of Janie Dee. Do not bother.

Did I see a different play than Ben Brantley?? Do I find myself saying that only a woman would understand the women in this play as well as the woman who wrote it? There, I said it.
I attended with three other women and we were in complete agreement that this play was riveting, extremely well acted and staged.
Mr. Brantley's unfavorable review of Linda highlights the plot of the play. Women are often not seen, take seriously or given the proper credit they deserve.

There is a fatal problem in the story which I can point out without spoilers.

Linda wants to change how the world sees women, and how women see themselves, by marketing cosmetics in one way rather than another. This is her central obsession. It's also blatantly self-contradictory and deeply delusional, yet the story completely passes this by without comment. (The products in question do nothing special, it's the branding that's being debated from first scene to last.)

It's possible that Skinner expects us to see this as a given, requiring no comment, and therefore all the bad things that happen to her are similar manifestations of this refusal to see her own contradictions. In which case, okay, but nobody else in the story seems to see the problem either, or even share her dream, so what seems at first to be engaging social comment is ultimately soap opera.

The best thing about the piece is that Skinner has found playable metaphors for how older and younger women perceive each other, which is difficult. But some aspects of the story do feel like going down a checklist.

I saw this play as lot more than a feminist tract on "the afflictions of contemporary womanhood" including low-self esteem; self mutilation etc. The play wasn't perfect but I found it very satisfying and saw it more as a commentary on corporate life; political life etc. -- i.e. the more things change the more they stay the same.

I wish Mr. Brantley were a more thoughtful and analytical reviewer. I was recently in the Times archives looking at some old reviews of Caryl Churchill's "Top Girls" and found both Frank RIch's review when the original London cast did it at the Public and Mr. Brantley's review of a 2010 revival. Mr. RIch brought so much more to his reviews. I miss him.

Jeez. In a review of a major serious work one would expect Mr. Brantley to address the basic issues of whether the playwright and director succeeded and if not, why not.
This indecipherable review about the invisibility of women of a certain age is antagonistically disrespectful of both the rising-star playwright, Penelope Skinner and the esteemed director, Lynne Meadow. Ms Meadow, in particular, was deserving of much more than an irrelevant, stupefying comment about the intensity of the play.
Ignore this meandering, graceless review. Really. The actors are winsome and talented, the writing is crisp, the direction is stellar. LINDA is a funny, challenging, portrait of a woman whose advertising campaign for a beauty company strokes the hope that women can rise above rumor-mongering, sexism and ageism. What could go wrong?
The play is very entertaining. All the actors are fantastic and the set is excellent.  The review is correct in many aspects  but doesn't convey how interesting the show is. It's never boring!

Ignore this review and see the play, which is one of the better Off-Broadway dramas of the season. This is an intelligent and well-written work about all the ways that our culture’s sexual attitudes and body obsessions are internalized to distort a women’s self-image. It is beautifully staged and well-acted and is not dogmatic about its themes. (And, by the way, far superior to The Village Bike.)

Brantley's review PERPETUATES the theme of the play: Women are often not seen, taken seriously, or given the proper credit they deserve. Brantley is deaf, dumb, blind, and, most unfortunately for the public, powerful. This play deserves to be seen; it's well-directed, well-acted, and well-designed. It's funny, sad, poignant, enjoyable, and eternally relevant. Go!

You are right that it is a contradiction but it is part of the character's self-deluding perception of everything about her life.  And her boss does, in effect, point it out by reminding her that the point of her job is to sell cosmetics, not make people happy. We can all see what her boss sees: that she is just kidding herself by thinking that a makeup ad can make the world a better place. As she is kidding herself about her marriage, her children, etc.

Couldn't agree more, Jay. I also saw Village Bike, and I do think this is a superior work. My friend and I were constantly nudging each other over scenes like the one where Linda objects to her girls 'helping' her with kitchen chores. As in, to "help" her meant that the chores were "hers". I used to have this same argument (er, discussion) with my own husband and daughter. And the idea that women over 50 are "invisible"? Please. Every day I doubt my existence in the eyes of others. The playwright nails it.

Yes, LINDA is intelligent and well-written.  Yes, it is beautifully staged and well-acted.  Yes, it has a deep understanding for the pitfalls of women in modern society.  And that got me through the first act.  But things started happening before intermission, and they accelerated in Act II.  Awful event after awful event happened to its protagonist, and they were not the inevitable byproducts of a sexist society, they were deliberate punishments inflicted upon her by the playwright.  Really, the playwright could not stop punishing her main character.  About two thirds of the way through, the protagonist makes a really stupid decision, which is justified by the playwright making her heroine momentarily mentally unbalance, which the playwright then uses to tear apart the poor woman's life for the rest of the play.  The last scene is like a final "Screw you" delivered to the heroine for daring to hope she could make a positive impact in the world.  I don't usually agree with Mr. Brantley, but I think he's on target here.
Kecia Lewis is the best in a play which is perhaps better in theory than practice.

I have fond memories of seeing a high school production of “The Skin of Our Teeth” some years ago. I suppose I was young and impressionable (and an aspiring writer and actor, to boot), but I immediately loved how the play attempted to take a stand at the intersection of history and modernity, literature and philosophy, and comedy and tragedy, to present an ultimately hopeful message about human nature.

By the way, in addition to your coverage of this go-round of the play, thanks also for linking to Brooks Atkinson’s review of the 1942 production. It’s a blast to read the colorful newspaper copy of 75 years ago, including such gems as: “[Wilder] has looked on life with his welkin eye like a prophet; he has winked his other eye in sociable good humor.” Also: “The actors are in very fine fettle.” Delightful.
I wish I could force myself to like it. I tried hard, I failed.

This production was lively as were the actors but the play felt dated.  As hard as everyone worked to enliven it, they could not.  We stuck with it to the end and although there were some interesting moments, watching this play was a bit of a chore.

There was a terrific mainstage production of "The Skin of Our Teeth" about two months ago at Marymount Manhattan College by guest director Owen Thompson. Universities are actually doing a tremendous amount of innovative theater work these days that go largely unnoticed by the arts media.

It's also worth mentioning that, even though Thornton Wilder won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for "Skin," he's been accused of near-plagiarism for borrowing rather liberally from James Joyce's novel "Finnegans Wake," without offering any credit to Joyce's work as the inspiration for the play.

Excellent review!  It is a tricky play, but this production is fabulous.  Really unusual, original and fresh.  It gives a sense of the groundbreaking quality the piece must have had in 1942.  Wilder gives Brecht a run for his money here, and Arin Arbus,  by adding the original songs, by Cesar Alvarez, has practically brought the show to the level of Threepenny Opera.  Much  like with Pygmalion and My Fair Lady, it will be as hard to imagine the play without them henceforth.

Sorry to say we left at intermission, after first 2 acts, which I think I have never done. I wanted to like it, and some parts were exceedingly well done, but the whole, it seemed to need more time to finish somehow. To blend. It was too long and rambling, and tiresome. It needed more glue and thought to carry one over that length of time (which I can do, I sit through operas quite often). I found it hard to hear some of the lines, which could have been an issue to continuity.

I love reading about it however, it makes sense then.
I've always wanted to change my last name to Antrobus.

Living in Houston I have not seen this production (nor in fact any production) of the play. However, In 1960 as a junior in high school in deep southeast Texas  I wrote my English research paper on Thornton Wilder and his plays. In particularly I recall "The Skin of Our Teeth" as an allegory of hope in spite of everything sort of story. While the critical analysis of this particular production perhaps finds the lack of subtlety of the play itself trite and simplistic, I can say that even after all these years I still find the message to be encouraging and hopeful particularly in light of the disarray in which the world seems find itself at present. Hopefully, we will as a species once again endure the uncertainty prevalent today by "the skin of our teeth." I think it is a timely production regardless of its perceived shortcomings.

Very much worth seeing, especially for Mary Wiseman's endlessly entertaining Sabina. The sexual politics of The Skin of Our Teeth is obviously very dated, but Wilder's theatrical invention still feels surprising and fresh, and TFANA's production makes the most of it. Also: loved the mammoth and dinosaur. The only superfluous element was the added songs (music and lyrics by Cesar Alvarez), which not only added nothing but detracted from Wilder's and the company's work--their tone didn't match the script, and they extended the already long running time needlessly.
My most painful experience in 60 years of theater-going. An artless hammering of banal allegory. Talent-free all around.
