So he proposes repealing the budget caps (sequester) on military spending but not domestic spending. Those priorities just make me want to cry. If American voters are good with this feeding frenzy for the war machine, if they believe that's where they think our strength comes from, and that patriotism is only about war, I think we're lost. With the few years of healthy life I probably have left, what's the use in actively resisting this madness? I believe we are nearing a tipping point in the American consciousness where the voices of reason and humanity, no matter how many or how loud, will be demeaned, ignored and then silenced and the "movement" Trump claims he started will rush headlong down the same nationalistic, war-making path that Nazi Germany took. The German people were not stupid people and most were "good Christian" people, but they bought in and fell in line. And we know the rest. I am just grateful neither of my adult children would qualify for a military draft and I have no grandchildren to pray for.

The president has massive character flaws, the fact that the bar was set (reset by him time and again) so low as to make him look presidential last evening changes this not at all.  He has no ability or desire to develop a plan that will help the economy or our security (so far his musings will diminish both).  and to the point of this column, spending more on defense and the military is going in the wrong direction.  Cut the spending here, sure get our allies to pay more.  Invest in our education systems, healthcare, infrastructure....truly look forward.  This man is not capable and unfortunately talked a very wide game last night that gives his cronies plenty of leeway and ammo to do just as they please - which is bleed the country of anything useful be that money, energy, leadership, the moral high ground.....sad.
Just watch: Trump is already planning to take credit for the long overdue major expansion at Laguardia now underway and planned for years. I heard it with my own ears in his speech "Airports!"
A 56 billion increase in defense spending, an undetermined decrease in our taxes, and an incalculable decrease in anyone's brain cells who believes both will occur.

It broke my heart to see the recent widow being taken advantage of.
Trump has no shame. He called Yemen raid during which a Navy SEAL, William Owens died, Trump called him Ryan and said the raid a brilliantly successful operation
Carryn could not stop sobbing and shame on Trump who loved adulation to make her a spectacle.
That was probably one of the most shamelessly exploitative things I’ve seen in a long time.

i agree. Despite 50 years of growing a global development business with many side shows, he has no bevy of loyal friends to help him govern the nation. He has his family and a few billionaires. The young ones can't pass the ethics check and the old ones are money launderers or vampires.

Donald reflexively turns to the military -- i cringe every time i see a marine salute him -- and he brags of the prowess he declined to display when his nation needed him.

altogether, the strongman hopes to rely on the military. Let's hope the military doesn't rely on the president. It's not clear Donald understands the law or the limits of his authority.
And his foot so bad that he could not remember which did not allow him to serve, but it certainly did not prevent him from playing golf those years. Will somebody check his golf records...

I am reading that Seventy (70) percent of ALL military spending, worldwide, is by NATO countries. And that NATO countries that are deeply in debt, like Greece and Italy, are spending more -- or slightly under -- the agreed-upon 2 percent GDP target. How is this not "military maddness?" Surely NATO nations could cut back to 60 percent of all worldwide military spending -- or to 1.5% of their GDP?  Is not -- in the case of the U.S. -- high and unsustainable debt NOT a threat to our national security? With Trump and the GOP, seems it isn't ...
You really have to wonder about someone so obsessed with size.

Just think of all the useful things you could be thinking about and writing about, and yet you remain obsessively focused on Trump.
How about a change of subject?
I'm sure there are many others of your former readers who find this unrelenting sniping tedious, predictable and uninteresting.

Thank you, Frank Bruni.

I watched Trump last night. It appears he wants to up our military budget by $60 Billion so he can starve the beast, starting with cuts to the EPA, IRS and DOJ. All the civil rights lawyers hired by Obama will be laid off.

It looks like he wants to help Session and Bannon get their new racist immigration policy put into national policy.
How desperate an these generals and admirals be for a job working for a man that recently said he knows more than they do? He just yesterday said they were responsible for the botched raid in Yemen.

In my (not so humble) opinion, the call to spend so much more money unnecessarily, on the military build-up, is to placate the military commanders who are sitting on their haunches while the POTUS makes such an appalling mess of this country that the military has to come in to depose him and restore order. It's his version of paying the Mafia their "dues" to provide him protection...but I see the day coming when the military will see him for what he is, and move to protect this nation from an internal war...not necessarily a military one, but certainly a civil disturbance aimed at sending this POTUS packing in disgrace.
To put it politely, Mr. Trump's over-inflated obessuib with his proposed bloated military build-up starts with those little hands...
Sad and true. The bright light in the article was the thought of stuffing Paul Ryan in a capitol broom closet.

You're correct - with trump it is all about image and substance is secondary.  He hasn't got a clue about how to govern, or the implications of what he sayd or does.  trump just knows that his followers cheer when he says these things.  Everything else is besides the point.
Another bullseye. Don't let him get away with any of these egregious hypocrisies, delusions or self-serving, ignorant assumptions.
The trouble with buying your boys new toys is that sooner or later they will want to play with them.

I am with you Mr. Bruno.

Donald---what are the facts? What are the figures? What is it (specifically) you will be achieving? We are grindinding down the personnel we have. We remain doing police work in a very hostile Middle East. Is it time to rethink a draft?

Has Mr. Putin not been teaching us that the new theater for war is the computer and our ability to deflect the drive toward autocracy being foisted on us by computer hacking. Our President is obviously not a great conceptual thinker. But, I do wish that he understood that the struggle for hearts and minds is already being taken care of by multiple well-funded security agencies. If they are not organized in a way that keeps the integrity of our elections securie then it is time to rethink that organization.

Finally, multiple assignments to theaters of intense violence is just plain wrong.
If we want to take care of our troops let us put a rigidly enforced rule against exposing them to more than a specifically identified number of days in a combat theater.

This is simply the Bush-Cheney strategy anew.  Spend, spend, spend on virtually everything, then cut taxes.  Then complain that we don't have the money to support Medicare, Social Security and Medicaid and propose to dismantle/privatize them in the name of preserving them.  We've seen this movie before and it doesn't end well.

I agree.  We already spend more than necessary on the military industrial complex & need to fight wars to keep it employed to justify the spending.  I'm talking about both the manpower and the hardware.

In response to several comments about how today's Generals might feel about being thrown under the bus by the likes of Trump - the boy President - I just have to imagine the scene if a true American hero, and a classic warrior like Marine Lt. General Smedley Butler (two time Medal of Honor recipient) was spoken to by Trump like Trump spoke of the leaders who carried out his orders in Yemen. Butler, a man who's real life story is beyond anything Hollywood can conjure up would not have brooked a foolish man like Trump.
Trump could not have shined his shoes.
Consider the possibility that the military buildup is being used to get the military on Trump's side so as to avoid a coup.
I didn't fault Clinton for avoiding the Draft and I won't fault Trump either.  Any sane person of our age tried to get out of that dastardly war.

Lately I have been disheartened by NYT lack of balanced content and increasingly slanted presentation of information and opinion.  Review the entire 01 March digital edition and you will find no articles, or editorials presenting anything but negativity toward the Trump administration. I’m no “Trump-o-phile,” but there must be intelligent alternative opinion. Has the NYT even looked for it?  As for slanted presentation, here is what I mean:  Note the photo chosen for Mr. Bruni’s “Trump’s Military Preening.”  American active duty military are ultimately led by civilian leadership. As such they steadfastly adhere to an ethic that requires them to be apolitical while in uniform. This photo shows the Joint Chiefs of Staff standing and applauding, misleadingly suggesting that the Joint Chiefs support the President’s proposed policy for funding and use of the military. I am certain the NYT watched the entire speech and should have noted that the ONLY time the Joint Chiefs applauded during the President’s remarks was after remarks that acknowledged the value of our military personnel, and the sacrifice of Senior Chief William Owens and the loss to his family. They stood to support the soldiers and sailors they lead, not to support any proposed policy. To suggest otherwise dishonors the Joint Chiefs, those they lead, and the ethos of America’s professional military. It is this kind of sophomoric posturing that is chipping away at my faith in the integrity of the NYT.

Those billions of dollars on military spending are going into somebody's pockets, somebody who votes and contributes to Republican politicians. He's selling hatred and bigotry and stupidity wrapped in the flag of patriotism. In the meantime, the rich, who can't figure out what to do with all their wealth, keep growing richer.

In his first couple of years in power, Hitler built up nationalist fervor &"Make Germany Great Again" after the humiliations that followed the loss of WW I & the forced signing of the Treaty of Versailles. He "Made Germany Great Again" by stirring faux populist nationalism, building a massive military, exalting the "real Germans - the Aryans" over the "untermenschen," promising to rid Germany of the "other" who, he assured,were re sponsible for all of Germany's problems, & discrediting or destroying all of the press that was critical of him or not under his direct control. He created a "cult of personality" as the only leader strong enough to restore Germany to it's former glory.

Trump, under guidance from the alt-right neo-fascists of his base & among his advisors is following the exact same playbook.

While I don't know if Steve Bannon in particular is fascistic, I do know that he has called himself a Leninist in a 2013 interview, saying" “Lenin wanted to destroy the state, & that’s my goal, too. I want to bring everything crashing down, & destroy all of today’s establishment.” He does not want to build a better America, but to destroy what Americans built over the past 240 years. He calls for "deconstruction" of the government. Derrida's concept has many meanings, but " the systematic undoing of understanding, "Whenever deconstruction finds a nutshell...the very idea is to crack it open & disturb this tranquility" & "a refusal of authority in general" are among them.

The whole speech reminded me of the old saw about the boy who cried wolf, but magnified a thousandfold. Mr. Trump has lied so often, so flagrantly, about so many things, that he has poisoned his own well of goodwill. When he opens his mouth, I assume he'll be lying. And that's not my fault: it's his. The military buildup is just one more example, and I find myself wondering, what does he really mean? Does he mean, I'm going to funnel billions of dollars to my fellow corporatists in the military-industrial complex? If those same billions were spent instead on, say, integrating the military and VA health care systems and computerizing the whole thing, how many lives, American lives, could be saved? How many American lives improved?

But Mr. Bruni is right. Trump doesn't want to do anything for anyone but himself, and the drudgery and wonkery of getting our vets taken care of bores him. Things that go zoom and boom and zap are far more exciting.

Or maybe, Mr. Trump means nothing at all, and tomorrow he'll be fulminating against military spending and vowing to cut it to the bone. Who can know?

Mr. Bruni, I appreciate your first paragraph trying to lend some optimism in DJT's speech, but even his gratuitous mention of recent hate crimes was hypocritical as he most recently has posited that perhaps they weren't really the actions of hate crimes, but acts by those who opposed his administration in an effort to make him look bad. Not only is his premise hypocritical, if true, it would afford him an opportunity to really speak out about these atrocities that are harbingers (and reminders) of what can follow. Instead, they were all included in one poorly constructed and very brief sentence. I think your paragraph might have contained more words. If one or both of the two Steves were the authors of his speech (I truly doubt he had little input), they fell short in their attempts at diverting his generally obstreporous rhetoric. I found his whole speech empty, but highly designed as reality show entertainment, including his comments during the applause for Navy Seal Owen's widow...worthy of Dr. Phil or Geraldo Rivera. Truly shameful. Sad.

However, even sadder is the devotion of Trump followers who are oblivious to the emptiness of his rhetoric. Example: Trump met with Black leaders seeking an audience for support of HBCs (Historically Black Colleges) and were fearing loss of federal Pell grants. Anticipating a discussion as DJT invited them into the Oval Office, they instead got a photo-op as he signed an EO that had recognition but nothing of substance.
I think Trump, though he never served, identifies generals as "winners", and thus, wants to be chummy with them. But my guess is, in a time of war, Donny would run the other way.
Unfortunately Trump's swollen Pentagon is in the U.S. tradition of confusing saber-rattling with moral strength.

When a guy with thin skin and a big ego hires generals, fires diplomats and pumps up military spending, it's easy to see what's about to go down. Protest  now - don't wait for the next war to begin--especially if you are of draft age.

"You cannot simultaneously prevent and prepare for war."

Albert Einstein

In this he is a true Republican; cut social programs, cut taxes on the wealthy, increase military spending.  No matter his campaign rhetoric about scaling back overseas military ventures; he's doing his damnest to please the R's at the top and forget about the base.  Where's my job Don?

I cringed when he talked about using the "torch" to "light up the world". Is he talking about shedding light, or setting the world on fire? Some wordsmithing to clarify his intentions would have been welcome.

I may be alone in this but I thought he took advantage of this grieving person, Mrs Owens. He used her grief in the worst possible way, invading her privacy and implying that her husband's heroism redounded on Trump himself.
I might be willing to support his military buildup if part of it is that his children will be serving - in front line positions.

Watching the Democrats last night, same as last year, was painful. Besides Bernie, they have no footing. Good intentions, terrible messaging so we return to the seesaw of obstructionist Republicans back to save the day, build up to war and applause, simplistic answers to complex issues that appeals to many. Though I have to give Trump credit, he is learning how to sell his product.
Who and where is the Democrat coalition?

What troubles me most about Trump's call for a military build up is what's next? I have had enough of wars in my lifetime: the Korean stalemate, the Vietnam disaster, the Grenada nonsense, Poppy Bush's wise decision to limit involvement in defending Kuwait (Congrats, Poppy!), trillions wasted and thousands of lives lost in Cheney's bumbling adventures in Afghanistan and Iraq, plus other, more minor skirmishes.

So what's next? Another war to distract us from all of Trump's promises, most of which will be unmet? Please, let's not go there!

I was also moved by Carryn Owens' loss and the depth of her grief. And I sincerely believe that she was there for one reason only: to love her husband by permitting the entire country to show honor and respect for his sacrifice.
I wish that everyone would stop trying to make some kind of political point out of her presence. Whatever Trump's reason was, and whatever others thought of it,
Carryn Owens was there to show love and honor to her husband.

"Too much!"

"Not enough!"

It reminds me of the old comedy bit of helping someone move a couch, and the person keeps saying a little this way, a little that way, until the helper blows up in exasperation, "Will you make up your mind already!"

It would mildly funny, if it were not the fact that the topic is the overall status and readiness and long-term needs of our military forces.

I am not at all confident Trump even knows what our military is even *for*. Hint: it is not simply "to fight wars." It is to be ready to fight wars, and to meanwhile secure a fair amount of the globe's stability and freedom of commerce within our areas of influence.

I do not trust this man to be able to understand -- or even care about -- anything that does not directly impact his own wallet and those of his offspring. It is simply the limitations of the man himself; it is who he is.

Shallow. But anyone from New York has known that for decades.

In the long dismal history of bloviating sanctimonious hypocrisy, the condescending treatment of that unfortunate wife of the slain soldier in Yemen by Trump and his sycophants has to rank among the most embarrassing and degrading.

Obama, a dictator with his executive orders. Trump, what a wonderful president with his executive orders. Obama, so dumb he has to read everything from a teleprompter.  Trump, what a wonderful speech because he kept on message using a teleprompter. "Republican" is just another word for hypocrite.

Somewhere Gen. Eisenhower is screaming with none of us to hear.

The military industrial complex is alive and well ( especially under republican fiefdoms )

Having said that, this is just a correction to the cutbacks a few years ago and furthermore to the President Obama not wanting to kowtow to previous republican bullying over the debt and deficit.

At the time, there were grandiose exclamations that 'severe'' cuts would decimate this sector or that one, however everything kept chugging along to produce 75 straight months of private sector job growth ( and counting )

Aye, this administration was left with such a mess. ( massive eye roll )

All this is just prelims for the war this administration is shopping for. The first casualty ( and counting ) was a week in to the term. More will come and more will be propped up for gross political grandstanding as they were last eve'.

This is what you voted for people. ( at least a clear minority of you )
userLocation: This is what you voted for people (at least a minority of you)

commentBody:
Bruni has again lowered the bar and stepped in quicksand much like his stationary colleagues gathered in the Congressional Hall, many foolishly adorned in all white, exposed in their uniform of bigotry. Presidential in tone and demeanor, and unifying in his message, Trump caught the Democrats by surprise. Praising the military and law enforcement caused a fright and consternation on whether to sit or stand.

Suddenly the sullen left looks more like the frothing at the mouth incoherent figure they imagined. The old left wing power elite is now revealed as the empty vessel one suspected. Unable to rise to the occasion, Bruni's cohorts looked remiss as eloquence has shifted right as have ideas of being inclusive with a promising future in contrast to the empty promises of those adorned in white, comfortably glued to their seats.

He's an abomination, and some of the news media's ecstatic responses (from the likes of Katy Tur and Van Jones) only reveal how easily we are fooled and how low our bar. His ignorance is bottomless and his character a black hole. Words written by someone else and delivered by a monster playing a human being do not add up to a President. (As the Twitter feeds of many Veterans succinctly pointed out last night.) The only credit he deserves is for the ability to read aloud.

Trump is increasing military spending to start a war and improve his ability to crack down on citizens. Period. He plays the music and even some of the smartest journalists start to dance; thankfully, Mr. Bruni, you are not among the revelers at the circus. The only story right now is Russia, as it's the only thing that can bring him down, and we follow distractions at our peril. Our inattention, optimism and overconfidence in progressive values got us here; don't allow them to blind us now. With a majority in the House or Senate we can get Trump's taxes and force an impeachment, so the next 2 years are critical. Jeff Sessions' Justice Dept will not oppose voter suppression, and we—and the world—cannot afford to lose.

Trump is only interested in things that make good TV.  A sharp-looking new destroyer or fighter jet is a great visual; a well-crafted diplomatic agreement is ho-hum.  The sadder part (Sad!) is that he does not understand that military force is a tool used to bring parties to the table; it is used in service of diplomatic objectives which must themselves be legitimate, or no amount of might will bring about the objective.  We don't take over countries and occupy them, after all.

As a veteran I believe the increase in the military budget is misplaced. It is cheaper to rely on collective security, but this administration apparently doesn’t seem to want allies. It should. The America First notion will have a tendency to separate us from our allies and that is not wise. The use of soft power and diplomacy to achieve national aims is much preferred, not only by the US, but by the world.

As has been pointed out, we spend more on our military than the next seven counties in the world combined. And this would be at the expense of other important federal programs. I suggest that there is a better use of these funds. The social safety net, infrastructure, clean air and water, education, and creating a job-friendly environment in the country are all preferred over this unwarranted increase.

It's clear to me why Trump needs a stronger  military.   When you simultaneously gut domestic social support programs, stop prosecuting civil rights violations, disenfranchise millions of voters, empower brutal, racist law enforcement tactics, neuter the free press, and stoke the violent hate of alt-right groups, he'll inevitably need a stronger military to enforce martial law right here at home. And at that point, it will appear the logical thing to do. His and Bannon's path must be altered before we reach the tipping point.

The Donald won't feel satisfaction until a display of military hardware 100 miles long is paraded by for him to smugly observe as if he were Kim Jung-un.

We're stuck with a stubby-fingered narcissist as president who will never be satiated no matter how loudly his adulators shriek of his "Great America Again-ness."

Democrats, I beg of you, focus on local level elections and political initiatives alongside of the national and global efforts.

54 billion would give every kid in America 19-21 years old around 6000 a year for college tuition. Combine that with what America already spends on grants etc we could probably send every kid 19-23 years old to college free.

54 billion would be a great start for medicare for all.

54 billion would fix all the GOP fabricated ills with the ACA

54 billion would reduce the national debt by 54 billion and interest

54 billion to an already bloated military budget is hardly conservative or responsible. Combine that with 25 billion for a wall is totally irresponsible.

We spend more on the military than the next 7 highest spending nations. What fabricated problem does 54 billion solve?

This is our money enough is enough, please write your congressional representatives. It only takes a moment, with cut and paste you can hit three in the next 10-15 minutes. This comment could also easily be cut and pasted into an email to your congressional representative. Got more time, call. A participatory government does not work unless you participate.

Instead of increasing the military budget, it should be cut, severely.  We spend more than the next several countries combined, a criminal misuse of public funds.  The greatest threats Americans face are not outside our borders, they are outrageously high health care costs, untenable college debt, growing income and wealth disparity/wage stagnation, crumbling infrastructure, gun violence, the poisoning of our environment and climate change.  Let's invest in those areas, instead!

Spending $54 billion more on military weaponry won't buy us any additional security. You know what will? Weaning ourselves off of fossil fuels. This is not some leftist pollyanish conspiracy, it's a real defense strategy.

On July 23, 2015, the Department of Defense, in a report to Congress, labelled climate change a "present security threat". Get that? PRESENT security threat.

If they insist on spending $54 billion more (where's that coming from, by the way?), then let's spend it on something that will buy us actual security, not some military hardware for the chest puffers to drool over. Let's start a crash program to enhance our energy security.

Let's face it, what were the Iraq and Kuwait wars about if not oil? And neither war bought us any security. Quite the opposite, in fact.

So let's do something useful for the money. It won't assuage the need for some to inflate their egos, but it will buy us security.

History has proven that times of political turmoil such as we are experiencing now end up in armed conflicts. President Trump is correct to sit down with his military experts to prepare our military to deal effectively with this likely scenario in our future. His increase in military spending demonstrates to our allies and adversaries alike that America will continue to pursue its commitment to lead the world in the preservation of democratic ideals. The cost of modernization of our military capabilities is small compared to the consequences incurred by not keeping up with the rapid changes our world is presently caught up in. This added expense can be dramatically reduced if we stipulate that for every dollar spent we should eliminate a dollar that is now being wasted.

I am a retired military officer, 22 years in the Air Force and 24 years as a Boeing engineer on the B-1B bomber and F-22 stealth fighter. After retiring from the Air Force, I earned my 5th college degree, all in engineering and physics.

My advice. Re-instate the military draft. It is the best way for Americans to get to know each other. Two years of government service for every 18 year old, male and female, no deferments. Not all in the military. No more engagement in civil wars or religious wars. Let them solve themselves. Avoid all insurgencies. Vietnam and Iraq showed that we are clueless in such wars. Americans suffer from attention disorders, and we can't stand wars of long duration where there are no front lines and no score card. We barely managed a draw in Korea, and we lost in Iraq and Afghanistan, because Americans just tune out after a few years of no apparent progress. Defend our homeland and our vital allies. To Hell with Africa and most of Asia. Enforce the Monroe Doctrine for North and South America, and for God's sake, stop supporting right wing police states.

Above all, support education and science. Every American should know and understand that all fundamentalist religions are stupid and evil. The Universe is nearly 14 billion years old and was not created in 6 days. Show no respect for peddlars of snake oil.

I used to be an Eisenhower Republican but the current Republican Party is owned by the mega wealthy and is unAmerican.

I urge you to read President Eisenhower's 1961 cautionary speech in which he warns the American people about the threat to our nation's economy and to our future security of an ever-expanding military industrial complex. http://coursesa.matrix.msu.edu/~hst306/documents/indust.html

When we outspend the rest of the planet many times over in defense spending I do not understand what the purpose of this is, at the expense of other government functions which per their logic will no longer exist so will not need that money. Same thing with nuclear weapons.

This guy must have real small hands. The insecurity is nauseating.

Bravo Frank Bruni, exactly right.
I would add that Trump's tribute to the wife of the slain Navy Seal was a grotesque manipulation of a tragedy, a classic ploy of the con.
Here was the dangerous man Trump, sending our heroes of the Navy Seal Team 6 on a mission that now know was not actually fully planned, approving the mission over dinner.
Trump sent Ryan to his death, he is fully responsible for what is now known to be a disaster. Ryan's father knows this. And yet not only does Trump fail to take responsibility (as Kennedy did with Bay of Pigs), but he moves this fine woman into position as his shield, and lies that the mission gained useful intelligence. A manipulation and a lie, celebrated by this awful man as setting a record for applause. What a con, even bragging on how extreme his ability to fool us is.

I am baffled by the rave reviews for Trump's speech last night. It was a mediocre speech read by a tyro on a teleprompter.  As Mr. Bruni observed, the rhetoric was giggle worthy. The content was the same old stuff we've heard since he began campaigning for the presidency.  He started with a belated and welcome denunciation of growing anti-Semitism, but it was canned political correctness coming out of Trump's mouth, dictated by his speechwriters.  He continued to demonize all immigrants as murderous criminals.  He failed to present substantial proposals to reduce poverty in the United States.  He has no plan to improve or replace the ACA. Just because he yammered for sixty minutes in a lower voice without directly insulting his "enemies" and no fistfights broke out in the audience doesn't mean that we're seeing a new, presidential Donald Trump.

When I was a child growing up in New York, I used to play war with toy soldiers. I wonder if Donald Trump ever did that. I grew up in the 1950s and was weened on WW II movies like Bataan, The Purple Heart, Wing and a Prayer.

That was the last war where we wore the white hat, where we knew who our enemies really were. Every American joined in the war effort, and the nation was united to win.

When I got drafted in 1967 and sent to Vietnam and following year, it was a rude awakening for me to realize that not all wars we engage in are "winnable." It has been downhill ever since.

So when Donald Trump stands at the podium and declares that America has to start winning wars again, it sends a chill up and down my spine. This from a man whose closest brush with the military was being sent to a posh military school in upstate New York because he was failing in high school.

And now he is playing war but with real soldiers. Chilling.

Arguably, our military does need more money, because it is a bit too close to Winchestering its ammo, drones, petrol and such after so many wars. Does it need more ships, a few certainly, but what kind? Not carriers (because of China's stand off missile capability) but maybe hard to detect nuclear subs plus a few more surface units tailored to real world use.

Anyway a blank check for $50 billion and change is an incompetent way to do military budgets.

Oh, and we are going to pay for it by slashing the State Department (also a terrific way to punish the 100 Foreign Service and other State Department experts who dissented from the original, highly stupid "Muslim ban." Rep. Nunes is correct to worry about McCarthyism, only it's coming from his Republican side of the aisle.
Maybe it’s a defense mechanism.

I'm seeing a fair number of comments from the "puff your chest" crowd regarding Mr. Bruni's respect, or lack thereof, for our military.

I believe it's people like Mr. Bruni who show the most respect for our military. They don't want to see unnecessary spending, which often leads to unnecessary military adventures. They're in favor of DEFENSE spending, not so much for MILITARY spending. And yes, there's a huge difference.

For myself, my military service has never been mocked or insulted by those on the left. The insults I received (an example..."you weren't in combat") have been at the hands of those on the right, particularly before the Iraq War. And none had themselves served in the military.

Chest puffing does not a national security strategy make.
For every $1 spent on Pentagon, how much of it ends up in the pocket of Joe SixPack in Fly Over Country?  How many jobs in Middle America does $54 generate?

Obviously, Mr. Bruni, you reason from the hypothesis that President Trump wants to preserve peace. Then you are correct, adding 54,000,000,000 $ seems unnecessary.

Indeed, as you point out, the USA outspends the combination of the next seven biggest defense spenders. However, if The Trumpster considers morphing the Department of Defense into the Department of Offense, it won't be nearly enough.

There seems to be a peculiar blind-spot in the American military psyche that leads it to maintain an unwavering belief in the value of hugely expensive technology as a game-changer. And this despite participating in a succession of conflicts in which the opponent was generations behind and proved extremely hard, if not impossible to beat.

From little slant-eyed guys in black pajamas to bearded blokes in dresses, they have cleverly countered undisputed technological superiority and forced you to accept peace on their terms. I was a child, but I still remember seeing the last chopper taking off from the roof of the embassy in Saigon in 1975. It was the opening item on the evening news, here in Belgium.

Winning wars is about being willing to die for your cause. No amount of money, no technological edge will change that. Unfortunately, looking at the behavior of your self-identified "elites", it seems very doubtful that you stand any chance there...

(Contrary to WW2, were the "have's" were eager to serve. For which we in Europe should be eternally grateful.)

I think Trump is trapped in his adolescence, when Daddy shunted him off to quasi-miIitary school because he was too much trouble to have around. Trump fixated on the miIitary men at the schools as alternate father figures and wanted desperately to impress them as he could not seem to do with Daddy. This is an excellent dissection by Frank Bruni, which asks all the right questions.

The American right's reflexive support for increased military spending is hard to fathom. Despite Trump's fantasy version of history, the nation's continual massive armament since the end of World War II has not, in fact, resulted in more effective performance on the battlefield.

In part, as Bruni suggests, this is because in today's world, giga-hardwear such as aircraft carriers are not particularly effective against the kind of insurgent, asymmetric techniques upon which, for example, non-state actors rely.

This isn't to say the United States could put away all its big toys; the possibility of more conventional war still exists—though it's hard to imagine how an actual war between the U.S. and, say, China, would play out. Dueling bombing campaigns? Drone warfare? Anti-ship warfare? Where, if anywhere, would anyone expect actual troops to engage?

But strangely, most Americans seem comfortable with the fact that their government spends as much on "defense" as the next seven nations combined—four of which, at minimum, are supposed to be allies.

This is an email I recently sent to my two conservitive Senators an Congresman on this subject.

Spending another $54 billion on defense is totally insane. Our military is not depleted. We spend more than the next seven countries combined with all but two being our allies. Examining just our Navy, that I know a little more about than the other services, we have 10 aircraft carriers compared to on 8 by all other countries 6 of which are owned by our allies. Quality wise we probably hold at least a ten to one advantage to the Russian and Chinese two carriers. We have 18 ballistic missile submarines and our allies have 9 compared to 18 by the Russians and Chinese. Quality wise ours our far superior. We have the largest amphibious fleet of ships of any country. The Russians and Chinese have virtually none. The last time we invaded another country with our amphibious Navy was 62 years ago at Inchon. Why do we keep spending the billions of dollars for a military component that we never use? Trump says we have far fewer navy ships that in the 80s. True but the current ships capabilities are far superior to those in the 80’s. We need to spend less not more on the Military.

"Guns and butter", what a novel idea. Hearing the pablum spouted by Trump, about spending billions of dollars on an already bloated military budget and promising to "cut waste" as a way of balancing the budget, is an antique political promise that is as empty as his promise of bipartisan compromise.

As disturbing, was seeing the flock of Republican sheep bouncing up and down in their seats, their vest-pocket principles of economic austerity now tucked away given that Trump has opened the spending tap. Where is the famous Republican pencil sharpening that looked at every Obama budget under a magnifying glass?

Finally, and most disturbing was Trump's flagrant exploitation of a widow's grief for an extended applause line, adding that her dead soldier husband "would be happy that he broke a record", apparently referring to the length of the mandatory standing ovation.

I watched in horror, our current Commander-in-Chief, using Carryn Owens, wife of Navy Seal William Owens, killed during a recent, planned raid on an al-Qaeda camp in Yemen. This woman is still grieving the loss of her husband and didn't seem ready to be exposed to such a large, albeit adoring, political crowd.
I listened to and watched news commentators describing this episode as "honoring" the deceased warrior. As I watched, Mrs. Owens was continuously crying, with tears flowing down her cheeks. Sometimes she looked upwards, with thoughts and words I could only guess. She seemed in no shape to share her sorrow with anyone that surrounded her, clapping respectfully.
I must disclose I am a retired VA Psychiatrist, stopping work after 45 years of service, 31 of those years exclusively with combat veterans with PTSD. Over 50 of my Veteran patients passed away over the years mostly from various forms of cancer, cardiac and respiratory diseases, alcohol and drug use complications, auto and motorcycle accidents and others.
I know how death of a buddy affected the combatants and how the veterans' deaths affected the families. I attended just about all the wakes. Not an easy thing to do. Families are devastated by the loss of a loved one. Death of a husband or wife in prime of life is unthinkable to the surviving spouse.
After listening to the President's commentary, the skeptical me can't get over the thought that he showed no empathy or compassion for this grieving young widow.

As expected, Trump avoided mentioning Russia and V. Putin. Amazingly, he did not to insult the media. By these standards, this speech can be considered his best speech ever.

Trump wants respect. The only way that he gain my respect is for him to show some sign that he seeks the truth.

One way for him to show that he is interested in the truth is get to the bottom of the Flynn debacle and Russia's hatching of our computer systems.

Trump and his Republican congress can clear the air is by appointing an independent special prosecutor to thoroughly investigate Flynn's activities and Russian meddling into our election process.

U.S. military buildup post WW2 and continuing in 2017?

Not just the U.S. but the Western world appears now to have sacrificed much of its noble value (free speech, artistic accomplishment, democracy--all we mean by higher culture generally) in attempting to spread its values worldwide. This of course is not to say the West did not have much to spread, but in extending itself it has clearly fallen to a raw economic argument supported by vast military/bureaucratic/corporate apparatus. We are at the level of crude behavioral psychology, pure commercialization supported by force--just pack the millions upon millions and counting into homes with enough goods to keep them quiet.

Sure, political parties in the West have their high values they talk about (religion or helping the environment--this or that cause, feel free to make your own list) but in actuality modern communications and compulsion and necessity to organize the world according to best lights has led to sinking ever further to lowest common denominator; we are not far at all from just viewing human beings as animals and raw consumers.

We can expect more military buildup--everything that can be described as systems of control, whether that means administration or surveillance or law or police or just "civil conversation". Doubtful any political party can modify this course very much. Just millions upon millions of people needing to eat, to work, to be managed. Benevolent system of animal selfishness?

Massive arms buildups are usually taken as prelude to war. It's totally implausible that the call for such a huge increase in military spending is all due to Trump's sick ego. It's more plausible that the "military-industrial complex" plays a major role. And it's even more plausible that the military brass, who are now in major cabinet positions, are concretely and secretly planning a war. Presumably with China.

That would be a thermonuclear war, and that would be an absolute catastrophe for life on this planet.

Military spending is good, by definition, because it something we can allow from a Federal Government, that those re-fighting the Civil War don't feel belongs to the states. That it also pumps up the bellicosity, pride and ego that is usually channeled into cheering for a favorite team and disparaging the rival is beside the point.

Social spending - on health, on education, on security, on research, on pollution control, is bad, by definition, because it is something states should manage and someone should be able to get rich on.

Redistribution is bad if it is based on taxation, and good if it is based on sweetheart laws that accrue wealth to a few.

Trump's desire to build fighters is ego which falls into line with the far right's philosophy. In this Trump isn't Bannon's puppet; he is Bannon's enabler.

Every time I hear a politician bark about bigger military investment and isolationist policies, my mind wanders to my memories of seeing remnants of the Siegfried Line, the preserved trenches of the Somme, the ossuary at Verdun, the German fortifications at Normandy, Dachau, the walled cities of the dark ages, and the lost villages of France. Defense against evil is necessary, all else is folly. There are plenty of memorials to this folly around the globe. We don't need to add more.
History tells us that those walled cities came at the expense of generations whose labors and funds were dedicated to building a protection that left them vulnerable to new weapons, different tactics, and poor. As can be said about so many things, hindsight is 20/20. It gives great value to foresight.

Let's hope, Mr Bruni, that someone in our flailing government has the courage and wisdom to provide some foresight before we all become beggars at the gates.

Trump is trying to buy in support for a military dictatorship like any dictator whether he is in North Korea or Russia. He dodged Vietnam due to bone spurs. He criticized American prisoners of war. He avoided paying his promised donation to vets. He attacked a Gold Star family.

As president, one of his first actions was to approve a reckless raid over dinner. No briefing. No consideration of pros and cons, costs and consequences. Just as dinner time posturing. Was it before or after dessert? Did he pose for the cameras?

Almost 30 civilians died, 9 of them children. A Seal died. Others were seriously wounded. No backup aircraft meant a costly delay. An expensive aircraft was lost. And the end result was not the death of the target or acquisition of good intel. Just posturing, blaming and evading responsibility for a bad decision.

Where is the new Benghazi investigation now?

Typical Trump. Con man, braggert, no risks for himself and then lies and threats to silence others. Throwing money at the military while destroying the country's environment, science, technology, arts, civil rights, and healthcare.

I will not stand idlely by and watch as Trump and Republicans take our nation to war status, reprioritizing all national efforts towards winning a war with enemies Trump alone sees.  Nor will I accept Trump's idiotic statements about getting other countries to pay us for bringing our already disproportionate military might to bear on their problems.  Other countries have health care and infrastructure spending and better support for the elderly than we do.  We have a dangerous egotistic billionaire playing the role of Gorbachov to Putin's Reagan, as Putin attempts to taunt Trump into spending on the military until our nation's economy collapses.  If citizens let this happen, watch out, because Trump will try to turn this military against us here at home, to keep us "safe" from the dangerous immigrants he sees behind every woodshed. To the barricades!

Saddam Insane and his massive tank army was fighting WWII when he lost the Gulf War to very advanced American military machine.

Trump is making America great again by chanting mantras from the past. Prepare for war? We are at war! We fight with ourselves; in the press, in courtrooms, behind backs, in local legislatures, in the markets, and in the streets.

Corporations relocate to other nations to avoid taxes. We threaten to relocate,when we retire to better places to live outside the country, while others will do anything they can to get in. Just like what previous generations of new Americans did to native Americans, these new immigrants have no qualms about hurting those already here. Globalized companies take advantage of this. The CEOs benefit most.

Trump is the ugly face of the America we have become. I was an engineer and had worked in defense electronics up to that Gulf War. I was proud of my accomplishments for the America we were. Then I switched to semiconductors for commercial markets when the war and money wound down. Our advancements in commercial electronics continued to serve this country well.

Alt facts or another missile are not going to make this place safer or better!

If President Trump's muddled recollections of late-night movies shapes his sense of military strategy we face some complicated years ahead. "They" did not lose Ryan, they saved him, but at the cost of Tom Hanks and several other soldiers. Whatever the inspirational value of "Saving Private Ryan" I do not see it as providing a rationale for spending $54 billion on hardware largely useless against foes such as ISIS. Great for boosting stock prices but not digging irregular fighters out of tunnels beneath cities in the Middle East. Perhaps a tour in Vietnam would have increased his understanding of the limits of massive firepower against the kinds of adversaries we are too likely to encounter today. Instead President Trump wishes to preen in front of grand parades of personnel and weaponry just like those filling Red Square. He seems willing to crush our capacity to deploy diplomacy and influence to buy some boats or drones that increase our capacity to wipe out wedding parties and family celebrations. Congressional Republicans have already demonstrated their capacity to defund Embassy security, making our diplomats more vulnerable to attack. Now he will end diplomacy itself, perhaps sending more generals to negotiate with Russian operatives regarding his private interests. Will cutting foreign aid mean reneging on recent commitments to Israel?  What will happen when ISIS or Al Qaeda begin to attack Trump properties abroad.....Seal Team Six or nuclear weapons?

The military voted for Trump so he will reward them, just as he will lower taxes on his wealthy supporters while continuing to tax the educated middle class that opposed him. If you're not in the Trump supporter class you'd better watch your wallet, because the biggest con artist on the planet is gunning for you.
I found reading that, like so many of Bruni's columns, 'emotionally satisfying."
A man with short fingers needs big guns to feel good about himself.

The president could close one loophole with one swipe of the literal and figurative pen: immediately revoke the right of military service academy graduates to be directly drafted into professional sports leagues, thereby avoiding active duty entirely.

What's this, you say? But these are individuals trained (on taxpayer funds) to be highly-skilled military officers! And paid a monthly salary during college (and the requisite graduate school), even! Why are we, a nation at war on multiple fronts, paying tuition for military officers to turn around and become multi-millionaire athletes instead?

(As an aside - you *did* know that academy athletes don't refuse pay when they play their games, right? How these athletes can be paid but other NCAA athletes remain uncompensated will have to be a head-scratcher for another deliberative body.)

In May of last year, an update to the Department of Defense Pro Sports Policy changed things to make way for profit. Originally, a graduate had to serve at least 24 months of active duty before going to a Reserve unit...unless, that is, the player's skill was such that it presented great PR and recruitment possibilities for the military if they turned pro. Compare that to the GI Bill.

Now? “A service member can request to be tendered an appointment in the reserve upon graduation and satisfy their commissioned service obligation in the Ready Reserve.”

What nation - much less one at war - pays for a half decade of football camp in its budget?

The alarmist view, or as I like to call it, reality, is that it's all part of the playbook. Dress the clown up as a soldier and watch the masses salute him.

Of course he's worrisome now, but when he puts on a uniform, as most of them do at some point, that's when we should start to worry with vigor and imagination.

A fine well-written piece by Frank Bruni, as usual. Rumsfeld famously said that the US was running out of targets in Afghanistan. While still bogged down there in an unwinnable asymetrical war, the US under Tump will also run out of places to destroy. The only winners will be the military-industrial complex but Americans will feel the hurt of all this money not invested in schools, roads, trains and protecting the environment. Trump keeps repeating "America first" but it looks as if he meant "I will destroy America first".

"I suspect that it’s emotionally satisfying." That makes sense, to you at least.'m certain that emotions are very much part of your own reaction to the president and what you characterize as his "strongman's way." The speech offered as much substance as most, which is to say not much at all. What is clear is that the 45th president can begin his speech with a salute to Black History month, denounce hate crimes, and then explicitly promise good jobs and safe schools to Hispanics and African-Americans and still end up getting ripped by this columnist. Equally clear is that most Americans, a sizeable majority, welcomed the speech, its tone, and its content. One can question the sincerity of the words, and the ability to deliver. But using this column to deny the obvious, that the speech was a good speech and appealed to America's better angels does little to win readers over. Those hostile to the new president continue to make the same mistakes made during the election. Democrats can have few complaints with policies that prioritize American workers and American jobs, especially for lower-income and middle-class voters. Had this columnist and his peers at the NYT actually explored the problems facing ordinary Americans a different person would be in the White House today. What we heard was a president who gave voice to those forgotten and dismissed by the NYT editorial board during the campaign and in this speech. This column? More of the same.

"...billions and trillions," "very, very beautiful, " tens of millions," " billions and billions," "tens of thousands," "big,big," "millions and millions," "countless,"so many more," " very, very happy, " the money is pouring in."

Typical Trump snake oil speech -full of hyperbole and "signifying nothing."

Trump or rather Bannon see ramping up military spending as a win-win strategy in that it makes Trump appear "strong' in the eyes of his voter base while awarding Republican party benefactors. Number two on the Republican party checklist right behind massive tax cuts to the wealthy.

Pointing out how much the US spends on defense compared to the next seven nations ignores the level of responsibility the US has compared to those nations.

No other country in the world holds the peace in more than a single theater (though usually complementing the US presence), while the US of A must be able to respond to war in Eastern Europe (from the Baltic to the Black seas), the Persian Gulf, the Korean Peninsula, and the South China Sea (just to name the hottest spots)-- Simultaneously. Outside of India-Pakistan there is not a single contentious area where the US military is not expected to hold up the post-war world order.

Or maybe we should go back to the era of imperial powers divvying up the globe? A world of "deals"?

The initial reaction to Trump appointing so many generals to high office was disconcerting. Oddly enough it now seems that, with the deep-sixing of Flynn, the military brass are the most rational and stable elements around the president.

The optics of any head of state surrounded by too many be-medalled warriors have historically had a disturbing banana-republic connotation. With Bannon, Miller, Sessions et al in charge of the banana grove, it's ironic to see men in uniform as possibly the only thing standing between the planet and a Trump induced armageddon. Mattis' even-hand and McMasters blend of actual combat experience and academic gravitas give us some comfort.

Trump can go back to imaging what has he sacrificed for the country, and hopefully be convinced that the extra 54 billion can be best used elsewhere, like regaining the moral high-ground through both national and international aid programs.

The only body part Trump has regularly flexed is not actually a muscle. Let's hope he keeps it that way.

Military-Security Apparatus, that’s the game in town as the likelihood of an Economic comeback has few other supports supportable by those with power. Pres. Trump is not complex but he is bright enough to know how the game is played and has been for a long time as did his recent predecessors. These are the safe choices that resist opposition from either party. The rest of America’s needs can ‘make do.’ So now all that are needed are a list of enemies; another easy one of those with a supporting media. Did you expect a Change to finally arrive?

I know a lot of people around the U.S. and unfortunately the world, watched this cartoon character with his swishy new hair blab on an on.

I just did have the stomach for it, so I'm grateful so many really good journalists can briefly outline the whole joke of the SOTH message from this joke of a preening man pretending to be POTUS. SAD!

The ultimate goal seems to be to destroy our government's strength to do anything socially, economically, or environmentally thereby turning this country into a corporation controlled, billionaire dominated, autocracy. Basically, it's a Reaganesque vision that government is the problem. The question is, will we be able to fix it after it is broken? If his track record in business is any forecast, he will surely break it. Will the voting public ever figure it out and respond accordingly? That remains to be seen. I have my doubts.

Trump's primary reason for the military spending spree probably has more to do with the fact that Arizona, a state that has an economy heavily dependent on military contracts, also has a senator named McCain who is currently rather unhappy with the White House's connection to Putin and Russia.

This is, at its root, a payoff to McCain in an attempt to keep him quiet about any potential Congressional investigations. Anything beyond that is just a bonus as far as Trump goes.

Mrs Merkel has already said at the Munich Conference that Germany would stick to its plan to raise defence spending by 2024. Let's look into this matter again when Mr Trump is a lame duck. No need to hurry with the testosterone policy. Remember our AH whose main priority since 1933 was a strong military. In school I learned that there was no other explanation for our build-up of the military than Hitler's goal, to start war and "make Germany great again". To hint at parallels to our GröFaZ may be overblown, but this speech (obviously not one written by Trump himself) does not convince me that Germany should increase its military spending from 1.2% of GDP to 2%. Such an ammount of Euro 25 billion annually can be better spent on strengthening the EU. Let's use it to end the Greek crisis, create jobs for young people in Spain or finance free rail tickets for the young valid for the whole EU-28 area. Show the Brexiters what they are going to give up.

We need a top to bottom overhaul of the Defense Department starting with a line item audit and budget. The DoD cannot or will not tell what it spends and bringing it under control cannot start without proper accounting.

There is much duplication of effort. The Marines seem determined to be a parallel Army instead of their original role of Naval Infantry. Each branch has aviation despite our US Air Force being established out of the old Army Air Corps to handle that role. Tell me exactly why the Frogmen of the Navy have morphed into soldiers under the SEAL name? Would the Navy not object if the Army fielded submarines?

Exactly why is it that US AFRICOM- the US Unified Command over forces on the African Continent is ensconced in Stuttgart, Germany rather than on the African Continent? Kelley Barracks was supposed to be a temporary home while a more suitable location could be found-that was a decade ago. The same for US Army AFRICA- headquartered in Vicenza, Italy.

The late Chalmers Johnson warned us that our current course was an invitation to ruination of either our finances or our Democracy and that was before the advent of Candidate Trump. Congress and the White House would be well advised to consider his work and that point.

This was a waste of space + print. While there's plenty of pretty language, there's not semblance of connectivity in this column of his proposals to a position regarding the National Security, global economic inter-dependency and concomitant reliance upon resources for which wars are fought, that the President clearly understands and develops policy in support of the same.

The tawdry allegories to body parts was simply pathetic and serves as nothing than pablum for the masses

"The Donald" is a chicken-hawk. He did not care enough about his country to go fight in Vietnam and predictably he is now in charge of the whole shooting match. He is a huge chicken-hawk, the most tremendous chicken-hawk. Much to our nation's detriment.

We won the Cold War by out-spending the Soviet Union. Bankrupting Russia sounded like a good idea at the time but the end result was Russia becoming a criminal oligarchy with strongman Vladimir Putin in charge.

That same strategy will not work with China. China may not be able to keep up with us at first but sooner or later this strategy will end up bankrupting the US.

Every time I hear about so-called President Trump cowardly avoiding serving in the military it makes me ultra mad.

My older brother, a poor Chicano raised in the barrio, went to Vietnam. He crawled through tunnels fighting the Vietcong and was never the same when he came back, Ultimately he committed suicide due to PTSD in January 2015.

I get mad when I think of Donald Trump's cowardice because my brother, my father and I are all of Mexican ancestry and we all proudly served our nation.

I knew things would get bad but I thought it would take months for things to get this bad. And the sad part is that it is only going to get worse and worse.

I want to escape the hell-hole known as Texas by moving to California but at this rate I may just bail on the US.

Canada has jobs, excellent healthcare and a civilized society. Sure sounds like Heaven to me!

"Trump’s address was an opportunity to change the narrative of his presidency from one of an administration in disarray to one of a man on a methodical mission."

That is wrong, Mr. Bruni. Donald Trump does not change and will not change. Let us not be led to anticipate further such "opportunities."

I wish Trump or one of his mouthpieces would explain specifically how a massive increase in military spending on new weapons and who knows what all will help to make the Taliban leave the Afghans alone, help to make ISIS go away, convince Al-Qaeda to forget about blowing people up, etc. And does he think all that big spending is going to intimidate the Russians, the North Koreans, the Chinese, or the Iranians? Just a colossal waste of resources needed elsewhere to actually benefit the common good of the nation.

As the great and sorely missed Gore Vidal used to say, we should send them enough to paint the White House and that is it.

Billions, if not trillions will be squandered in the service of this con-man's ego. Historians will look back on all this in disbelief.

Trump cannot deliver a coherent argument for the increase of military spending, other than what Mr. Bruni said that the military is his biceps.  Trump still remains on the juvenile level of "my biceps are bigger than yours."  His reason for placating Russia and Putin is that nuclear war is bad, Duh!  All boils down is one simple question: Mr. Trump, with your promise of massive tax cut and infrastructure spending,  where does the money come from?

Trump can't separate game show rhetoric from reality; he's always unthinkingly selling us his pathetic products only now in forms that will cost us billions.

For one, America has nearly 12 aircraft carriers, the rest of the world combined has 8. Let's just hope all of America's new war toys don't end up running into each other on the open ocean or in the skies above it. America needs less money on weapons and more on infrastructure, we clearly cannot afford Trump's pathetic policy page ripped out from Reagan's playbook.

Somebody might want to tip off Trump that supporting Assad is precisely what both Iran and Putin want.

Trump's grandiosity knows no limits. He has to see himself as the best, most wonderful at everything; what he has surely must be the best, the biggest, the most wonderful. What he does, same thing - grandest ever. I'm sure he already sees himself as the greatest president this country has ever had (or will ever have).  No, he has no plans, only braggadocio and bravado. He thinks that that is all he needs for his wonderful-ness has gotten him so far.

As a child of the 1940’s, I see Hitler in everything Trump does. Hitler declared himself protector of the "Volk." During the campaign, Trump vowed, "Only I can solve your problems."

Hitler denounced Jews, socialists, communists, the press, as "enemies of the Volk." Trump recently denounced the press as "enemies of the people."

Hitler deported Jews to death camps. Trump wants to deport immigrants, some to literal deaths in their home countries; others to figurative deaths, living with the knowledge that they may never see their children again.

Now, Trump wants a spike in defense spending. For what purpose? To invade little Sweden? He doesn’t need a spike for that. To fight Russia, for which he has had nothing but good to say? Hardly. Who then? Why, of course, it must be China, which he has vilified at every opportunity.

Now the love affair with Russia becomes clear. Trump wants Russia to join him in a war against China, or at least remain neutral. Here again, the Hitler comparison is apt. Hitler sought enemies abroad as well as at home, and waged war against entire continents—Europe, America and Russia.

And that was before the atom bomb. "What’s the point of having nuclear weapons if we don’t use them?" Trump reportedly asked the Joint Chiefs during a briefing.

I understand Times's columnists get paid to write columns.

What I do not understand is why said columnists have to waste their time trying to comprehend the lunatic ravings of a man so out of his depth he may as well be the cliche of the drunk uncle at Thanksgiving dinner torturing his fellow dinner guests with tail of the good old days.

Find other topics to opine on, and leave Trump to The Onion and Psychology Today writers.

Frank, that sense of ' strongman ' you think you get from DJT is really just plain ol' carnival barker snake oil/smoke and mirrors that proposes no way at all to pay for the puppy dogs & rainbows world he imagines - it's the same shtick that he's perfected from a lifetime of carnival barkery in his professional life.

Don't forget that he would have been bankrupt if he didn't owe so much money to the bankers that they couldn't let him go broke, so they took over his financial affairs and put him on a monthly allowance, then he had multiple times where he took his casino companies (other people's money) into bankruptcy, then he was saved by discovering he could take $900+ million$ in tax losses, so that no one knows if he's actuallly paid any income tax in the past 20 years.

And now, the U.S. taxpayers have taken over the exorbitant expense of his family's traveling and personal security.

There's a trend of grifting here, and of unrealistic financial projections from someone who's gotten in financial trouble in his own private business when no one could veto his budgeting.

There's no reason to believe the guy has suddenly learned financial restraint just because he's entered his 8th decade of life.

Be afraid.
No need to put Paul Ryan under wraps: deficits only matter when Barrack Obama is President.

In his address to the Congress, President Trump seems to have changed the way he said things, but he said the same things he has been saying for a very long time, with no clear policies/paths to accomplish them. He sounded a bit more nuanced as he laid out his promises - desperately sticking to a serious note in his delivery. He condemned the attacks on Jewish centers and the hate crime in Kansas. But it was too little, too late. For a man, who tweets at 3 AM attacking Nordstrom for dropping his daughter's products, it must not have taken more than a week and a lot of criticism later, to condemn acts of violence and hate. Therefore, it seems to me as if this speech -a serious attempt at an image makeover for the President - is yet another tactic the Trump administration is using to divert attention from issues of national and international importance. Don't fall for it.

If I were a betting man in one of the now defunct trump casinos I will bet his new military funding will go to invent a secret weapon that will grow, not one, but two, one on each foot, bone spurs on every present and future ISIS fighters so the bone spurs will be so "debilitating" that those ISIS fighter cannot walk or run, let alone shoot. Easy. Raise taxes. It is mind boggling that our elected officials suck up to Grover Norquist and the NRA.

Finally, to keep America safe, we must provide the men and women of the United States military with the tools they need to prevent war — if they must — they have to fight and they only have to win.
This quote from tonight doesn't even begin to make sense. So Trump. Prevent war -if they must- they have to fight and they only have to win? That is the main line that has stuck with me after watching another hooey fest by Trump. I just can't get my head around the idea that all they have to do is win.
