What would Trump know about the Military, besides knowing how to avoid serving in it? There has been a lot of commentary about how disunited the Country has become. One of the reasons is Nixon's ending the draft, because of the controversy resulting from the conflict in Vietnam. For my generation (high school graduate, 1954), nearly all males who could pass a physical would be called up for Military service. The valuable side effect was that we got to experience life and people far from our home region. I enjoyed the service and stayed in for 22 years. I had 12 Permanent Changes of Station (PCS) during that period in the Air Force. Here is where I was stationed, listing the nearest metropolitan area. I was born and raised in Niagara Falls and entered the service with an ROTC commission from SUNYB, as it is now called. My 12 assignments were NYC, Atlanta, Pensacola, Boston, DC, Saigon, Omaha, St. Louis, Montgomery AL, DC, St. Louis, Seattle. I was a weather officer. My early assignments to the South were when it was segregated. In addition, I had numerous TDYs (short business trips) to the Southwest, and to Europe. I think I have seen it all. I know a lot of old vets and we are in agreement that the Military draft should be re-instated. A great way to get to know our large and varied country, but even more so, when we go to war, we should go as a country, rather than a small group of careerists.

I wish I could do it again.

This speech to Congress reminded me of the scene in the Godfather, where Michael is asked by the priest...do you you renounce Satan?  Michael:  Yes, I renounce Satan.  As we see this exchange played over repeatedly, it is interspersed with absolute carnage (murder) on all of the Godfathers  adversaries.

We've seen this show before. Reagan had his "peace through strength" mantra. He increased military spending by 35% and bragged about deficits not mattering.

We've been at war for two decades, enough already. Yes NATO needs to pay their fair share but we don't need to keep throwing money at the military. Especially if we're winding down our military engagement abroad.

Trump has no concept of the sacrifices that our troops make. During Vietnam he was a legal draft dodger. He is clueless about serving his country.

Tonight was a prime example of how little he understands about the sacrifices of not just our troops but their families also. He exploited the grieving widow of the troop who was killed in the bungled mission in Yemen. Her husband deserved to be honored but she deserved better than being used as a prop on television.

Trump reminds me of the school yard bully who has to have the bigger stick. Guess what, you're the President and it's time to grow up.

Seeing Donald Trump giving a State of the Union type speech with the Speaker and Vice President behind him was surreal. How did we get here? I am still waiting for someone to step in and tell us we opened the wrong envelope. Is there a worse choice out there? I am having trouble coming up with a name.

Frank,

Your "Opinion" begins from, Your Boss doesn't like Trump, a large majority of your reader base doesn't like Trump and you don't like Trump. Moving on, none of you want him as President and all of you feel his supporters are "not of the right class"!

Your lack of knowledge on the true state of our military as demonstrated by your opinion here is truly impressive. Beginning with the navy surface fleet. A majority of the Aegis Destroyers and Crusers are equipped with the very old Spy-1 or Spy-3 radar systems. There is a new highly capable Spy-6 radar which is available today, but is not scheduled to be fully deployed until 2030. The difference is a three fold improvement between the two systems.

Almost every foreign warship in these two classes entering service over the next 12 years will field a superior radar system to those in our existing ships. Do you think this might have something to do with budgetary limits? This is just one of many systems that are below the current level of technology in our fleet.

Each of these ships is crewed by hundreds of young Americans who our government (you and I) places in harm's way in ships that are not the best that they can or should be.

But because you don't like him, it's all about Trump not the thousands of Americans going to sea, risking their lives in substandard equipment to defend our country. If yours is the "correct" view, I'm glad to be a Deplorable!

The Trump administration never says why this 54 billion dollar military spending increase is needed exactly other than to say our military is "depleted". How so exactly?

As Mr. Bruni says we spend more than the next 7 nations combined. Is that still somehow not enough? We have a significant nuclear stockpile that is more modern and more than a match for Russia's. The US has 10 aircraft carriers. No other nation has more than 1 active. We have bombers that can strike anywhere on the globe, fighters that do 100's of sorties and don't get shot down, and well-trained and well equipped ground forces.

And for what threat is this additional money needed? No other nation's leader who is sane would challenge the US in a conventional war with the possible exception of North Korea's out of desperate and temporary attempt to hold power. Can we really not handle North Korea with the conventional forces we have.

We could spend money differently to handle threats such as ISIS but this does not involve extremely expensive weapon system purchases nor large fielding of boots on the ground. It instead involves what President Obama has already been doing which is to place special forces and special ops to assist local forces. That's smart not expensive.

I'm all for ending the military sequestration that only became a necessary concession to the Tea Party wing of the Republican Party. But Trump's increase is another vane gesture to appear the tough guy on the block.

Anyone who follows military trends, technology, and policy, like I have over the last 35+ years knows that we need signficant increases in military spending like we need a cholera outbreak. We outspend the rest of the world militarily in truly shocking ways. How many nations do we want to be bigger than combined - the next top five, six, eight...?

What's the purpose of all this spending - really? In a world where we get less Return On Investment than we ever have, for being the "World's Policeman," we should have long since learned that we simply can't/shouldn't interfere in the affairs of other nations... and when we do, we usually make it worse for them AND us.

Trump wants what? To withdraw, to spend less on other nations, to involve ourselves in other places - or not? If the military is for Our Self Defense only, we have far more than enough. Is he serious about reversing 45-50 years of nuclear arms reductions? If so, why? That's abject Insanity!

Upon serious reflection, the only reason I can see for significantly more military spending is... because Obama didn't do it. In a time when we have truly critical domestic spending needs on Infrastructure, we need a heck of a lot better reason than that. We just can't afford it, and we just don't need it!

For a country that has a military budget greater than the next six countries combined, it seems that putting billions into the military is more important than policies that combat the fact that millions of citizens are unable to fill their prescription because of the price.

I could maybe learn to tolerate Trump's shallowness and contradictions if there were some sign that his superficiality and mutually exclusive goals--and means for achieving them--were purely rhetorical while he reserved active, probing listening, deep understanding, and rational planning to his private high-level consultations with experts and leaders, domestic and foreign. As it is, he shows absolutely no sign that there is a "there there". From what I can see, his rhetoric is as deep as he goes. I believe is a fatal flaw for him, and possibly for us as a nation, because it leaves him simultaneously open to the manipulations of Bannon and Miller, while alienating a large part of Congress and most of the American public, with the result that little will get done that is coherent and positive. If Bannon truly wants to burn down the "administrative state" it appears that, in President Trump, he has found not the perfect ally so much as the perfect tool.

I voluntarily served with pride and am now disabled vet.  Let's get our current vets taken care of(medical/psych/homeless/under-or-unemployed/at or near poverty, etc) before putting even more in harm's way-- since we still have backlogs of claims for wars long over, still unknown fallout of effects from many wars/war environments and its still unknown how to adequately fix the current VA.  Human lives cannot be purchased for any amount of $-- ensure budget for HUMANS before equipment!

I wonder if, after Trump's term ends, pundits for the Times will need to consult a psychologist. Four years of analyzing this man's utterances as if they reflected a coherent world view, indeed, as if they expressed any kind of comprehensible thought, might easily trigger a nervous breakdown. Tonight's speech, of course, did not require an interpreter because he simply parroted the words of Steve Bannon.

Aside from a superficial coherence, the speech was notable for Trump's cynical exploitation of the wife of the Navy Seal killed on the raid into Yemen. The president, in effect, used her as a prop to sell his version of the raid and to pressure Congress to increase military spending. Even for Trump, this tactic marked a new low in his sensitivity to the suffering of others.

Well, it's still early days, and I feel sure we have yet to plumb the depths of Trump's amorality. I just hope the pundits for the Times have good health insurance.

When Trump's physician told him that his BMI (height-to-weight ratio) classed him as "obese", he simply increased his height.

There's an analogy here in this (needless) military expansion: his insecurities are so patently obvious, but then those failings apply equally -so it seems- to his Cabinet and to the Congress.

Would that someone, anyone in government might "grow a pair" and stand up to oppose his lunacy.

I was appalled that he used William Owens distraught widow Carryn to gain a few political points. He is the president who could not be bothered to monitor the raid unlike Obama during the raid on Bin Laden. Nor did he insist on a backup helicopter like Obama which saved the mission.
This speech was an attempt to save his dysfunctional presidency. I am not buying a word of it.

"If we were winding down, why were we building up? If caution was the order of the day, why did it require such lavish investment?"

Yes, how is spending more for less an example of a lean and efficient government? It doesn't take much imagination to conclude that the goal is not a lean and efficient government or even a secure USA. If those by-products happen to result, fine, but basically they are just talking points. Efficient government and perhaps even the security of our nation (think Russia) will be sacrificed, if push comes to shove, to further the accumulation of wealth by the people who own stock in the military-industrial complex, which are not the people who have lost their manufacturing jobs that the president promises to recreate out of nothing. We shall see if his rich peers in business and Congress are moved more by his rhetoric than their balance sheets (including the one upon which the federal budget deficit is written) and create jobs out of thin air and security out of exotic aircraft while maintaining all the entitlements he promises to preserve. We shall see if spending more and cutting revenue results, with the wave of a magical Don Wand, in a balanced federal budget and whether the powerful in industry are willing to sacrifice some profits for the good of the country, without being forced to. Let me know if any of the president's fantasies come true.

54 billions dollars more! To what end? Even spending a trillion dollars more  won't buy us the absolute safety and security that we seek. As it is, we can pretty much destroy the world if we want to and be destroyed in the process. And while we become the hyperpower of Trump's fervid imagination, we will poison our streams and make our air unbreathable. What mad pursuit is this?

Following 9/11, the United States has not suffered any major attack from a foreign nation or from immigrant criminal terrorist violence -- not here at home. Immigration policies of recent administrations seem to have succeeded in deterring terrorists, and the Obama policies prior to Mr. Trump's ascendency will be tough for Mr. Trump's vague "extreme vetting" to improve upon.
One might wonder how much money saved, how many American and other lives would have been saved, how many injuries prevented, how many cities, towns, historic sites would not have been destroyed had the United States and its allies found ways to avoid engaging in military operations over the intervening years. I thought of these things during the long and heartfelt ovation directed at the wife of a Navy Seal who was killed in a questionable raid. At what point dare we ask, "Was it really worth it?" When should a person or a nation stop deliberately bashing headfirst into the wall?
Doug Giebel
Big Sandy, Montana

Take a grieving widow, thrust her in the spotlight, extol the life her husband gave for his country, all the while denying any bit of blame for getting him killed. By now, "his generals" must be smart enough to see how this is going to play out over time.

Not his fault Ryan Owen was killed, six more soldiers injured, a helicopter lost and dozens civilians killed, when he couldn't even be bothered to be in the situation room when the mission he approved went down.

One senses that this planning to throw huge amounts of money to the military is an attempt to make himself a big man in "his generals" eyes.

Another trump on the stump speech with lots of promises but no details. Wonder who really wrote it?

Great column, Frank,.finally someone points out the BS about Trump's war memories....what a psychotic 10 year old's fantasy....and by the way Trump,..define "win"...with our military we can "win" every war, it's the peace,.(remember the Marshall Plan Don?) .. that creates a meaningful outcome. We've been in Korea and Japan how long? No Trump is just another classic chickenhawk, trotting out the widow of another soldier killed for nothing, simply to bask in the company of his bravery and service and get the photo op. Not trying to be callous here , but were any of the thousands of young Americans in the cemetery's of France and Italy so honored or remembered. One's sense of proportion reels at the cynical agit prop offered up shamelessly by Trump and his minions at tonights speech where an olive branch was held out by the man who denied for 8 years the legitamacy of our first African American president. We must never forget or forgive this singular act of cowardice, deception, and treason. And when he speaks of winning at wars again, remember,  you have to be in one to win one.

If you ask Trump supporters when America Was Great (to understand what it means to make it Great Again), they all say the same thing immediately: WWII. And the booming postwar decade that followed. America came in at the 11th hour and saved the world from evil, and American identity has been shaped by this victory ever since.

Nothing can rival the enormous positive boost to national identity of WWII. The full blown wars that followed were complicated, messy, and, for the most part, failures. When Trump talks about winning wars again, he is talking about WWII and that greatest generation. Trump grew up in that postwar decade of opportunity and triumph. That was his childhood. That is what he and his supporters mean when they talk about making America great again.

Problem is, the US has matured and deepened in ways that make going back to a pre- civil rights era, pre-women's movement, pre-LGBTQ movement, pre- non-European immigration, pre- most social and cultural developments that have enriched our country beyond measure, impossible. We cannot return to the Halcyon days of white men's childhoods (or their memories instilled in their children) when life was simpler and whites had all the power. It just isn't going to happen, and it should not happen. Rather than fighting it, we'd be better off embracing our evolution towards national adulthood.

All the military spending in the world will not turn back the clock. It will only enrich corporations that feed the war machine.

Our air force is cannibalizing aircraft. Our true readiness is suffering from lack of spare parts and fully functioning weapons.

It's one thing to have a downsized military, but another to be trapped by the sequestration. We need a fully functioning military, be it larger or smaller, and we should not be cannibalizing weapons and aircraft for parts.

The tip of the cap to military contractors is expected since most employ people who know their livelihood depends on the government's continual upgrade of weapons and can be expected to fall in line behind the man who keeps them fed.

He may not need to be continually stroked, he has to know how to slip a punch and enough to keep the pot of racist stew simmering or, with all his bravado and money, he wouldn't have made the election as close as it was.

While the news here has become all Donald all the time the world still turns on its' 23.5 degree axis, most of us get up in the morning and we will survive our latest step into the as yet drained swamp.

Although on occasion accidental, for the most part progress demands a majority in the right place at the right time and is almost invariably a slow process.

I just hope there is enough left for our kids.

Trump could not have said anything that Bruni would have liked or even fairly analyzed. Trump spoke to the majority of Americans and was generous and reached out to democrats. If the democrats and liberals like Bruni ignore Trump they will do so at their peril, The American People will support the Trump that spoke tonight.
For those always looking for the negative, they will be seen as sore losers, with the emphasis on loser. Trump was optimistic and almost Reagan like. The democrats better get on board or they will be in the wilderness for a long time.
Trump became President tonight. Now we shall see if the liberals and democrats can be adults or will they stay petulant children, as Trump appeared before tonight.

This is how the military-industrial complex works. Pretend to be Ronald Reagan and take tens of billions from other agencies, safety-net programs, infrastructure, etc. and give them to the already-bloated military and super-rich defense contractors. Claim it’s all meant to be a deterrent – “peace through strength.”

Problem is: it’s no fun having all those new shiny toys without using them. So, Mr. President, you wanna look like a hero and be reelected? No better way than to start a war. So look for a country – preferably with brown people – to antagonize. Compare them to Nazi Germany. Once you’ve whipped America into a violent, jingoistic frenzy - which isn't at all hard to do - send some of our troops over there to “advise.” Then send some more. And some more after that. Sooner or later, our fancy new planes will be dropping fancy new bombs, fancy new ships will be bringing plenty of fancy new weapons and troops, fancy new boots will hit the ground, and all of those perfectly avoidable casualties – civilian and military – will start mounting.

Oh – and don’t worry about an exit strategy. Or about destabilizing the region, refugees, etc. These are not America’s problems. We need to start worrying about ourselves. America first!

Frank says, ''Social Security and Medicare are off limits...'' unless you're Barack Obama. Then if you want to cut $750 million from Medicare, we promise to never complain.
I hunt and peck for the right keys but Frank hunts for perfectly normal-sounding things over which he attacks his political enemy with. Did it bother Frank a bit to have one of our aircraft carriers tied up in Virginia waiting for a power plant replacement because the Navy was starved for funds?
userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene

commentBody: He could give 20 speeches in a row in which he strikes a new tone and comments on actual policy, but he'd still be Donal Trump. What part of this does the media not get?  It is not hyperbole; it is fact: the man is an ignorant buffoon narcissist.  Even if his aids were to prevail upon him not to tell pants-on-fire lies, insult entire groups of people, or levy an all-out attack on the 4th estate, he will still act in a way that is beyond the pale.  This is Donald Trump!  Trust your eyes, America.

Five things stood out in President Donald Trump’s State of the Unionish speech.

First, Donald Trump has greatly improved his use of a teleprompter and managed to give a speech with an almost pleasant tone.

Second, Mr. Trump continues to be unconfined by the normal strictures of truth.

Third, we should show more respect for Stephen K. Bannon. Referring to Mr. Bannon as Co-President Bannon would not be appropriate, because that title would diminish the Bannon importance.

Fourth, next to Bannon, the big winner is President Putin.

Fifth, this is going to be a long, hard slog for Democrats and for anyone else who cares about the Constitution, the rule of law and fundamental fairness.

"He used his speech to complain once again that America was paying too much of the defense bill for our allies. He said that he was finally getting them to pony up. If so, why do *we* need to pump tens of billions of additional dollars into the military, especially when we already spend more on it than the seven countries that spend the next most combined?"

Because *everyone* must spend more money on militarism; not just America, but the entire world is not spending enough on weapons with which we can kill one another. That is the logical conclusion Donald J. Trump's militaristic formulations.

Ladies and gentlemen of planet Earth, where so very many of you already live marginal lives of poverty and degradation, and which you have brought to so many social and environmental tipping points, your preeminent nation-state, America, at this juncture in humanity's history where you need to start working together as one planet, is being led by a madman, assisted by madmen, with no real vision of any future. He speaks the language of death, not life, of humanity's defeat, not its victory.

Mr. Trump's vanity continues to suck most of the oxygen out of any space he occupies.  This speech seemed to be yet another "fix" for his adulation addiction.  The exploitation of Ms Owens, wife of the fallen Navy Seal, fits right in with his self absorbtion.  Nothing presidential to see here folks!

I always enjoy the humor of Frank Bruni's essays.
Quoting Trump saying “Finally, the chorus became an earthquake.”
It's a bit of comic relief in what's turning out to be the US's Greek Tragedy.

I'd like Trump to quote Curly from the three stooges. This quip seems appropriate. "I'm trying to think, but nothing happens!"

That's a cute essay, devoid of any serious analysis of geo-political conflict zones.  McCain wants more.  China lied to our faces about the Spratlys. Kim Jong Un assassinated his half-brother.  Putin.  Iran.  Assad. And yes, ISIS.  There are plenty of legitimate reasons to significantly increase the military budget from the sequester era.  But Frank here, lounging in the NY Times faculty room, is joking about Trump's pectorals because wars are passe.  Good one.  Cute essay.

What do you expect from an insecure ignoramous and narcissist who blames his "opponents' for the shocking wave of anti-Semitism that his embrace of the alt-Right has stirred up. This person is incapable of thoughtfully considering policy options, and he views the world (including the widow of the heroic Navy SEAL who died in a futile botched operation that Trump didn't adequately review before it went forward) only as props for the advancement of his own ego. This man, a lineal descendant of Joe McCarthy through Roy Cohn and Richard Nixon, his "mentors" has no shame. And so we may ask, Sir, in the end, have you no shame, no shame at all? We all know the answer. This nightmare can't come to an end soon enough - and when the truth comes out about the Russia connections, it will!

With Trump, you can be sure that he is driven by the ego, not any logic, in his head. Trump's plans to pump up the military come not from strategy, but from the same place that impelled him to talk about the size of his inauguration crowd (and talk means lie), his election victory (including lies about voter fraud and a winning margin he did not achieve), and the size of his hands (as it were).
We could save tens of millions of dollars by investing in a good mental health counselor for Trump.

One hardly knows where to begin, with the present occupant of the oval office.

But let's look at the numbers. We spend $586Bn for defense...some 19% of the 2015 budget. That represents 13 times more than the next nation, and more than the next 7 countries combined. He wants to increase it by $56Bn..or just under 10%. Which means that we'll be spending 14 times more than the next country, and probably more than the next 9 combined. Is this really necessary?

Oh...and to pay for it...he'll attack the $462Bn we spend on all other government operations? Gut the state dept., and the EPA? They only have budgets totaling some $12Bn combined... 56Bn is 12% of the amount we're spending on all government operations. It's unlikely that congress will approve anything close to what he's asking for.

So while he's flexing his metaphorical biceps and pecs, where does he find time to assemble the platitudes that found their way into his hour long dissertation?

Bloomberg was right...it's Don the Con. Not even the GOP is going to go along with his budget proposal.

“Preening” is a two-dimensional view of Trump’s motivations. But at least Frank wasn’t SO transparent as to refer to hand-size.

Picture an America when last we were pretty united, generally and not merely narrowly prosperous, and sufficiently self-confident that we reached for the moon, space and the stars. That was a long time ago, but Trump remembers that America well. It was a time when most of us called ourselves simply “Americans” without the profusion of hyphens that the identity politics he understands so poorly imposed on us … oh, and when we had a military that nobody dared to challenge, so long as they were allowed to “win” – an obvious reference to Vietnam, which he remembers well, too.

So, he’s planning to “upsize” a military that Obama, like Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton before him, allowed to degenerate very significantly, requiring restorations that Reagan and Dubya provided. It’s not about “preening”, it’s about re-booting an America he remembers that held green memories for him and millions of Americans, not so green ones for those who were sidelined – all those hyphenates, for instance. For others who advise him, it’s more about China and Russia pushing the envelope and a radical Islamic terrorism (there, now I wrote it) existentially nipping at the West.

He’s gambling on 3%-plus economic growth largely to pay for it, and there ARE paths to that 3%. While that won’t be easy, those betting against Trump have very short memories indeed.

Go get ‘em, tiger.

Why does Trump want a big military buildup, even if the DOD doesn't and there is absolutely no justification of need for more firepower?

As usual, follow the money if you want answers. Ever hear of the "military-industrial complex?" That's about $$. In fact, that and fossil fuels are driving the current stock market bubble.

Of course Trump wants to think of himself on the review stand as endless lines of missals, tanks and soldiers pass by. And Bannon wants a war with "Islam" and China. But beyond these two egomaniacs there are those who want to get rich, or richer. Dylan's Masters of War.

I don't like watching Donald Trump
He makes my Ticker lose a thump,
The coif billowing 'bove his bean
May need a hirsute quarantine.

The dainty way two fingers meet
When verbiage is incomplete
Suggest within his past may be
A sorry stint as maitre de.

In kindergarten may the brunt
have been of every hotfoot stunt,
Wore he the dunce cap frequently
With grades rarely above a D?

If this seems too ad hominem
For one viewed as a creep pro tem,
With snide comments about his hair,
It's just that Trump I cannot bear!

Trump's right hand man, or perhaps it is the other way around, is Steve Bannon. Bannon recently made what has to be the most absurd statement of our new century, that with the 'orator' Donald Trump, that we have not seen such great oratory since Williams Jennings Bryan.

Perhaps next we will be told by the smarmy peddlers of ‘alternate truth’ that The Donald is the greatest ever humanitarian, advocate of women's rights and defender of the environment. But just saying these things does not make them true.

Perhaps somewhere, in a parallel universe, there is another Donald who went on a different path, and has all of the qualities of an honorable man, but here on planet earth, our own Donald is the epitome of tasteless bombast, braggadocio and self serving deception. And now that he is our president, his delusions of grandeur have very serious, life changing consequences, not only for our nation but for the world.

Bravo, Mr. Bruni...but you forgot one little thing: the military already owns the USA. A look at Trump's advisors and nominees tells us that.

The perceptive observer might wonder why so many general (or former generals) have positions of power in this administration. Hm-m-m.

Trump is a playground bully wearing a fancy suit. Bullies don't understand diplomacy, just force. His desire to defund the State Dept. is a dead giveaway of his intentions and worldview. Why talk about stuff when you can just smash someone and take what you want?

He claims to support the military in one breath then says it's terribly rundown in the next. How insulting to the troops! But he will fix it. It's easy to fix something that already works really well. Just put coat of paint on it and show the everyone how much better it is now. Trump's painter costs $54 billion.

Our strength comes from our laws, our sense of community, and our respect for the truth. Trump has constantly rebuked our laws, driven us apart, and lies continuously. That's OK. He will buy us a bunch of ships and planes, fire the career diplomats, and everything will be all better.

Some men drive big cars. t-rump wants to be one up with the biggest military. He must have a lot of stock in the military complex or is paying back his donors who very likely do. That and the prisons. Heaven help us.
He apparently thinks he can just run up America's debt and declare bankruptcy. That has worked for him so far.

I watched Republicans stand and cheer for things they despise, and have no intention of implementing. The president read off a list of things that were either physically impossible, ruinously expensive or politically unworkable. But the fact that he didn’t veer off script and diss Arnold Schwarzenegger must have seemed like a major victory to Republicans.

No reasonable replacement for Obamacare will be forthcoming. If Republicans couldn’t think of an improvement after nearly eight years of maniacal hatred and endless failed and purely theatrical vetoes, they’re not going to think of one now.

There’s a big difference between a child’s letter to Santa Claus and the actual gifts that wind up under the tree. Dear Santa, he seemed to say, I want world peace, a massive military, a complete dismantling of environmental protections, and an Alt-White America in which Muhammad Ali’s son is suspect.

He wants to be seen a strong man so badly that it’s no wonder he’s infatuated with Vladimir Putin. He wants us to think he’s smart, but in fact he’s a 98-IQ weakling who will ultimately get sand kicked in his face. Republicans are getting their hindquarters handed to them at town hall meetings, and Democrats are in no mood to compromise. Good luck getting them to sacrifice their careers to fulfill the impossible fantasies of a narcissist.

And if that doesn’t do it, they only need to imagine this loose cannon prosecuting a war. It doesn't even bear thinking about.

Good summary, Frank. Trump, as usual, rattled off an endless series of lies, excuses, and fantasies that he is on his way to becoming one of our greatest presidents. Meanwhile, many of us watched in horror.

Let's take the widow of Ryan Owen, the warrior who was just killed on the botched mission in Yemen. Trump's instincts told him she was vulnerable and could be exploited. Sure enough, the network TV cameras, who trust the President's commercial instincts, zoomed in her tears. Trump then went on to brag about the wonderful mission her husband died in, as fellow fake warriors Pence and Ryan joined in the applause.

My dad was an Army colonel who fought in three wars, and died a pacifist. His best friend was General Johnny Johnson, who spent much of World War II in Bataan death camp, and survived it and joined the fight.

Those were men. They never talked about their war exploits, or bragged about their many medals for valor in combat.

Trump, who came closest to combat on WWE when he pulled punches against an actor, would have repulsed them. Somehow today's generals, my contemporaries, often support Trump.

My dad was right. The spiritual decline that Toynbee and McLuhan foresaw has seeped into our generals, who genuflect to a circus clown.

That clown just stopped pollution regulation our rivers and bribery restrictions, and wants to kill EPA. And start wars. We need a real man- or woman- to show us the way out.

Where is he? Will enough people listen?

I don't understand why people who didn't serve in the military--especially those who got out of serving from some sort of contrived excuse--are the most bellicose. I'm thinking W, Cheney, and ... Trump.

I suppose it's because those that served have seen first hand the price of war.

But I find myself wondering about all the generals Donald has surrounded himself with, as if the more brass he sees, the more he's reflected in it.
Which begs a question: how long will these generals tolerate serving under Trump?

Mattis seems to be adjusting well, although that stony face wouldn't reveal much. But the latest, McMaster, who begged Trump not to say "Radical Islamic" terrorist, knowing each time it's uttered, it recruits 100 more jihadists--how does he feel now? Knowing his advice falls on deaf ears and how little leverage he'll have with his president, if he can't even convince him to ditch a phrase?

As for Trump's view of war, in general: He campaigned on the stupidity of Iraq, but is ginning up the military as if we'd just been attacked. Surely we don't need an 11th aircraft carrier ....or more fighter jets, unless Trump wants them available to land on said carrier. We have the strongest military in the world, bar none. So why does throwing more money at it feed Trump's ego? Does it make him feel like Superman?

I also wonder if Trump has seen "Hacksaw Ridge". If so, he might realize that courage and winning depend on a lot more than one's weapons .

Yeah, it's kinda like 1943, when my dad told me about all the letters in the newspaper started complaining that there was too much attention to this "World War" thing. Jeesh, it's been a whole year and half already, isn't there something interesting or more important going on? Can't we get back to sports and the Oscars and stuff? How are the REAL Yankees doing (the ones in the Bronx)?

Not....

Just think of all the useful things you could be thinking about and writing about, and yet you remain obsessively focused on getting people to look away from Trump.
You could, for example, try to come up with a reason for Trump demanding so much more money for defense that's not rooted in his pathetic need to feel bigly. Good luck.

Critical difference. Clinton was judicious in his dealings with military leadership and circumspect about using its power. Bush and Cheney-- draft evaders also-- led us into two wars which together = the worst FP disasters in US history. trump looks bent on following in their hypocritical shoes, not the more honest path that Clinton took. I not only "don't fault"  those who protested the Vietnam war and avoided participation in it-- I honor them, and am grateful for the spotlight that ended the tragedy.  However, I despise hypocrisy.

Remember how Trump bragged early in the campaign how his time at a military school was the equivalent of active military service or how he disrespected Senator McCain's Vietnam service? Trump turns my stomach just about every time he opens his mouth. E-5, US Navy, 1976-1980.
He has no shame.
She did not succeed.

Carryn let herself and by extension her dead husband be a pawn of trump. She sure did not build any solidarity with her FIL, who is rightfully asking for an investigation. (similar to Benghazi, one can hope) That is why people are upset. We feel her pain, we do not like trumps use of her grief.
The elected representatives no longer read their e-mails. In CA, our senators either ignore us, or THEY send US e-mails.

JK your plea to teach that "all fundamentalist religion are stupid and evil" fell on deaf ears with an activist and loud and voting segment of our population. They want the lines between church and state to be blurred or toppled. Republicans now run and win as "Christians first." We have a fundamentalist running the Dept of Ed who will make church schools paid for by the tax payer.

great Freud -- you must be a psychoanalyst! What brilliance and insight. I'm simply amazed. If you are insecure about your masculinity then -- the cure is to become president, have former generals in your cabinet, and order them around. I'm going to tell my therapist and I'm probably running in 2024 (2 terms for Trump, of course). Then I can finally come to terms with my insecurities. Thank you Siggie (sometimes a Siggie is just a Siggie, not a Sigmund).

Just two questions: 1) You do have evidence that Trump is insecure in his masculinity, and 2) You do know your comment is complete rubbish?
Who do people rush to make themselves look like mean spirited fools by spouting ignorant hate speech?
It's the best appetite suppressant I've ever come across.

There is something to your point that people exaggerate their risk of dying in a terror attack though that is a fat-tailed phenomenon, meaning jihadists would love nothing better than squaring the death rate of 9/11.

Of course one salient difference between death by ISIS and death by diabetes is the extent of one's own agency implicated in the latter. Except for periods in the 1950s and 1960s and possibly the 1990’s when tax rates on the rich just happened to be high enough to prevent overinvestment, the economy has generally suffered from periodic overinvestment cycles.

It is not just a coincidence that tax cuts for the rich have preceded both the 1929 and 2007 depressions. The Revenue acts of 1926 and 1928 worked exactly as the Republican Congresses that pushed them through promised. The dramatic reductions in taxes on the upper income brackets and estates of the wealthy did indeed result in increases in savings and investment. However, overinvestment (by 1929 there were over 600 automobile manufacturing companies in the USA) caused the depression that made the rich, and most everyone else, ultimately much poorer.

Since 1969 there has been a tremendous shift in the tax burdens away from the rich on onto the middle class. Corporate income tax receipts, whose incidence falls entirely on the owners of corporations, were 4% of GDP then and are now less than 1%. During that same period, payroll tax rates as percent of GDP have increased dramatically. The overinvestment problem caused by the reduction in taxes on the wealthy is exacerbated by the increased tax burden on the middle class. While overinvestment creates more factories, housing and shopping centers; higher payroll taxes reduces the purchasing power of middle-class consumers. ..."

I do not see any mention of the win loss idea on trade. The assumptions of the Trump people, and those rust belt losers, is that the economic pie is fixed, so there are winners and losers when it come to trade.

This flies in the face of facts and history. The more people get involved in trade the more the economic pie as such gets bigger. The U.S. outstripped other countries due to its enormous resources such as iron ore, coal, lumber, cotton, which brought a huge workforce here to build railroads, ships, steel mill and so on. Now other countries have caught up, or have more resources because theirs were not exploited as much.

The advantage the U.S. held until the end of WWII has gone down. Even so, we have become richer because of trade, and so have other countries. In some cases we buy quality such as Bosch, Braun, or like Honda dominated the small auto market in price and reliability. How many had a coffee grinder in their kitchen 30 years ago?

Honda motorcycles dominated the market for years, Harley was a cult bike. They had to catch up. Mexico may sell more here than they buy, but a prosperous Mexico is to our best interests. We will invest in a growing country, and sell it more goods also, like the tings we make best. The economy expands, it is not stagnant which is the Trump view, and the view of many fossilized Republicans.

Mr. Trump's world, prior to being elected, was the development of real estate projects around the world, but centered in New York City. For the purpose of my comment, I will stipulate that he has been a success in that world.
That world, we observe, is characterized by "selling" a concept and its positive impact on both those involved in its creation and potential end users. The tools regularly employed are "puffing", aligning the facts to fit your conclusions, making pronouncements to embolden partners and generally guessing at the final costs. The hard data is left to others - any deviation from the pronouncements is generally blamed on others or explained away as "the way this business works".
We will all bear witness as to whether or not this approach can be successfully adapted to the operation of the federal government.

The exuberant responses of Republican lawmakers last night--the smiles, the approving head nods, the endless standing ovations--were in sharp contrast to their treatment of Obama for eight years. Their stolid non-responses to his proposals for infrastructure renewal, immigration reform and health care improvements never varied, aside from one irrepressible representative who yelled out, "You lie!" If the ecstatic Republicans expect the Democrats to turn into willing partners because the president's speech writers cobbled together a long series of applause lines, they have moved into a castle in the air built by a leader they have come to adore.

The irony is the guy could hit a home run very easily. Drop the wall, the anti-immigrant rhetoric and deportation schemes, and focus on the criminals. Establish a commission to develop a thoughtful approach to reform of health care, promising to veto any plan that would result in anyone who has gained coverage under Obamacare to lose it. Announce a Marshall Plan for rebuilding and modernizing US infrastructure, including aggressive investments in clean energy, that will put a million people to work in good-paying jobs. Pay for it with a combination of temporary tax hikes and targeted reductions in federal spending, including defense. Simple, understandable, acceptable to everyone in his base except the people who hate Barack Obama so much they won't stand for anything less than immediate unconditional repeal of the ACA. All it would take is an admission that he may have been wrong about some things, and we're going to be more thoughtful going forward. Which is, of course, why it will never happen.

"How will we get over the Trump Addiction?" Another intriguing view of Trumptopia that appeared in the Independent, a UK news organization. The following is an excerpt from this eye=opening piece.

"Eventually, when Donald Trump departs from us – in however sudden or gentle a way, perhaps even ironically, though that word appears to have lost its meaning since the US inauguration – I suspect we shall all feel the same as my landlord when the Lebanese war came to an end. For the really insidious nature of the Trump presidency, I fear, is not going to be the fury he engenders, the hatred he sows, the nuclear lies he tells, perhaps even the wars he launches, but the enormous withdrawal symptoms that the world will suffer afterwards.

If there seemed anything noteworthy to come out of his speechifying, I would read up on it and watch it firsthand later. I continue to refuse to watch most of Trump's live coverage, including his inauguration speech and his first address to Congress. I refuse largely because so much of what Trump says or does is spectacle rather than substance. I also don't want to give him the satisfaction of a higher viewership rating. I do go back and review anything that seems substantive.

I simply refuse to be caught up in Trump's maelstrom of marketing and distraction. I want to see past all the noise and know how he and his team are impacting our nation and planet. A vision of a better medical future for the United States must in my view be a vision from a Public Health (PH) perspective. President Trump chose to follow a different line, presenting Megan Crowley, who against all odds has survived Pompe disease, a rare and ordinarily fatal disease.

From my PH perspective I would like to ask the President: What improvements in the American medical care system could lift us from 2d or 3d world status as concerns maternal and infant mortality and pre and post birth health?

From my view as one who translates and edits the work of Swedish epidemiology researchers, I would ask both Megan's father and the President: Do you realize and acknowledge the importance of the basic medical and genetic research that made it possible for you to save your daughter's life. Could you, John Crowley, explain to the president that without this research no miracle could have been accomplished for your daughter and far fewer such miracles will be possible in a future America where science is often seen by you, the President, as a provider of fake news?

Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com
Dual citizen US SE

Promising to rid the nation of "ObamaCare", thus casting 20 million Americans aside without protections in place to have equal healthcare as more fortunate Americans is not pledging to serve America's "forgotten men and women".

In addition, his speech was bizarre as he used multiple "human props", including the very grief stricken widow of a Navy Seal. There is a time and place for the right words and memorials. But by past words and deeds, Trump has shown little true regard for humanity and human life and I can't fathom what is truly in his heart at times like these.

If pre-candidate Donald Trump has spent more time reading a newspaper or watching a TV newscast once in awhile instead of chasing beauty queens and deals... If actual candidate Trump had maybe said to a staffer or two, "Look, I need some briefing papers with background on the important issues that I might have to face if I get elected..." But the actually elected president suddenly has this blinding revelation that health care --- hey, and maybe a couple of other issues --- might be more complicated than he thought... Do we need any more evidence how totally unqualified this bozo is?

Trump talked about how foreign products come into the country virtually duty free while our products are taxed to the hilt by these foreign countries. FYI, I priced a Mustang in Japan. After duties and other nonsensical assessments it came to about $75,000. Not fair!

Are still going to go out and buy Japanese cars?

Trump will never be able to bring down the status quo in Washington.  Those Democrats and Republicans entrenched at the feeding trough will never give up.  The party elite of both parties wants a President they can control.  They will take Trump down.

Trump has no plan - except to dismantle our beloved democracy. He remains in my eyes and much of the rest of the world the useful idiot for the sycophants represented by the two white male Ayn Rand acolytes sitting behind him on the stage.

Unfortunately for Trump and the right he has already very clearly displayed for all to see exactly who he is and what sort of values he represents. His ability to stay on message for an hour with the use of a teleprompter does not in any way define him as a new person. He remains a vile, careless, irresponsible person who is still highly unqualified for the job he fills.

Reading between the lines of his speech reveals the racist bigot he remains. His speech merely masks the hatred and divisive nature he built his platform on while decrying the same last night. In essence it portrayed a man of little integrity, credibility and accountability. Different day, new tone, same shallow man.

I've listened to the morning news shows with such politicians as Ted Cruz and Joe Manchin praising Trump's speech and what a transformational hour it was. I must have watched a different speech because saw a guy totally disconnected from the words he was so studiously reading from the teleprompter.

It's all so confusing. Isn't this the guy who railed on Obama for using a teleprompter? At least Obama gave the impression that he might have actually written the speech himself and had rehearsed it more times than just in the limo on the way over. Isn't this the guy who had insulted about half the people in the room that he was exhorting to come together in kumbaya unity?

People are talking about what a powerful moment it was when he paid tribute to Navy Seal Ryan Owens' widow. I was appalled. It was such craven political theater. To me, it smacked of reality TV at its most sordid. This woman has only been a widow for 30 days, and the man, who was directly responsible for approving the mission that killed her husband, was using her as a prop while meantime, Owens' father wouldn't even meet with Trump at the airport. And then Trump doubled down on a lie about the intelligence gathered. That is perverted.

If Hillary Clinton had approved the botched raid, by now, the Republicans would have already held hearings and opened seven investigations into Yemen-ghazi. I don't get how the hypocrisy of it all seems to elude the media and, evidently, the American people.

It is truely astonishing that the Commander in Chief would get the Secretary of Defense to take the blame for the Yemen mission (read fiasco).  If nothing else, he clearly doesn't understand his role as leader of the country.  The military must be thinking about their responsibility as they move forward.

Trump's vision has created the reality that there has been since he has been elected for weeks and now months no mass murders or multiple killings in the USA with no political capital to be made out of them because they never occurred.

Trump's pivot to appearing more presidential is a tactic to keep the press and public focussed on the image he portrayed last night.  Always deflection to distract from the elephant in the room:  what are his ties to Russia and where are his tax returns?  Let's not lose sight of the bigger picture.

The Donald has always had visions of grandeur in regards to buildings, golf courses, hotels.  He has depended on tax breaks that end up being paid for by the working poor.  Now he is taking those visions nationwide and will take away services and health care from the poor and shrinking middle class , increase our national debt, but train more people to kill and stockpile more munitions.

If you were tuning in last night for the first time, then I suppose that President Trump seemed presidential. But if you have been paying attention, then you know that Mr. Trump's game is centered around a constant stream of self-evidently incompatible promises--if for no other reason than budget reasons--aimed at allowing anyone listening to find a narrative that appeals to them personally.

Maybe the narrative you want to hear is "Build a great, great wall, deport illegal immigrants, beef up the military, lower taxes," or maybe it is "equal pay for equal work, paid family leave, improved infrastructure, stimulus through infrastructure." Either way, the narrative is there if you are willing to dismiss or ignore the incompatible parts and believe that Mr. Trump is really only talking to you.

And short on details and specifics, Mr. Trump offers up only the desirable outcomes, making it difficult to oppose him on the grounds of policy or approach.

This is Mr. Trump's gift. He states problems and outcomes in such a way as to make the listener believe that the solutions are self-evident, as if pointing out the issue and stating the desired outcome are equivalent to a solution.

Who doesn't want everyone one to be taken care with far better healthcare for all at a tiny fraction of the current cost? That this issue is complex is irrelevant in Trumptopia. The only thing that matters in Trumptopia is the identification of the problem and a stated desirable outcome.

It wasn't the inauguration speech, but it was still pretty gloomy. He made a few nods to anti-semitism, workers families, and clean air and water, but the rest was 'the boogey man is out to get you.'

If the debates are any guide, the blustering and bullying will return. He can only hold it together for so long. And good speechifying is a poor indicator of being presidential.

And how will clean air and water be promoted by gutting the EPA, and repealing methane emissions and clean water regulations? Will we be any healthier with lax drug testing standards?

After burning through $10 Trillion in debt with our last President, the Liberals are suddenly fiscal conservatives?

I'm not sure what has been more painful, watching the Falcons owner on the sideline of SB 51, Warren Beatty looking back into a big red envelope, or Mr. "I used to be Governor of KY, now I'm nobody", ramble through a rebuttal. With a teleprompter of all things!

That about sums it up. How much will the Dem donors spend just on name recognition vs. Trump? Pathetic.

As a disillusioned and head-shaking Democrat, the speech appeared to be conciliatory, but with far too many asterisks to be taken seriously. The main question is "how" to financially accomplish his grandiose plans. His uncontrolled throwing out of words like "billions" and "trillions" as though there is in existence a money-oozing cornucopia was simply frightening.

Perhaps he should give another speech tomorrow in which he describes "how" these plans will finance themselves.

"Mr." Trump, America's bloviator in chief, will never "do his job as well," because he is a con man, a fake president, just as he is a fake businessman. This is not unusual for Republican presidents. George Bush was a fake president, a fake cowboy, and a fake businessman; Ronald Reagan was a poor actor who played the president's role. And a large part of the American electorate unfortunately loves fake "reality" shows.

That this man is our President and who's presence is treated reverentially is all too surreal. I still cannot believe it is all happening.
We must get to the bottom of the Russian connection, and fast. And insist on the tax returns.

After a month of rumbles, the earth shifted under my feet last night. A speech of seismic proportions. We know what the aftermath of an earthquake looks like. A fault continues to run through Congress.

And if they do not stop Mad Donald, it will be their fault.

I get that America is a falling empire, and is falling as most empires do, with the help of ego wrapped, wealth encumbered, cultists who worship themselves. Division becomes the new order, and bankrupting the country with insane foreign wars the war to distract the populace.
But Donald Trump is even worse than W. and that person stumbled us into a war of aggression that was a war crime that created ISIS, destabilized the entire Middle East, and killed thousands of American troops.
The world has far more to fear from this falling empire and its love of stealing the wealth of others than America has from pretty much anyone.
Since all American demagogues need to cover themselves in blood, I need to way that Iran is not my enemy, and America has no business attacking it. I am a nobody, and have little influence, but I do fear for the future.
Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

I have heard all these promises filled with great verbs before. What I would like to see is legislation going to congress to transform them in law. Executive actions will not cut it. I believe the DEM's introduced a trillion dollar infrastructure bill, where is it??

I listened to Trump's speech last night. I heard about a country that will not exist with what he, his cabinet, and the GOP are planning to do to America. There will not be sparkling air and water unless one considers water with the sheen of oil or other contaminants glistening in the sun sparkling. Our air will be filled with more, not less particulate matter. That great, great wall will block animal migrations, interfere with human interactions across the border (many of which benefit both sides). The pipeline will not provide permanent jobs for people and American businesses are less interested in hiring Americans for permanent jobs than they are in hiring temps or contract workers whom they don't have to offer benefits.

What Trump has delivered in his first month and a half in office is chaos, empowerment to groups who are racist, anti-Semitic, white nationalist, is the knowledge that they can, with no fear for the consequences, kill, threaten, or maim anyone who does not fit their idea of American. He has resurrected a phrase, enemy of the people, that belongs to the Stalin era in Russia. He has appointed to his inner circle and the cabinet people who are like him: rich, white, conservative, and with shady business connections or dealings in their backgrounds. He has not been working for Americans. The only thing he gets an A for is bad behavior.

Trump's fairy tales for adult Americans:
Infrastructure across America is crumbling, and $ 1 trillion will be spent .....
ACA is a disaster, and will be replaced quickly by something that is cheaper, better, and covers more people.....
Water and air purity will be unaffected as environmental regulatory authorities are made increasingly powerless and squeezed by cuts.....
A strongly rooted global supply chain on which US jobs and industry depends not withstanding, trade pacts will be repealed , walls built, tariffs imposed on imports and this will not harm us but will bring in more jobs, since everything we need will be made in America (also be better, cheaper, shinier..)
All of this will be done not only without raising taxes, but by cutting them drastically for all, and without raising the deficit or cutting any entitlement programs which make up 2/3 of the budget......

Fairy tales, however, are for children.
It can't be long before the rubber hits the road and most Americans who voted for Trump wake up to the fact that they have not only elected a liar and a charlatan as President, but someone who is incompetent, inexperienced and intellectually unable to understand the complexities of national or international issues or how government functions. The question is, once they do, what next?

On the morning of his address to Congress he is attributing blame for the loss of our Navy Seal to his Generals. Later he muses about who might really be responsible for the recent attacks on Jewish institutions. Then, as he speaks to Congress, he behaves more normally and, in some corners, he wins high praise for his presidential moment. Nothing is different - or as my mother used to say, "A leopard doesn't change his spots."

The most outrageous part of the mentally challenged and deranged president's speech was when he declared a brand new office inside the homeland security office called VOICE - and then spelled it out as Violence Of Illegals Criminal's Engagement.

Compared to American born and raised citizens, illegals are much less prone to commit crimes as statistics clearly show.

No wonder there was a loud groan to be heard in the hallowed halls of Congress, but only from the Democratic side.

The whole sorry spectacle of Trump's speech addressing a joint session of Congress was nothing but a repetition of his ultra nationalistic tirades of his campaign rallies, albeit one read in a lower tone with less swear words.

BLUE GEMS That's what pieces of paper written in blue ink were called when they were issued by J. Edgar Hoover. Trump is channeling J. Edgar Hoover, who provided Trumped up evidence to Joe McCarthy and his notorious attorney, Roy Kohn, who was Trump's "mentor." Dementor more like. Trump's blue gems have no meaning and less impact. Meanwhile, welcome to Trumptopia, Utopia's Trumplandia. Yup--there he goes again, the Dementor In Chief, attacking the Washington Establishment and Reality-Based Media! Now that the Barnum Brothers' circus is closing, Trump can move their props to the White House where he can have the Elephants on the South Lawn in peaceful retirement, carrying on the heritage of the GOP by fertilizing the lawn. And trumpeting to tourists. Not to mention performing their circus tricks out of boredom.

Trump operates in the realm of magical thinking. Whatever he says instantly and magically occurs. That's how infants think when they begin to communicate. All of his statements are just that. Hot air combined with blowing smoke. Just look at his record of business failures, bankruptcies and abuse of employes, contractors and creditors, as well as the US taxpayers who bailed him out from the bankruptcies. What made anyone think that his running of the nation would be any different leave alone better than the way he's run his businesses over the years.

Trump is incapable of performing his official duties due to a medical condition, dementia.

Not to forget: Republicans are near the 90% approval mark for Trump. A CNN flash poll says 80% of everyone thought this speech was "positive." Breitbart callls it "triumphant." At the same time Democrats are 90% disapproving of the Prez. Our country is seeing two realities, both very "real" in their respective views. The wide chasm between Trump's ambition and any way to pay for it, plus the even deeper chasm between Republicans and Democrats - chasms within chasms - bodes at least strange and possibly catastrophic for our country.

1. Russia's role in our election--?
2. Trump's tax returns--?
(The two issues are probably related.)

Meanwhile, so far Trump is all storefront (talk) and no merchandise (actual progress).

All of the fawning over how Trump looked "presidential" or "composed" or "strong" makes me nauseous. All he proved in his speech to Congress last night was that he is capable of reading and that he is still perfectly at ease lying to people.

Republicans wrote this speech for him with the hope that those of us with functioning brains will lighten up a bit. We cannot do that because nothing has changed. This is the time to really turn up the heat on the President and party that strives to undo our democracy!

It was an ugly and heartbreaking speech. It culminated in the exploitation of the grief of what is obviously a divided family. The wife at the speech ,the father refusing to even meet Trump. It disguised the fact that trump dodged his responsibility for the soldiers death and milked the grief for a thrilling and cynical emotional high point in the hall.  I just wanted to cry at all the "points" he scored for as one of his supporters said , "a true patriot". Awful, awful, awful.

When somebody shows you who he is believe him the first time. Trump has consistently shown us who he is from the time he started to run. He is still the same despicable self centered person. He has shown us who he is through most of his cabinet picks and his actions reinforcing the irrational fears of his base. The base has real concerns but Trump will not fix those. The low skill manual labor jobs will not return and Republican policies will make their lives worse not better. The only question is how long Republican appeals to emotions will work until the base realizes they have been conned.

I'm surprised you did not mention his words about school "freedom of choice ". Sounded to me like like an intent to dilute public education, and turn DeVos loose with her voucher/charter school philosophy.

I always thought what made America Great in the past were all the public school systems.

I find it funny that people are giving Trump credit for maintaining self-control for one hour. Reminds me of a parent that praises a child for not throwing a temper tantrum at the store. We have a 70-year-old stupid, immature narcissist as president. Just because he occasionally acts reasonable doesn't change that.

Trump leaves a lot to be desired but the speech and its contents were bipartisan and presidential. Frankly the real losers were the democrats with their sour faces incapable of applauding policies and programs that rational Americans support.

Who is against a merit based immigration system? Cracking down on violence in Chicago, baltimore etc? Make American buy American? Perhaps the most telling time was when Trump said he was president of America and not the world. The democrats sat motionless. Pretty pathetic. Behavior like this will continue the marginalization of the Democratic Party.

I did not vote for Trump but I was very impressed with his speech. It was so much better than I had expected and I am sure that is what many people are thinking this morning. There is likely much disappointment among many Democrats that Trump did so well, as many of them had to have been hoping for a disaster.

I would expect nothing less than this sour tone from the EB. For the rest of us, it was a beautiful speech that reached out to all Americans and acknowledged the contributions of so many. President Trump has addressed the issues so many of us want to hear about, health care, failing schools, immigration. His one month in office has been a good start. From the paper that touted 8 years of hope and change that delivered nothing, a little humility is called for.

It sounds like Donald is expecting to built hard infrastructure the same way be builds his businesses. Hire those "forgotten men and women" to do the work, then chisel their expected wages down to a fraction of what was promised when it comes time to pay them.

Or maybe he could just borrow money from Russia.

So our so-called President is more like our Con-Man in Chief. Some liars are effective in convincing the gullible because they believe their own lies. They have chosen to ignore objective reality, replacing it with a totally self-serving agenda, based on a grossly inflated appraisal of their own importance.

And too many of us have lapsed into the error of measuring human worth by financial net worth. This is where it has gotten us.

Thanks to his speech writers who wrote one line each for his very 1st S.O.T.U. address,Mr. Trump looked presidential than he ever was. And ever will be.

His vision of America that he painted last night which you rightly called an Edenic America or 'Trumptopia' was as phony as everything else he said.

His call for $1 trillion infrastructure spending is as old as this country is.

Obama proposed it many times but the marauding and totally racist Republican members of Congress who only want to fight foreign wars instead of taking care of the American people, never paid any attention to a Black president's plea.

Now since the exactly the same plan is proposed by their White president who harassed our country's first African-American president for 7 years for doing nothing wrong but for being "Presidential While Black", the same Republicans will procure this money by cutting down all the social safety networks that our poor Americans depend on, so that their man in the White House can take credit for a proposal that the Democrats in the Senate already proposed a few days back.

Go figure!

And Trump presented his main campaign promise again "build a Wall" on the Mexican borders but not on the Canadian borders from where the White Canadians sneak into our country.

If asked he'd say that the Canadians don't come to our country to steal our jobs.

"Well Mr. President,thanks to you and your billionaire friends' production lines there, Mexicans don't come to our country anymore."

He did give us some insight as to how he plans to pay for the infrastructure bill - through public/private partnerships.  Not only will his base have to still pay taxes to help pay for this, they will be charged high tolls for all the roads they drive on because the roads will be owned by Trump's rich buddies.  So much for caring about the middle class.
"The president offered up lots of gauzy promises but no real ideas of how to pay for them."  Sounds like every presidential speech given to Congress that I have ever seen/heard.

The speech last night was yet one more version of the on-going scam.  We are being continually hoodwinked by Bannon, Miller and Kushner every time they trot out a new Trump.  Was this the long-awaited "pivot" or will he go back to being semi-demented?  Who knows.  The only question that remains to be answered is whether Trump is the manipulator or the manipulated.  We may never find out.  In the meantime, pay no attention to what he says; it is almost meaningless.  Watch what bills he signs or vetoes.  That is the only thing that matters.  The rest is pure circus sideshow.

Headlines: Trump successfully read from a teleprompter. Period.
--Trump did not write the speech.
--Even if he did, with a 70 % falsehood rating, who would make book on anything he says?
--Generalities are always easy--just like Tweets. The real world's problems are more complicated.
Trump played a role, this time more successfully than in the past. However, his love of monkey-wrench-tossing and chaos prevents him from being a leader many trust to follow. (His night speech was at odds with his lunchtime meeting.)

If Mr. Trump accomplished one thing in his first month in office, it was to set the bar for presidential discourse so low that a stiffly delivered speech that does not infuriate half the American people is considered remarkable progress.

It would have made a better inauguration speech, but that was eons ago.

Now, let's see how he plans to deliver.

How does allowing coal companies to dump their coal ash in streams create jobs? Have the coal companies hired anyone or even promised retention as a result of the Presidential gift of pollution?

How does rushing out a poorly thought out, poorly drafted, poorly executed Executive Order on banning people from certain countries aid National Security? If there were indeed dire and imminent threats from these countries, his lack of thought and preparation made those dangers more probable.

How does aggravating Mexico, a potential ally in the fight to curb illegal immigration, further the goal of protecting our borders?

How does alienating our NATO allies for a few dollars strengthen our security?

How does playing footsie with a country that delegitimized this President by messing around with the election campaign strengthen our security?

How does throwing money at the military square with the non-interventionist promises during the campaign?

How does appointing billionaires and Goldman Sachs alumni to Cabinet positions drain the swamp?

I don't what they call this in NYC, but it seems to me a classic bait and switch. He promised a shiny new car and has delivered a clunker.

And not to be overlooked is his attack on the free press and his new abhorrent tactic from yesterday - accusing his political opponents of false flag operation instead of condemning the openly avowed anti-semites who support him. It is time for Republicans to step up to defend the Constitution.

If reading a professionally written speech is the standard for being presidential, then sure he has set low bar for expectations. As a society we so much admire transformation of a grizzly bear to a varnished artifact. But it was an artifact indeed. Devil is always in action. Fingers crossed for us.

Infrastructure work? Sure, Democrats are for it; Pres. Obama proposed plans for it from the beginning of his administration, and Republicans refused to support it in any degree.

So now Trump proposes infrastructure work as if it's a new idea; but in one respect, it is. He refers to the concept of "public-private partnership": Do we really need the construction of toll roads by for-profit companies? Looks like yet another Republican bait-and-switch.

I refuse to watch any wannabe-dictator un-reality show. It's more of the same Lies and Poisonous Vapor no matter how his handlers try to tweak the "tone" dials. If you can see through the apricot mop to the beady little eyes, all you find is emptiness. His plastic parts can wildly gyrate and spew vile hate and dystopia or they can affect slightly more muted actions on the lower setting. None of it is compassionate, intelligent, or presidential. Nor is it harmless. Perhaps we need a VOICE - Victims Of Incorrigible Corrupt Executive, but that would be for all of us, including nature, global climate change victims, the poor, the middle class, and even his gullible voters. Our only hope is that his cheap, foreign-made parts spontaneously combust or Russia issues a recall. Until then, you won't find me in front of a television normalizing his behaviors; I will be marching in the streets, enlarging the resistance, and taking local action. See you there!

Trump's behavior last night was in such sharp contrast to his consistently off behavior, and most especially at that recent crazy-fied 77 minute news conference, that I wonder if somebody slipped him some a calming down med.  In any case with med. or without, such divergences have a short half life.  A tiger may saunter down a different path but he can't change his spots.

Trump has done one thing very well and consistently. Projection. Whatever defects and flaws he has in his character, he attempts to paint them on someone else. So Hillary became "crooked Hillary". And her "corruption" in the Clinton Foundation became a major theme of his campaign. Of course, the monetizing of the presidency going on right now makes those accusations look petty. So when he accuses the press, the watchdog of democracy, of being "the enemy of the American people", I know, without any doubt at all, that he is looking in the mirror. Sad!

Really? You're criticizing Trump for not replacing Obamacare in under 40 days. Imagine the criticism if he had - Doomed to fail. Rushed to judgment. Not even thought through. The writer clearly abandons common sense just to be critical. Did you forget that he needs to get buy-in from the do-nothing obstructionist congress.  Obama's legacy will forever have a severe black mark from failed Obamacare, among so many other  failures. You should praise Trump for being brace enough to try to tackle health care when it is fraught with unimaginable challenges and risk to his presidency and the GOP. As far as striking a balance between pursuing Trump's great vision and how much we should spend on it is what makes governing so tough in the first place. Add to that getting it through congress, which is what differentiates successful and failed presidencies.

With a national debt at $19 trillion dollars, no president or Congress in most of our lifetimes has ever paid for programs.  We should hold Trump accountable, but not just because he is Trump, or to create a metric by which he is guaranteed to fail, as have all his predecessors including those the Times did not call out for failing to pay for their proposals.

President Trump is right on his message as promised.  Whether socialistic democrats want to work with him and congress will be shown whether it be problematic or not.  The socialistic democrats seem to enjoy their divisiveness and are not truly concerned for the American people or want to better everyone's future.  The last eight years did not work perhaps the next four to eight will work for everyone to prosper with the U.S. standing tall in the world again.

My overwhelming feeling about Trump's address is of a student chosen to give a speech at a civics event sponsored by a service organization as President-for-a-day. The English majors would quote from Macbeth:

Life's but a walking shadow, a poor player
That struts and frets his hour upon the stage
And then is heard no more: it is a tale
Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury,
Signifying nothing.

"The forgotten men and women", now are those the ones he forgot to include when he discussed healthcare with insurance executives, or are they the people he forgot when he discussed "jobs" with business "leaders" or are they the millions of forgotten men and women whose health and lives are at risk due to his destroying the EPA?

There is a flaw in Trump's idea of allowing interstate commerce in Health insurance; that means rural people who underutilize sparsely available health care will be paying for extensive use of urban and suburban health care. That means the country folks will be paying for city folks doctors bills and hospital bills where people use lots of medical care. The Trump followers in the country, are not going to like this.

The staged speech of an unfit fanatic did nothing to assuage the fears of decent people that this out-of-control lunatic pretending to be President and his gag-worthy administration will do anything to help middle class workers and advance democracy here and abroad. The majority of Americans will continue to resist the racist radical extremist right personified by a bragging corrupt Putin-loving bigot and the spineless haters who goad him on to curry favor with dictators.

Watching his address to Congress would have been a waste of time. So I didn't. This man cannot tell the truth so why listen. His handlers instruct him on what to say and they're an ill-informed group of "apprentices" and a scary bunch to boot!

I really don't see much happening on any front of the economy, infrastructure, military, health care reform, or immigration. Congress is still in a holding pattern with ideological gridlock and that has to be broken before any meaningful legislation can take place.

I really don't think 'How are we going to pay for it?' is a question that has much relevance anymore, since the last 6 presidencies all saw US debt levels rise in double figure percentages. OK, Clinton scraped by with a 9% rise aided by a soaring economy, but let us not forget the tireless GW Bush, who eclipsed his father's miserly 10%  debt squib with his own whopping and unrecoverable 42.7% cluster bomb crafted through diligent creation of his own private Vietnam.
