Barack Obama, your smartest and nicest President yet, inherited this monster and now passes it to Trump with his own 16.8% further- into- the- hole-debt cherry on top. So yeah, rather than whine about the odd trillion-dollar addition here and there to something that is not just incomprehensible to the vast majority of  US citizens but also absolutely out of anybody's control for ever and ever, might I suggest a more pragmatic approach might be to let the guy do his Trump thing. As Bruce Lee said, "Be water, my friend". You might as well be, because your cup runneth over.

Aside from the negativity of this article, it does not accurately reflect the speech the President gave.

The speech was hopeful, outlined an agenda and offered a hand across the aisle. What it did not do was rush an agenda to the floor with out planning.

Regardless of your political persuasion, it is common knowledge that the ACA is dying. This is in large part to a rushed agenda. Minority Leader Pelosi stated on Sunday morning all the rushed accomplishments she and President Obama pushed through, from the ACA to the failed stimulus. Both examples of poor planning and execution.

If there's anything a good business leader has to and does, it's planning. You don't rush complicated initiatives. Like the EO on immigrants. A learning moment for the President.

While the Editorial Board looks for reasons to douse the President's party, the smartest thing the President can do is, "Get it right."

The Democrats didn't get it right in 2008-9 because they let the power go to their heads and thought themselves invincible. They thought they had a dynasty coming and the could fix problems because the "little people" would be so happy with the gifts they would pray to them forever.

People don't appreciate getting broken toys for gifts.

So this time I believe the Republicans will read the plan before they enact it and put out something that works.

They've seen what happens when you don't. It's not pretty.

Trump promised access to healthcare for all, not healthcare for all. Americans have had access to healthcare, though 50 million could not afford such.

Millions of Americans cannot afford to fund a healthcare savings account of an appreciable amount nor could benefit from tax breaks. Republicans coverage for preexisting conditions expire if coverage has lapsed for 18 months through, perhaps, job loss.

Chances of an American dying on American soil from Trump/Republican healthcare will be much greater than dying from terrorism.

There are two "Trumps" to be dealt with. The first is the unhinged madman of his rallies, where he eschewed teleprompters and actually tore one apart, and instead extemporized his unfettered, disconnected, immature, and wildly unstable id to all the unsuspecting dupes in his audience. The second Trump is the one seen last night, in the well of Congress, reading a speech someone else (Bannon, Miller) wrote for him, not understanding a single word of what he said, but acting like the Messiah come down from the Mount to save America from the teeming hoards of filthy, dangerous outsiders.

The point to remember is that Trump is ALWAYS the first version. No matter how smoothly he delivers his lies and propaganda, he is always the uncontrollable madman. At times, when a more civilized demeanor is needed, he dons his sheep's clothing and speaks in tongues to smoothtalk his listeners. But underneath this veneer, he is still the lunatic wolf, bent on devouring America. And the people be damned.

And yet the media rushes in to pronounce him "Presidential". Van Jones even wrote an article for CNN titled "The Moment Trump Became President". What he misses is that Trump never became President in the full sense of that word, nor can he. He is still the same misbegotten, lying charlatan of the campaign. He cannot change his stripes, no matter how well he reads someone else's words off a teleprompter. Trump is Trump, and that spells a dreary next 4 years for America.

The grieving widow was used for political purposes! How about the photo op with  Ivanka and Jared. The father was right not to come to this shameful display! We have been fighting War on Drugs over many years and spending a lot of $ to what end? Prescription drugs are now causing more deaths. Violent crimes committed by immigrants is a smaller part of the picture than Trump presents. Crime has gone down in my city. I lived through the 70's, 80's and there was more crime back then. Prisons are full of low level drug sellers that were incarcerated during "The Wars on Drugs". What did we win?

Some of those business executives meeting with Trump in the West Wing told him that they had jobs, but no qualified applicants.  Logically, you would think this knowledge from the front lines of manufacturing would prompt a leader to think about vocational education.  I did not hear anything about that last night; only that jobs are coming back.  Well, mostly they are not.  And the ones that do and the ones that are already here require people to have some specific technical training.  Technological advances have changed the way we manufacture things.  This, far more than NAFTA or immigrants, has changed the reality if manufacturing employment.  Technological advances in the way we extract coal and falling prices for alternative fuels like natural gas, have strongly contributed change in coal mining employment.  It would be nice if our president could demonstrate an appreciation of the organic changes taking place in the labor market and propose a plan to help ordinary Americans adapt to them.

Given the unpatriotic attitude Republicans have regarding taxes none of this stuff is going to happen, and that's that, period. Prepare for a big horrible, if not tragic mess.

As for reality based media maybe remind the public that over the last sixty years Republican administrations are the deficit spenders and Democratic ones expand the economy and reduce debt.

After that point out that it is the Blue states that support this country including donating to support Red states. None of them pay their own way except Texas.

Both Bannon and Trump are wannabe TV stars. They need to keep seeing themselves, or, the consequences of their actions, acted out on TV. Preferably accompanied by hostile opposition to enforce in their radical status.

Even as they inhabit their actual parts in real government it is not as real as seeing it through the eyes of the media. One could discuss Lacan's idea of; the real, the imaginary and the symbolic, to drill down into the infancies of both men - but that would conclude pretty much what the world is viewing in action.

To say that they have 'jumped the shark' on 'jumping the shark' might lay it out more clearly. Something Trump has been doing since - whenever.

When reading from a teleprompter he sounds half-presidential. But anyone can read the prepared remarks (prepared by whom, I wonder?) and sound as if they have a plan for our countries future.

It is the daily barrage of ineptitude and insults that tell the real story of this so-called president. That, coupled with the incompetent selections that have filled his cabinet. Betsy DeVos and her ridiculous statements about HBCU come to mind most recently, while Pruitt and the private email server fiasco seems like ancient history, but only happened last week.

Each week we are subject to some new outrageous assault on our liberties and what most certainly must be violations of the constitution. It is like the slow removal of a bandage. I hate to say this, but I wish he would just do something completely illegal so that congress has no other choice than to stop their sycophantic clapping and head nodding and remove him. It's time to rip the band-aid off quickly for the good of our country.

Trump also said that education is the civil rights issue of our time. But he appoints a secretary of education that doesn't know students with special needs are guaranteed an education under federal law and thinks that historically black colleges and universities are pioneers in educational choice.  I would laugh but I'm too sad and angry.

Stephen Miller wrote a great speech and Trump delivered it like a sixth grader presenting a book report. But, as the average Trump voter reads at that level, this resonated with their sensibilities. The question I have is this: can Trump continue this clear-headed "public face" when all of his unscripted moments and tweets indicate that his cognitive skills are at the polar opposite end of this reasoned approach? Or will he suffer some kind of public meltdown that shows even his most ardent supporter that he come from a unstable, volatile and vengeful place?

Two chickens in evere pot! Two cars in every garage!Sound familiar? It is only a matter of time until even Trumps most ardent supporter realize that the Emperor has no clothes.
In the mean time we need to focus on keeping Trump sane enough to not bring the world down upon our heads until the mid-term election. At Which time we can use each of his failures to deliver to defeat him and his opportunisic supporters (those who know that there is no plan or funding for his delusional agenda but are in it for themselves) by takeing back some combination of the House and Senate and begin to "bind up the nations wounds".

Balsamic prompter's speech (no doubt written and approved by Bannon and Co.), offering grandiose feats in harmony, classic demagoguery by telling what his public wants to hear...but divorced from reality. Believing in something is a far cry from being so; but, quite frankly, I doubt he believes any of his assertions...unless he is able to convince an obstructionist republican congress (until Obama left) to increase the country's deficit by the trillions of dollars. His doggone intent to repeal Obamacare is really the objective, given his newly acquired G.O.P. party doesn't have the foggiest idea how to replace it...without meeting the wrath of the 22 million folks who depend on it. And his attempt to build up the military (already bloated with 600 billion dollars at its disposal), which did not request more money (to enrich private contractors), is another fantasy of his for display only ('a la Russia and North Korea'); all at the awful cost of thrashing valuable programs to help the poor. He forgets that the U.S.'s capitalist system breeds inequality, by always favoring capital over labor, requiring government to moderate the inequities of greed...by sensible regulation and getting the 'rich and powerful' to pay their fair share. Thus far, crooked lying Trump seems to be favoring mostly his own privileged class...and not those in need (invisible to him, as he never had 'skin in the game'...other that exploiting the folks that worked for him). This is a vain, nasty guy.

I listen to political boiler plate - from tax credits, block grants and competition on the right to free college on the left, and ask myself how that is going to work.

I feel the same way listening to drug ads. The pill will make you happy, or cure your pain, or step up your sex life, or control your blood sugar. But while all those happy images are flashing, a voice over rapidly explains that it also may cause seizures, coma, anal leakage and death.

Can we require politicians to have that voice-over when they talk policy?

"The policy may cause increased inequality, larger deficits, instability, economic meltdown, polluted streams and even death."

I suppose if we are going to judge the high water mark as the fact that the President wasn't actually embarrassing, no one will be listening to the voiceover of the dire side effects anyway.

Some thoughts in no particular order:
1. The democrats and other cynical naysayers look very foolish today. Opposition opposes. Not a problem there, but you can oppose without looking infantile and foolish. To be fair to the Dems last night, I was expecting more a tantrum like opposition like the one they've shown since Trump won. They were disgusting but still behave.
2. I'm tired of this "where are the details" rethoric. And this is done from both parties...in a 1.5 hours speech, how do you expect a president or candidate to provide "details" of programs that require pages and pages of procedures and budgetary calculations? The address last night was for a newcomer president to provide his vision for the country, not for talking GL debits and credits.
3. The speech was magnificent, great job Mr. President.

I couldn't bring myself to watch or listen to the speech. The President's utterances hit my earls like the TV ads or used car salesmen. I hear a huckster selling a piece of bad property by saying it is the best buy I could get, imagine the opportunity, you'll love the way you look. I hate ads, I don't like to get phone calls at dinner time either. Have we become inured to the constant barrage of ads in our world. I am used to listening to a President who has a realistic understanding of policy and history, not a sleazy salesman. I listened to some commentary afterwards and apparently he read the speech and seemed more Presidential. Another way of selling the rubes. I cannot believe that the electorate wants a wall, lower taxes for the upper class, and more military spending on battleships at the expense of environmental protection and diplomacy.
The president's economist once again offered the Koolaid of tax and regulatory strangling of the economy. This is the dogma of the Republicans since Reagan. He cut taxes at a time that the economy was swinging up and got credit, but then had an epiphany of responsibility and had to reinstate them. Do we have to keep doing the experiment about taxes? Mr. Bush got taxes lowered and we didn't get a massive increase, Kansas tax break didn't work. We had a recession and the consumers got nervous and stopped buying "Life is Good" caps. So give a tax break to the CEO, so the buyers will come back?

"It's time for the American president to do his job as well."
The poor, tired cries from the media -- pull yourself together, Trump, act "presidential" as if an appearance of normality in his current position is akin to actually being presidential, and do what a president is supposed to do.
Everyday, the same empty phrases and wishes.
He is not presidential, not last night, not ever.
He can't be covered by the media as if he is normal, or qualified to be president, even if technically he is, by 77,000 votes and the Electoral College, Russian interference in our election, James Comey, etc.
Stop looking and hoping for something -- and someone -- that doesn't exist.
No policies, no world view, no intellect, no idea how the government he heads even works, a white supremacist as his closest advisor, encouraging hate one day, decrying it last night -- he's a lost soul and that's how he needs to be covered by the media.
A dangerous lost soul, completely out of his depth and comfort zone.
And that's how he needs to be covered by this paper and the media in general.
Out of his depth and out of his mind.

Trump is all sales pitch, lies, and contradictions, but it is pretty clear you can fool American voters much of the time. That speech was pure razzmatazz and bunk that whipsawed anyone's brain who was trying to keep track. Let's see:

Lots more coal, the Dakota pipeline under the river, AND clean water folks

Build that giant expensive wall to keep our all those immigrants, most of whom are malicious criminals, AND a more welcoming attitude to hardworking immigrants

Great education--once it is privatized

Great, great healthcare--once it is privatized, regulations are removed, and access become more arduous

Gigantic expenditure ($54f billion) for the military (on what and for what reason?)--to bring us peace, of course.

Lots of trashing of Obama and lots and lots of first person singular. Obama was the guy who talked in terms of "we": Trump is all "I" and "me" befitting any dictator or demagogue

I sure hope the press holds Trump accountable throughout his reign, because Trump is one slippery dude, who sure knows how to the play American voters as fools, while he, his pirate's den of millionaire and billionaire cabinet officers and advisors, and the Republican Party decimate the national treasury and trash our country's good will.

Then pile on American values and symbolism at the end

I decided not to watch;  I was not going to let Trump ruin a good night's sleep.  So I read all about it this morning.  Apparently I missed little except a list of banal promises written by someone who must be a writer of children's books.  It sounds like Trump must have also been sedated, which was a nice touch.  But he is still a liar and anyone who is foolish enough to see this speech, or his comment yesterday about changing his approach to undocumented immigrants, or his extraordinarily tardy denunciation of anti-Semitism and hate (when his whole campaign was founded on hate) is pitifully disillusioned.  Trump is first and foremost a salesman, which is not meant to be disparaging.  We all are to greater or lesser degrees salesmen.  But Trump is not particularly slimy, dishonest type who will say anything and do anything to make his sale and then worry about delivering the goods later.  Trump could see that his first 39 days were not selling well even with his supporters nor with members of his own Republican Congress.  He saw that he was using a losing sales pitch, so he had to change his pitch. But Trump is unchanged, and he is not going to change.  He is still the same malignant narcissistic sociopath that he has always been whose sole interest is in feeding his own ego.  Many people see politics as TV entertainment and Trump as great entertainment, which he exploits.  But he is still selling the same old snake oil; last night, it was just in a new bottle.

Trump put on another spectacle. His supporters saw and heard what they wanted. A rabbit pulled out of a hat with drum roll. They did not see the sleight of hand, inflating his ego and bank account while insulting and scamming others. They will deny the shallow, snake-oil sales and dangerous reality of Trump -- so well documented; definitively documented -- because they are blinded by the pompous spectacle of Trump and their thirst for revenge on a federal government, which Republicans forced to fail.

We are living in a surreal time. When lies Trump truth. Alternate-facts are evidence. Some people believe Trump's words over their eyes. Some people believe Republicans work on their behalf because Republicans waive an American flag to hide their efforts to make the federal government fail.

Democrats cannot/should not try to appeal to Trump supporters. When they suffer greater in Trumptopia, they will be told it is the doing of Democrats. And they will believe it. Despite all facts, evidence. Trump supporters should be cut loose to lay in the bed they made. Democrats should devote their energy to mobilizing and activating the electorate which sits on the sidelines and does not vote. Educate them; end their apathy. The people who voted against Trump, the majority of all voters, need Democratic leadership to not just help them survive Trump but to mobilize us to trump Trump. AND Republicans.

What State of the Union-like speech has not included gauzy promises without specifics? At least the speech showed that Mr. Trump can act presidential if he wants to. If  Mr. Trunp continues to control himself,  those who expect or hope for  an early end to his presidency may be disappointed. But do not despair. The photograph the other day of KellyAnne Conway on the couch in the Oval Office  sitting on her legs proves  that the Trump administration can be brought to its knees.

This nation has always been a sanctuary for con men. Our president is the greatest con of all time.

"Health Insurance". The term itself is a fraud.

"Environmental Protection Agency" Fraud in progress.

"National defense" Specialists in attacks on other nations.

This address should be nominated as a mocumentary in the Oscars next year, maybe with the title "Wah Wah Land."  There were some themes early on that most could get behind but as we know the devil is in the details and those were sorely lacking.  While opening with an homage to black history month and decrying recent anti-semitic acts, earlier in the day his administration was floating the idea, with zero evidence, that his "enemies" (liberals, liberal Jews?) were in fact behind some recent desecrations.  Many Americans think we should be upgrading our infrastructure but his plan for how to pay for it?  A combination of public and private funds.  Huh?  Does he mean lots of toll roads and bridges?Plus we're only going to use "American" steel and workers for these projects.  Are people going to be willing to spend 2 versus $1 million dollars per mile to build interstates?   Tariffs on foreign products but is the American buying public ready to pay more for everything from televisions to underwear?  Oh wait we're going to make all that stuff here at home in American factories paying lots of part time workers minimum wage with no benefits.  Then their is health care.  Cheaper drugs & premiums, no mandate to buy insurance, but no exclusion for pre-existing conditions, and no requirements for what is required as basic coverage.  Say what?  Accomplished by allowing interstate insurance, slashing the FDA budget & regs, and a tax credit?  Show me the money.

Well, we will see. I thought it was a good speech. It may be Trumptopia, but there must be a vision, and his vision is one many will buy in to.

He urged compromise, and it was effective. He called for a repeal and replacement of Obamacare, with improvements, and with that call he was pressuring republicans and giving hope to democrats. On immigration, he hinted at major reform in the afternoon before the speech, and created a buzz with that, adding to the atmosphere of compromise.

His support will go up. His detractors will look like naysayers, impeders of progress, out of step, marginalized. Be careful editorial board of the NYT, if you don't find something positive to say from time to time and give some credit, you will risk becoming irrelevant to the narrative.

Lets not become co-dependent. Abusive relationships usually cycle as follows:  threats, harm, apology, repeat. And so it goes: threats from Trump (borders, deportation, the media, etc); harm (bogus tax cuts, poor cabinet choices, terrible executive orders, deregulation of environmental protections, destruction of health care, women's rights, etc.) and "apology" (last nights substance light performance).

Kudos to President Trump for making the pivot if you will, delivering a speech rich with policy and full of hope that only bitter angry democrats could find fault with. The democrats were dressed in white to cover their black,  dark hearts. These radical leftists hate our President and despise any vision for the people of our nation that weans them from the dry government nipple. The President has both parties of congress, a seat on the Supreme Court and 8 years to undo the disasters of Obama. Stay tuned.

Gauzy promises indeed, with the hammer, Paul Ryan, seated behind him.
It made one miss Joe Biden.
The Celebrity Apprentice President, the man engaging in all the trivial fights, obsessed with admiration and self-praise. He still has the same steep learning curve he had the day before. He still has a white powered nationalist pulling his strings in his inner circle, still prominently on the national security council. That speech was salted and peppered with Bannon-speak.
Still falsely implying he inherited a terrible economy.
Fully void of details. Trillions for privatizing the public domain in a scam called rebuilding our infrastructure?
Humor me with specifics.

Mr Trump gave the best speech of his political career last night.

His speech writers clearly intended last night's address to raise his profile from that of a con man to that of a statesman. Long on self congratulation for things he has yet to accomplish and long on vision without a plan to fix things, and specific on blaming others for slip-ups of his and his party's own making, his address never the less was surprising in its call for working across the aisle.

That said, we must treat his speech as words designed to paper over the gulf he has created in this country with his partisan and divisive campaign which appears to be never ending.

Until he actually leads a governing process as distinct from tearing down the accomplishments and policies of President Obama, he remains nothing more than another republican politician.

Last night’s speech only proved that Chump can stick to a teleprompter speech on occasion. The billionaires and the alt-right are cheering along with the craven Republican party whose sole purpose is to hold on to power at all costs. However the underlying dark philosophy is unchanged and the chaotic action does not match the bombastic rhetoric. The Democratic leadership should not be beguiled by a TV makeover but must fight the destructive policies of this administration.

I tried in vain to watch this address. I flicker in and out of stations to view a few times. I get this horrible, foreboding feeling. At the risk of sounding a bit dramatic , my gut tells me this man truly views himself as King of our nation. A King who will save the poor, misinformed and uneducated surf of this land. You see, he has never lived an authentic day in his life, he never had to for he was born into great wealth. From an early age, he was taught that winning at any and all cost defines a successful life.

America is a 238 year old experiment. It was born with a pledge of a democratic government "of the people, by the people, for the people". Maybe these times are a message of complacency on our part. Maybe these times are bringing "darkness out of the woodwork where it formally hides" .

This 4 year ride will be a turbulent one. My hope is that "we the people"continue to raise our pitch forks. We practice greater diligence keeping in touch with our elected offices and insisting our voices are heard through our votes.

Trump can try and create whatever facade he wants to try and slow down the loss of support he is facing.  But the leopard never changes his spots. The rich will get richer, the vast majority will face less in so many ways: less income, less healthcare, less protection from  environmental hazards, less protection from American bred gun violence, and less optimism about their and their children's future. This is a person who exudes hatred and anger. He tempered the speech last night because it was written by others to try and make him look different than  who he is.  It took 70 years to create the Trump we see every day. One speech cannot undo the arrogance, hatred, racism, xenophobia, misogyny, and lying that I, for one, have come to know and despise.

One of the most disturbing points in Trump's speech was to see the glee on Paul Ryan's face when Trump proclaimed the Keystone Pipeline would be revived. At a time when our planet is experiencing one environmental catastrophe after another, it is a crime against humanity for Trump and his advisors/supporters to continue their allegiance to carcinogenic-liquid-death (a.k.a. oil). Likewise, this plan to build up our military when we already have more firepower than any other nation is also ill-advised and immoral. First, Trump proclaims that he was against the Iraq War. Now, as president, he wants an unprecedented surge in military spending. Trump, who appears to have paid little or no federal income tax for years, should be the last person to determine how our tax dollars are spent. Disgraceful!!!

Golly, I pay more attention to Wall Street, which is right now partying at the thought of him cutting even more taxes for the 1 percent, giving government leadership roles to the nefarious Goldman Sachs gang, and already dispensing with federal protections against businesses poisoning our air and water by gutting the EPA.

He threw no bones to the rest of us. No minimum wage increase. No support for the Affordable Care Act. Zero support, zero, for our public education system. Any service member will tell you that his big, big boost to the military will be spent on over-bloated civilian military contractors, not the men and women in the military forces who often must rely on food stamps and housing waivers programs because of their meager incomes.

Sad.

Resist!

1. A border wall that Americans will end up paying for instead of for much needed infrastructure that will update dangerous bridges, roads, and other systems.
2. Muslim ban that is against the Constitution and the promises of America itself from the days of the founding fathers. Sharp rise in hate crimes against Muslims and Jews. As George Washington wrote to the Jewish community in Newport, "For happily the Government of the United States gives to bigotry no sanction, to persecution no assistance, requires only that they who live under its protection should demean themselves as good citizens."
3. Mass deportation including peaceful immigrants who have been here for decades or who arrived as children. Families broken up, American children left without their mothers or fathers, other children deported into dangerous conditions when they have loving families waiting to receive them. Immigration agents turned into stormtroopers and jackbooted thugs with no rules.
4. Pollution of America's water, land and air. Regulations that protect workers, that keep products safe. All disappearing.
5. Destruction of healthcare system that helps more than 20 million Americans, many of whom will suffer and die. Rollback of Medicaid benefits.
6. Slashing of budget on Dept. of Energy for big science and technology. China moving rapidly ahead on supercomputers and cyber issues. No NEA, NEH.

Forget the country's builders, artists, and inventors. Trump is trashing them all.

Well, President Obama had won a Nobel Prize in the early days of his presidency for what? Being the first biracial president? He had accomplished nothing in the first month, but had big plans, few of which came to fruition.

Obamacare as it stands would fall on its own merits. It needs to be fixed or more insurance companies will leave and only expensive options with limited coverage will remain.

Remember that you can't tell a book by its cover. Trump is finally finding his way and is being guided in the right direction. If the goal is to have him fail badly, subsequently everyone in the US fails badly. If he succeeds, the US succeeds. Regardless of your opinions, he is still the US president.

On the same day these fine words were flying, three of  Trump's children were in Vancouver promoting the opening of a Trump hotel/condo development amid  protest, controversy and, a paucity of city officials. The undisclosed local security costs and what are probably much larger secret service costs for this conspicuous corporate promotion are underwritten respectively by the Canadian and American taxpayers.

Promises, promises, promises...

Barack Obama proposed a $1 Trillion infrastructure program (at essentially zero interest) to put unemployed Americans back to work but the obstructionist Republicans spoke in one voice and shouted "NO!"

Infrastructure definitely needs to be built and re-built. It would definitely help if all Americans decided to pitch in and do their share by paying their fair share of taxes to avoid increasing our future debt obligations.

Today's Federal tax burden as a share of the US GDP is actually at the low end of historical averages. If we take simple steps to restore progressive income taxes we can afford to make these improvements without burdening our children.

Let's see... Eliminate Grand Cayman Islands tax evasion, raise the income taxes on super high earners, eliminate the "carried interest" loophole, and repatriate and tax US multinational corporate profits allocated to P O box addresses in Ireland and elsewhere.

I didn't hear any of this in Trump's speech last night. Maybe he could "Put his Money where his Mouth is" by showing us his tax returns and how much he has personally contributed to our infrastructure.

While the nytimes is still following up on the promises' watchdog function- what else after dropping from the policy watchdog the editor and ceo promised in their very letter after election?- it is perhaps instructive to take a look back at the issue.
Since this is the first time accountability is called upon intentions,which is the hidden motor of promises, i think it would be correct to go back to when televised presidential speech (usually full of promises) were archived and confront this presidency with the precedent ones.
Otherwise all this jounalism activism is un-meaningful.

Of course, it would be delightful to check out the post-presidency life of these promises either they were realized or not, i think president Clinton would come out very low on the list, since he has repeatedly self-blamed for pretty much all the civil causes he took charge of, starting from the marriage act, down the road with three-strikes-out criminal policy, and continuing with economic subsizing imported food into the third world directly from the first (which is maybe the only issue he's now repairing through his foundation).

That said, it's amazing the pattern nytimes has developed over this presidency, being outrageous at every word of Mr.Trump, only to eventually recognize he softened his position, and then repeat the cycle.

In the meantime its inflamed articles ensued subscriptions, and mr. Trump is not outsmarted. Only exposed readers are harmed. That's still serious but not tragic.

I watched Trump's address and the media drivel that followed. I evidently, watched a different version of his speech. Here is what I saw:

1. No real call for unity. No sincerity about working "with" the opposition.
2. Continued animus towards democrats evidenced by the continual right hand waving/pointing gesture to the democrats side of the room. It was a belittling and blaming gesture.
3. A painfully blatant manipulation of the recent widow of an honorable service man who died in Trump's first military action. Her loss was, observably. too recent and raw. His words too insincere to hide his real purpose in having her there. Then he claims for her a record length of applause???
4. No promises for continued government financial support to individuals for health insurance. Only access and temporary transition accommodation.
5. Proof positive he lives in a fantasy world and is very bad at basic math. He is going to spend all of this money: the wall, infrastructure, historic military funding increase and tax cuts.
6. He may not have shouted his words or displayed his typical level of anger. But, his tone was just as divisive and mean-spirited.

Yet the media claimed he was "more presidential?" Why does this man keep getting a pass from the media? His performance was marginal at best! It is a very sad day when we've lowered the bar THIS FAR for the president. This was perhaps the worst address in modern presidential history. The Emperor STILL has no clothes people!

For those who would hope for a renaissance of the Democratic Party, we will have to separate Donald Trump' s performance from the policy. The speech was delivered with that odd mix of emotional truth and alternative facts. The performance was not only his best but a warning to Democrats that he will be a very formidable opponent whose approval ratings will get a big bounce.

However, Donald Trump missed an opportunity to propose a health insurance plan that would reassure the American people while appearing to opt for the Ryan Plan that would reduce benefits, increase costs and cut coverage. Health care/insurance directly touches every American and their families. It is on this issue that Democrats have a golden opportunity to present to the nation an improved ACA that could include, among other features, the public option. Health care is about cost, outcomes, benefits and coverage with the only important choices that of doctors and hospitals. Ryan and the Republicans talk about competition and the choices that competition provides. Competition in plans are irrelevant. Choice of plan is only important if you understand insurance jargon. Medicare is a remarkably efficient program that provides excellent benefits, universal coverage at a reasonable premium while allowing its subscribers the doctors and hospital of their choice. If the Democrats can address its financial future and take the lead in fixing the ACA, they will receive the support of a grateful public.

For whom was this editorial really written? Reads like a commitment by the editorial board to slash and burn Trump at every opportunity, perhaps to justify their misstep in endorsing Hillary Clinton and their misjudgment about the election result.

Trump's first address to Congress was pretty much a home run. So far, I've found only one poll (CNN/ORC poll of speech watchers) gauging public reaction: "Overall, about 7-in-10 said the speech made them feel more optimistic about the direction of the country."

That's about all that could be accomplished or expected in a 90 minute omnibus speech delivered after only 40 days in office. Earlier in the day, Trump rated his messaging as merely a 'C' or 'C+.' As polls become available, we'll see if his grade improved last night.

Trump's first true State of the Union address in 2018 will provide a better podium from which to judge his administration's first year. I hope he succeeds. But, the truth is we'll have to wait until we see.

My current reading is The Dictator's Handbook by "Bruce Bueno de Mesquita" but no I am not thusly about to wander into diatribe about Trump's likeness various of history's worst leaders. One of the examples used in the tome is Lincoln (manipulated himself a second term against the odds by instituting absentee voting for soldiers), it's about how the powerful stay in power with promises and payoffs to select constituencies. Instead I am going to point out that Trump is rounding off into Mr Ordinary, a typical American President of the last 100 years. Full of expensive vague promises with little ability to pay, a difference being that Trump is an expert at defecting blame if and when those promises fall flat. Recall Obama mentioned curing cancer in one of his first speeches.

If this is a trend and the starting position of the Left remains severe outrage we can see that they will look pretty silly fairly quickly, sort of like the Tea Party demanding the Gov keep it's hand off Medicare. Can the Left stay focused without it's clamorous name calling and outrage? My advice to my Left fellows is "Do your job."

Most people have never created a business, they only wish they have for the money. Developing something from a piece of land, with nothing on it, that then this creation has economic viability and employs hundreds of people, is quite an accomplishment, the process teaches lessons.
The lesson is in the vision, the lesson is in the planning, the lesson is in the execution, the lesson provides wisdom on how the create the next and larger creation. This country will only grow out of it's malaise of low economic growth through smart investment, productive execution, repeated over and over again. Since every progressive I have ever known has never created a successful business, it is impossible for them to understand this. So the reality is if this is going to happen, the negative Nellies, whom are the progressive left, just need to be ignored and let to whine and protest.
The Chinese get this as does most of Asia. They are focused on creating growth. The Greeks don't. The Germans get this, the Italians try. The Israelis execute a plan beautifully, the Palestinians don't. Our progressives don't implement or execute, they just expect other's to provide for them. What a sad group of people.

"It’s time for the American president to do his job as well."
Every time the word "American president" is associated with his name, I cringe. He will never be up to the job because he doesn't have the intelligence, the thoughtful consideration or the understanding necessary for even adequate execution of the office. Each time a man who has boasted of his predatory behavior towards women, vilified those Americans and world citizens he disdains, made fun of people with disabilities (the list is well known and continues) is normalized in any way, we are further threatened by his dangerous vision of the world and his threat to humanity. Every day that goes by without challenges to his conflicts of interest, his refusal to release his tax forms, and his relationships with Russia is a day that brings increased acceptance of his threatening behavior. Action must be taken by every citizen, the free press and all legislators of conscience.

It's more like "Visions of Trumperbole" than "Morning in America" and a "city on a golden hill."  We have a President who seems to know how to demagogue an issue, but not how to legislate an issue. Who asks the political class to put aside "trivial fights" while he continues to Twitter shame Arnold Schwarzenegger, Nordstroms, and a "so-called judge" among many others.  Unfortunately, the President seems to have learned that legislation is "more complicated" than a 140 character Tweet. If he's really for immigration reform, lets see what he proposes; if he's really going to spend $1 trillion on sorely needed "'crumbling infrastructure,'" let's see the legislation he sends to Congress; and meanwhile we're all eagerly awaiting "better health care" at "'a fraction of the price.'"  "Promises, Promises" may have been a hit on Broadway, but it's always a flop on Pennsylvania Avenue.  It's time for Mr. Trump to move from acting in a "fake" Reality TV show to the true reality of  Washington and acting like a President.

"He even opened his speech with a long-overdue condemnation of hate “in all of its very ugly forms.”

Agreed that although long overdue, I'm glad that he said that in front of the world. President Obama said that the position has a way of changing you and if he can remain subdued, refrain from calling American individuals who disagree with his policies enemies, and hire people across the aisle, he may be able to turn the negative perceptions of him around. I also would like to hear him apologize for the hateful rhetoric he has consistently spewed against other Americans. If he can demand apologies from others, he can freely issue apologies as well. Simply stating for us to move beyond the past, doesn't heal the deep wounds that exists in the people or organizations he attacked on Twitter, but a sincere apology, not denial will.

Many have stated he was very Presidential last night and while I agree that I saw a better Mr. Trump, Presidential means taking ownership of the past wrongs that were said and done, not just sweeping them under the carpet. True unification accepts and embraces dissenting views. I would like to hear him say, "I apologize", not just "move on".

Overall, I give him an A for effort and a B-for his speech. While none of us are perfect, if he continues to understand that he is the President for all Americans, I may one day give him an A overall and sincerely believe that he is putting all Americans first irrespective of party or disagreement.

Last night, I saw someone who listened to his advisors to deliver the speech his supporters — both inside and outside that room — needed. He did that well, which heightens my worry about our country's future because it attempted to use data and history to dress up the administration's agenda, but the content and lack of connection to how to pay for these grand plans remain the same.

What stood out to me is that it's irresponsible to express competing ideas as if they can exist together in reality: Keystone and Dakota Access Pipelines/promoting clear water; merit-based immigration system/hire American; "high honor of admission to the U.S."/freedom, etc.

How are these ideas the essence of America? Criminalizing immigrants, failing our public education system with school choice, returning health insurance to not be an option for many people, refusing refugees, talking about hate and civil rights as a policing problem instead of a cultural and institutional one, trading diplomacy for military might, declaring that we "are all made by the same God." None of these embody greatness.

Last night was just another campaign speech. Not unusual and not unlike what presidents Bush and Obama have done in the past. But beneath the rhetoric lies a GOP plan to privatize everything they can get their hands on, cut taxes for the wealthy and for corporations, remove a host of environmental, health and safety regulations and spend billions preparing for a new war.

These are the issues we are confronted with. His supporters are hopeful because he at least is now talking to them.

The press should spend its time carefully examining this list and also speaking to the working class. We've already cut 10 trillion dollars in taxes for the wealthy. Why wasn't there a jobs rebound from that?

Our wars have already put 3-4 trillion on the American credit card, which the working class is paying for. We've already been at war for 16 years. And what have we accomplished? So what would spending an additional 54 billion accomplish?

And we know that contrary to what the GOP claims, private companies don't deliver public services cheaper and more efficiently that government workers. Ask anyone who's tried to contest their cable plan. And when they do reach someone, ask why they have a strong East Asian accent? That's what privatization looks like and will continue to look like for Americas working class.

While Trump deserves attention, his plans for the country deserve more because of the damage they will do.

Tell me, as part of your "investigative" reporting, can you tell us just which Republicans took this ego driven president "out to the woodshed" to have a talk?
The buffoon of the past month had seemed to be replaced by an almost "presidential" entity. Of course,once parsing his speech, one is struck by the volume of promises with virtually no means on how to enact these promises but, at least, he sounded like a "leader" for at least an evening.
I, for one, am not swayed or stirred from my initial impression of the man; a blowhard, bully and a man used to having his own way even if he isn't sure just what that "way" is. As evidenced by his talk last evening, somebody talked to him and, for the brief time frame of his talk, he seemed almost, well, believable.
But that was last night. Which Trump will we see today or tomorrow or over the weekend? Can the "controlling forces" that squeezed an almost acceptable talk continue to influence this man? I really doubt it but it did play nicely especially to the almost lock step Republicans who can't wait to deliver more tax cuts to those who finance their party.
All in all, a good display of "smoke and mirrors" delivered in a measured tone with just enough "patriotism" tossed in as a garnish.
Wave a flag, call upon "Jehovah", mumble platitudes about "everyone getting along" and then proceed to wall building and upper class tax slashing, the true Republican agenda.

Last night was a turning point, but not the one this journal thinks. It showcased that this nation has lost its way. The Fourth Estate fell hard in inexcusable ways. I listened in disbelief as pundits marveled at how "wonderful" this transparently awful speech was.

Never mind that mere hours before intoning about the terrible antisemitism happening all over the country, he was opining that it was a trick conjured by Obama and protesters for attention. Never mind that hours before looking dewy eyed into the camera and assuring us that our Children's futures are sacred to him, he was merrily putting in place systems that will slash funding for their schools, endanger their drinking water, compromise air quality, take away their healthcare (a literal death sentence for some) and that a day before taking to this stage he was openly mocking the military for its failures, even as he pivoted on stage to smirk at them. Quite literally everything he "promised" last night he has already undercut through an executive order.

That brings us to the grotesque exploitation of a grieving widow and the families who lost loved ones in violent crime. Wake me up when we exploit every murder by noting the white, Christian Americans who kill each other in staggering numbers.

Although these insane hypocrisies, reversals, and lies were transparent, I then watched the spectacle of America's "best and brightest" pundits and journalists fall all over each other gushing about this debacle. Sad.

I listened to the entire speech last night; I never listened to an entire speech by Obama. I found President Trump to be inspiring and presidential. He's my man. I realize the liberal opposition is angry and disappointed that Hill lost. Well Trump won and its time to move on. As Obama told the Republicans in 2009, elections have consequences. Well that's true now as it was then. The election of Trump has consequences, and if the Democrats wanted to avoid those consequences, they should have paid more attention to the working class instead of Beyonce, J-Z, Bon Jovi, and the rest of the entertainment class. Their valises are not America's values; they are especially not my values. Its time to steer America back in the right direction. Trump has done that. Thank you.

This official senior citizen is left feeling jaded, if not cynical, and definitely depressed. Donald Trump personifies just the sort of politics that we have wanted to leave behind for generations. We thought that incoming economic and educational tides would raise all boats. We have sought more than once to promote, create, and preserve a great society within my sixty-one years living upon this great planet - the only one we happen to have.

We are not, via Mr. Trump and company, looking forward: We are looking backward toward social division and cultural chasms. No matter how well the scripted speech is delivered, it is just that; a script intended to mollify and mislead. We are better than this. We need to let our other branches of public service know that we expect wiser, more informed, governance than can be offered by the current white house administration. Trust but verify? Better to know whom to trust to verify.

A lot of the media will be fooled for at least a short time by the Trump speech. Too many will frame this as 'the pivot' or 'the reset' where maybe Trump will begin to transform into a normal President.

This will be proved 100% wrong by the policies Trump actually pursues (they will not change), the tweets the next time someone disagrees with Trump (yup, he's still unhinged and still lying), and the speech Trump will give it his next rally (the policies have always been much closer to the content of his rally speeches than the content of the few teleprompter speeches he has given).

People should ignore Trump's teleprompter speeches, or at least the ones where he stays on script. They are the fiction, the rare instances where one faction of his handlers (the weaker faction in the White House) is able to get Trump to dangle a glimmer of hope of some sort of pivot to normalcy that never actually arrives.

The real Trump is the one tweeting irrationalities at 4 a.m., saying that nobody knew health care was so complex, proposing a budget that only makes sense if you are ramping up for war in the South China Sea and Syria, claiming credit for "saving" jobs that he had no role it saving, governing by inflaming racial and religious divisions, displaying utter ignorance on policy issues on a daily basis, etc., etc.

It just took Trump a few minutes into his speech, to demonstrate to me how confused Bannon or whoever wrote the speech is. “America is ready to lead”. America or any other country will not be able to lead the world from a position of isolationism. Leadership does not thrive behind a wall, attacking your friends and, admiring your foes.
From that moment on, the confused ideas continued almost non-stop:
“America has expended billions defending other’s borders.. overseas” So the escalation in the military budget is not directed to actions overseas but to fight domestic violent crimes, “lawless chaos” “crime cartels” and illegal immigrants.
The change in immigration policies. Asylum is never granted just to the highly educated or foreign investors, it is usually granted to people running for their lives flying from war zones. The idea is to protect them and give them a chance. Will family ties be ignored?
“American crime”. What about crimes committed against non-American, legal and illegal persons living in the USA?
I completely agreed with the announcements of fighting the opioids addiction pandemic and, the one trillion dollar budget to rebuild our infrastructure. I thought Speaker Ryan would collapse but to his credit, he managed. I loved the “clean air” pledge and, I cannot wait for the Secretary of Energy's policy.
America’s "new friends". To make Putin happy?
Yes, trivial is over. Now, I want to see the budget. Do not forget Trump tax returns and Russia investigations.

Tax cuts as enacted by republicans feather the already luxurious nests of the ultra rich while the rest of us get a stick or two. Results time and again have shown that tax cuts do not have a profound effect on economic growth. Neither do tax hikes as long as they're not ridiculous.

Tax cuts tank revenues. Military spending is one of the least efficient ways to stimulate economic growth though some increase in economic growth can occur if the increase is large enough. Whatever acceleration occurs goes into the military industrial complex's pockets.

Pssst... Mr. Not-My-President, Ryan and his Tea Party pals in the republican caucus will never approve the infrastructure improvements we need.

When will their voters realize the free lunches republicans promise don't exist?

What was different in Trump's speech last night was his delivery. The content didn't change. Trump expects "unity" to happen when everyone agrees with him. Consensus, however, could only come with flexibility. Gutting the EPA, installing cabinet secretaries pledged to undermine the departments they will run, promoting Bannon over legitimate security experts, maligning journalists who represent different points of view, crowing about a fence along the Mexican border and frightening an immigrant population that has lived and worked here for years... these are some examples of the delusions Trump has spouted and imposed  since he swore that he would "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States." And with all that, because one night he manages to read from a teleprompter and maintain a "measured tone" in his address to Congress, he is now rated "Presidential?" What I heard was Trump playing nice instead of nasty. The grandiose proposals were still unsupported and there was no acknowledgement of alternative viewpoints. Despite the smooth tones, the message was authoritarian to the core, and unreasoning besides.

As the left side of the room remained silent with arms folded, I was reminded of lines from Simon and Garfunkel's Sound of Silence:
" People talking without speaking, people hearing without listening."
Trump continues to campaign with the same tired rhetoric. One day Ryan and Pence will come to the realization that the promises made by Trump can never be kept. Grand illusions of Trumptopia are to be paid for on the backs of those of us who depend on Medicare and the social services who's fund we have contributed to. He claims that social security and Medicare are sacred cows, while military spending increases to unprecedented levels Who was it that promised butter and guns? Oh yes, guns are now available to the certifiably mentally ill and the wall keeps getting higher There was nothing there to expect except more broken promises and confusing alternative facts.

That he read the speech from the teleprompter allowed him to look quasi-presidential, but the actual content was no better than typical trumpian bait and switch. He talked about clean air and water while embarking on a campaign of deregulation that will be a polluters' charter. He highlighted a young lady with a rare handicap while promising to hurry along the development of new medicines; maybe he doesn't remember how the precautionary approach to thalidomide delayed its use in the US market and avoided who knows how many birth defects.

I have heartfelt sympathy for the military widow from the Yemen raid, but she is twice a victim - first for losing her husband and secondly for being shamelessly used sympathy for her to mask his negligence in ordering an ill-chosen and ill-deployed mission. It wasn’t enough to invite her and nod to her sacrifice, as other President would have done. He nauseatingly milked her loss for his own crooked purposes.

As I listened to this deceitful manipulator-in-chief, the image that occurred to me was of the serpent in the Bible.

Was Trump more conciliatory in his speech last night?  There were several themes carried over from his campaign that were still reflected in his speech.  Stirring up American’s fear from a huge increase in crime, from violent acts of illegal immigrants from Muslim nations and Mexicans, his commitment to building the wall, a renewed effort in the failed war against drugs, violence in inner cities caused by guns is a demagogue’s tool of choice in winning support for his mean-spirited policies. His new acronym for helping victims from violent crimes committed by immigrants was quite revealing in itself: "FORCE" (Victims of Immigration Crime Engagement).  He expressed reverence for the undeserved beleaguered brave members of law enforcement but said nothing about the racist violence committed against African Americans by the very same group. It was sheer hypocrisy to single out Congressional Democrats to compromise and work with the Republicans to serve the best interest of Americans.  I remember Republicans voting consistently as a block to vote no to everything proposed by Obama.  The truth is a cabinet filled with billionaires and executives from Wall Street will place almost zero priority on the needs of working class Americans; indeed each cabinet member picked to head their departments are united in their drive to emasculate that department.  Donald is thin-skinned and vindictive and will not depart from his actions and statements on display so far.

The ugliest moment in the 60-minute address came when Mr. Trump announced the formation of an office on “Victims of Immigration Crime Engagement,” and then introduced families of people allegedly murdered by illegal immigrants.

He'll never change.
Not sounding like a raving lunatic doesn't equal "presidential" as so many in the media are spouting this morning.  An amoeba couldn't get under that bar.

All this is true...but no one better than Trump knows that many Americans, with their fixation on the short-term, become distracted by that shiny new object. Last night, Trump was that shiny new object. A Trump you have never seen before. He will be looking for a bump in the polls and will probably get it

Build up our roads and bridges, 54 billion increase for the military. Now he may not be saying who is going to pay for all this, but we do know who is NOT going to be paying: Mr. Trump and his family, because they don't pay taxes.

This editorial is absurd. Anyone expecting a fast start from Trump has their head in the sand. He's an outsider and its just going to take more time. Slow is ok with his constituency and not unexpected. Trump has time. He's not facing the Great Recession. No emergency calls for an immediate response.

Trump voters voted for an outsider who promised to enact a broad array of measures to revive the middle class. That is a job that will take years. The Board wants a hare. Trump's constituency is fine with a tortoise. Moreover, anyone who was watching knows that Trump took a huge step forward tonight. The support of the Congressional Republicans was enthusiastic for a change, and that promises good will where there has been little. The greatest roadblock to change for years has been gridlock. And Trump made important inroads tonight.

The desire for a line item budget is insider think, an approach that has put the middle class where they are. A line item budget does no good if it isn't approved. Approval may well finally be within reach.

Trump and his supporters understand that political progress comes in different forms, not just in lines of a budget. And what matters is where we are in 4 years, not one month. No one has helped the middle class for a long, long time, and that's why they got their candidate elected. This is a democracy. They won even if you object to how. It's their turn and they want it done their way, and they are not complaining.
How is going to pay for all these?  He is not even paying his tax , at least his fare share of income tax, we do not have any evidence for it so far.

Did he promise to quit tweeting? It would improve his presidency if he did. I wish someone he trusts would tell him that the tweeting is what is making him look unhinged. Or maybe is better that he continue so that we are kept aware of how nuts he is.

"It’s time for the American president to do his job as well." So, a pot shot at his predecessors.

Trump only knows how to do empty promises, grandiosity, and bombast. That, indeed, will continue at least for now to keep his fans happy. Interviews with them repeatedly show that they think he is doing a wonderful job, getting things done, bringing back jobs, and making us safe again - all in about a month. Donald Trump, miracle worker. As the man himself would say, sad, very sad.

Trump's speech reminded me of his $1 billion Trump Taj Mahal casino speech in 1990.

“It’s truly going to be an incredible place,” he told reporters. “We’re calling it the eighth wonder of the world.”

And then, magically....reality interrupted....and just over a year after it opened, the Trump Taj Mahal was in bankruptcy court, followed in 1992 by both two other Trump Atlantic City casinos, the Plaza and the Castle. In the bankruptcy plan that was worked out, Mr. Trump ceded to the lenders a 50% stake in the businesses in return for lower debt interest rates. The lenders agreed to defer certain principal and interest payments and hold off on personal claims against Mr. Trump for five years. But there was little or no reduction in the enormous debts that would plague his gambling empire far into the future.

Mr. Trump now says he looks back on the period as his golden era in the casino business.

“Early on, I took a lot of money out of the casinos with the financings and the things we do,” he said in a recent interview. “Atlantic City was a very good cash cow for me for a long time.”

https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/12/nyregion/donald-trump-atlantic-city.html

Heads Trump wins; tails America loses.

Never put your vote in an incorrigible, unethical, shameless gambler.

The art of the deal seems to be an expectation game. The POTUS is considered presidential when he appears to be less crazy. He calls for politicians not to engage in triviality but in fact the 3AM tweets have been coming from @realDonaldTrump. Such is the mind games the propaganda in chief has cooked up for our Commander-In-Chief.

I must ask - what about Russia?  This president is surrounded by people known to have had contact with Russian operatives during the campaign, one of whom resigned when it was learned that he had discussed favorable treatment of Russia in exchange for, what?, even before the inauguration.  It is known that Russian operatives hacked the election, thereby tilting the outcome to Trump in exchange for, what?  Where is the independent prosecutor to produce evidence either that this administration is completely above-board, or that we have a president guilty of impeachable offenses?  If all this known liar of a president has to do is promise the nation a pony for Christmas to distract the press from pressing Congress to appoint a special prosecutor in this serious situation then we are utterly doomed to our collective fate.  And, astonishingly, that appears to be the case.

With a habit to repeat the old rhetoric, perfected during the elections President Trump forgets that without a visionary action plan in place, duly supported by a team, and commensurate resource allocation for the same mere parroting of the empty promises could rather prove counterproductive and deceptive. This alone might trigger a serious systemic crisis in coming days.

How many of Trump's worst ideas are really Bannon's doing. It took George Bush 6 years to figure out that Cheney had to be ignored. How long will it take Trump to figure that out with Bannon. Trump doesn't need to be coddled. But keeping Bannon and Miller around does not bode well for his presidency. He also needs to grow a pair, not a fake blustering pair and realize that not every little thing needs to be fought over or deserves a tweet. And cut out the lying or hyperbole or speculation.

This "President" is a charlatan...a huckster...a snake oil salesman.

The real "President" - the one who's running the show, the one for whom not a single American citizen voted - is busy getting high off hits of "deconstructing America" as he works to build his "Christian militia" to "deal with" all of us who don't live in a state of fear and hatred 24/7/365.

So Trump addressed hate in America?...after a campaign full of hate, a month ignoring hate, after doing nothing to acknowledge and admonish white rage?

Health care?...after years a GOP that appears to have given the notion no more thought than it took to vote 60+ times to repeal the ACA (which so many Trump supporters are just now discovering is that awful "Obamacare" they hate so much, the plan they now admit has saved many of their sorry lives).

More military?...because we don't spend enough and we're American dag nab it, we love killing!...one thing's for sure, war has always been a reliable revenue generator for the rich, and making money for the rich seems to be more important for the Grand Old Putrefied than anything else.

Then the wall, another solution in search of a problem.

All this, and more...just to make us forget...Russia.

God bless the press, that "enemy of the state" - time to fight for our lives. Too bad that is exactly what we are doing.

Too bad many of us will lose.

A chicken in every pot, a car in every garage, promises, promises.
Mr. Trump may have, in his early adult life, dealt with the details of how to accomplish something that he wanted to do. Decades of wealth has accustomed him to delegating others to do the work required to do this. He has advisers, lawyers, accountants, and others to do the research and use their time to bring him the proposals , then he decides if he likes them or not. He has taken on the Presidency with exactly this same attitude. He thinks he understands the worlds problems without having done any research or spent any time thinking about them other than watching television. Now he delegates others to come up with the plans to accomplish what he thinks needs to be done. World problems are not solved by watching television. Mr. Trump has never had any proposals to solve any of the worlds problems because he has never taken the time think about how it could be done. He has lied every time he has proclaimed that he did. His plan to build a wall, give everyone cheap and effective health care, destroy ISIS, create jobs, make America great again, all lies. There were never any plans, no time spent trying to understand the problems let alone how to solve them. Now that his ineptitude has become self evident, he is bringing down what we have accomplished over decades of effort and experience, and in the process causing the general public to distrust the very institutions responsible for making this country great.

Can someone tell me a location where infrastructure is actually crumbling?  I would like to take a look at it, or maybe take some pictures.  Anything within 150 miles of NYC would be fine.  Thanks in advance.

Mr Trump's campaign and his first weeks in office have been an willful insult to the history of the United States. He apparently is now hoping a majority of the citizenry suffers from amnesia and has forgotten the vitriol he has and continues to foment.  Guess again.
I believe in the old MegaForce motto:  "Deeds, Not Words." Trump tried not to sound like a would-be dictator.  His actions speak otherwise.

Mr. Trump, if you are going to get all the things you want then rich and poor alike will have to pay their fair share, including you.  As our leader, you need to be a good example to all of us.  By releasing your income tax forms, you can  prove to us here and now that you are, and have been, a contributing citizen.

I didn't watch trump, but caught the critique after including the 62 % approval ratings after the fact.  Have to indulge in a minor conspiracy theory, that maybe a lot of 'not my president' folks did not watch 'his new found self! His tweets before the speech, saying that Obama was behind the White House leaks and that maybe the Democrats had planted the 'anti semitic' raids to embarrass,him,were enough to not to acknowledge him as being fit to be president.
Remember, last night was all words.  It lacked details.  In my view, he has zero credibility due to all of his egregious lies.  I'm with Harry Truman...show me.

I wonder what out-of-work West Virginia coal miners are thinking. During the election campaign Trump stridently promised them that he would put them back to work. Those miners lost their jobs because surface-mined coal from Wyoming was cheaper than the deep-mined coal of West Virginia. Is Trump going to order the industry to re-open the closed deep mines?
Trump said that American companies tax will get a "big, big  tax cut".  Well expect the stock market to have a very nice day.

I am agog, I am aghast at the reaction to Trump's speech from the media and some left-wing pundits.

"A Surprisingly Presidential Speech" - the Washington Post. Really? Can the bar be any lower?

Van Jones was practically swooning, declaring that this speech will "make Trump a two-term president."

"Trump Softens Tone" declared the Times. Oh, goody. The bully shows he can almost be normal.

Beyond the preening, boasting and cynically hiding behind the tears of the woman he made a widow, what he actually SAID seems to be lost.

Let's look at this one nugget:

“I have ordered the Department of Homeland Security to create an office to serve American Victims. The office is called VOICE – Victims Of Immigration Crime Engagement. We are providing a voice to those who have been ignored by our media, and silenced by special interests.”

There's Trump's alt-right racism, media bashing, lying and paranoia all rolled into one.

If you're not an American victim you don't count. Tough.

How does Trump know that some immigrants have committed crimes? He finds out through the media! So much for being ignored.

Special interests suppressing this information? Name 'em.

His demeanor, while more subdued, was as nasty as ever. Utterly devoid of compassion, he reads words given to him in a vain attempt to normalize his destructive, delusional politics.

Not buying it. Challenge. Resist. Don't be fooled or distracted. Investigate his ties to Russia. Tax returns, now.

'Nobody knew health care could be so complicated'; Making Mexico pay for his wall by putting a tax on Mexican products that Americans pay; Blaming the military for the needless terribly botched raid in Yemen that he ordered (and Obama refused); Calling the press the enemy of the American people; Insulting all our allies?

A softer tone does not change the fact Trump is a dangerously incompetent fool and serial liar with a hate filled message. Is there any chance the people who voted for Trump will ever admit we now have the village idiot sitting in the oval office and take responsibility for putting him there?
That was some bedtime fairy tale, especially the "to promote clean air and clean water" part.

I think I agree with Senator Schumer: it didn't matter what he said.  Short of announcing that he was resigning and reporting to federal prison (but first appointing Judge Garland to the Supreme Court), you weren't going to like President Trump's speech.  Doubtless much of your editorial was pre-written.

Trumptopia gives a positive connotation to a reality where all is just as Trump said it is; lest we forget the discriminatory policies and religious bans that would follow from living in such an existence.

I object to the reference of this Trump reality being anything related to the "topia" description. For not only are the things he proposed beyond reality, a place that cannot be, but it is certainly negative and unworthy of such characterization.

Create a foreclosure prevention fund for homeowners
Close the Guantanamo Bay Detention Center
Tougher rules against revolving door for lobbyists and former government officials
Provide a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants
Reduce oil consumption by 35 percent by 2030
Create cap and trade system with interim goals to reduce global warming
Cut the cost of a typical family's health insurance premium by up to $2,500 a year
Bring Democrats and Republicans together to pass an agenda

The above are some of the promises made by Barack Obama which he did not keep. Mr. Obama made 533 promises throughout his campaigns and tenure. Some he kept, some he didn't and some he had to compromise. There are always excuses for promises broken. They are irrelevant.

All politicians make promises. Some they keep, some they break and sometimes they compromise.

Few are judged on them after 6 weeks in office.

His approval ratings are low, naturally he had to go with what the public wants to hear. Personally? I didn't believe a word he said, as my mother would say "Actions speak louder than words".
He'll be tweeting his next meltdown tomorrow...

The speech was not as bad as we feared. However, the idea that Trump is disciplined enough to keep it going and actually start to deliver on his program seems a bit far-fetched at the moment. Nevertheless, at least things didn't get worse, which is about as good as it gets at the moment.
It's now a question of demanding results from him. Not being seen as obstructionist is important. The opposition is best provided by demanding that the government start to deliver on the new jobs and better healthcare that was promised in the campaign. Letting them off the hook by just objecting to everything is not the way to do it. It's better to join with the voters and constantly demand results - results that are way more complicated to deliver than his political neophytes realise.

Trump is just like XFL all hype. XFL was going to be bigger, better, and  baddest football. Vince McMan was tremendous promoter, great tv ads. Problem was it was all hype, short of talent, and execution. Where is XFL now? We have seen the ads and Trump can only replay the hype, because he is short on talent and execution. The game plan Republicans want is cut taxes on rich and that's all we will get. Seen that show before, very sad.

A few weeks ago our new President wrote a check for 25 MILLION DOLLARS to settle claims of FRAUD and RACKETEERING.

Don't get Trumped again....

Other than destroying health care for all Americans (Obamacare, Medicare, Medicaid, company plans) believe nothing from this vicious cipher.

He's disturbed.

Of course the media are fair. CNN conducted a poll right after the speech and since the results were very positive for Trump, CNN felt obliged to explain that Republicans were over-represented in the poll by 9%. What I want to know is are the billions of dollars sitting in an unidentifiable Caymans bank account Trump's share of the 19% profit from the sale of Russian state oil company reportedly offered to Trump's friend Carter Page by an associate of Igor Sechin, CEO of Russia's state oil company, when Page (a campaign advisor to Trump) visited Moscow in July. Reportedly Sechin's associate said to Page that Rosneft's chief was so eager to have Russian sanctions lifted he offered Page & Trump 19% of the privatization profits of Rosneft. Page reportedly said that if Trump was elected, the sanctions would be lifted.

These allegations, from the famous leaked MI16 dossier, are being investigated. 4 months before the claims were reported to Trump, Obama, Biden, Yahoo's Michael Isikoff was told by a U.S. Intelligence source that Sechin met with Page during Page's 3 day trip to Moscow. On that trip, Page is reported to have met with top Kremlin internal affairs official Igor Diveykin. Diveykin told Page Russia possesses compromising information about Trump. Carter returned to Moscow for more talks on December 9, by which time he'd been 'let go' by the Trump campaign. Trump associates now claim Page never worked for the Trump campaign.

Darryl Assa has called for a special prosecutor to investigate this.

He does not think in critical ways nor does he have the capacity for reading, understanding, articulation or curiosity. A lazy life indeed.
