Trump's cynical tasteless use of Chief Petty Officer Ryan Owens widow Carryn was uncomfortable to watch. So graceless. I felt bad for her.

Remember that Ryan Owens father refused to meet Trump at Dover Base and wants an investigation into the Yemen mission, saying to Trump through the Miami Herald "Don't hide behind the death of my son." Trump still used Owen's widow and repeated referred to Owens as "Ryan," invoking his memory in a sleazy, familiar manner.

Trump's gross.

Making speeches is a standard tool of the process of tightening the control of power. A change in “tone” is not a change in intent. The purpose remains the same. To dishevel policy and promises into a mash of indistinguishable confusion so each one of us sees and finds our own hopes; change or not change is not the point! The sleigh of words make finding the proper, true meaning hard to find. No matter how many times the words are turned over, they don't line up with facts or acts. They drift and bob and mainly offer false hope.

This is President Trump, after all. Why, after one speech, is the media running out of breath declaring the old President of only 45 days swept under the carpet—aren't the tactics plain?

Maybe the media are dunces, finding it impossible to draw out experience and memory, to compare the convergence and divergence of shadow and act. Too bad! They, as much as the elect, create the world of make-believe reflected in the looking glass of national denial, for there the meaning lies.

What is more "trivial" than endless recitations over crowd size and dead voters--by the winner? When is the "time" to denounce acts and threats tied to ideologies of hate and violence? When do surreal photo-ops (displaying every executive order on camera; conducting national security in a Mar-a-Lago dining room), false flags/fake news/alternative facts become real policy?

Remember every pivot is a circle. Every circle ends as it begins. It moves but doesn't change.

"He even opened his speech with a long-overdue condemnation of "hate in all its very ugly forms."

And may we include in those "ugly forms" the hate-filled tweets emanating daily from the paranoid soul of our Commander in Chief? Very doubtful.
How to assess the statements of someone proven untrustworthy?  Why bother?  He (Bannon probably) counts on people being gullible with a short attention span.  And he isn't wrong.  Pathetic.

Amoral hucksterism and historically fraudulent superiority of character and values is no foundation to build a future upon.

Trumptopia promises to be a failed emarassment to white nationalist America in this century just like Fascism was an embarrassment to Europe in the last century.

:...it sounded at times as though he were still running for the job, rather than confronted with actually doing it."

There is a large chasm between the propaganda of a campaign speech and the reality of building a Bill that can actually be passed in Congress. Trump served up delusions of grandeur and magical thinking.

The frustration of listening to a speech by President Donald Trump – and Tuesday evening he gave the best speech of his life by adopting a softer, almost congenial tone – is hearing the casual lies, the reliance on vague promises and sloganeering, and the monumental ignorance on so many issues.

The listener doesn’t know where to begin to analyze and offer a fair critique of the speech because there are many, often contradictory, inaccuracies and relatively few specifics.

One of the more ridiculous themes of President Trump was his description of a plan to renew the nation’s infrastructure as though no Democrat had ever thought of doing the same thing.

It was galling to hear a Republican ignore the fact that President Obama was rebuffed by the Republican deficit hawks for trying to do the same thing, ultimately leading to a threatened shutdown of the government and the burdensome sequestration plan.

We still have no idea how this infrastructure renewal will be funded other than a vague reference to a public-private partnership.

One supposes that private companies will buy the interstate highway system on low-interest, long-term credit extended by the American taxpayers. The companies will charge hefty tolls to motorists on every stretch of highway and receive generous accelerated tax depreciation on the toll roads, and perform some repaving. After a few years, the entire system will be sold back to the federal government at an enormous profit.

Welcome to Trumptopia.

The doom and gloom crowd know what can't be known, where Trump is headed.  After all, even he doesn't know. They believe they have taken the measure of the man and the outcome is pre-ordained. Even though there are a million question marks, they are sure they know how the book ends. Many have been very wrong in their own lives -- divorces, bad jobs, bad investments -- but they still are juding books by their covers.  Some people never learn.

It's funny that every time Trump almost sound like a normal guy, i.e. managing to stick to his script, it is described as something very special - he is "softening" his tone etc. But by now, everybody knows what will follow, some slight will make him rant, curse and insult in the near future again. I know the press, both foreign and domestic, should analyze the Trump speech in a neutral manner. But I really think it should be pointed out that this Trump speech is a very average speech if compared to previous presidents, and a really mediocre one compared to Obamas oratory brilliance and spirituality.

It was a simple political speech. Simple, plain and generic. Look-me-too-can-be-a-good-boy kind of speech. Nothing presidential about it. Nothing touched the heart. Nothing for the mind to ponder over. And the English language spoked rather read aloud without rhetorical ethos.

How he would get it all done? wait and see. I remember the same question asked after President Regan came to the White House.

Trump's technique is to present a promise as a carrot on a stick. As long as that carrot is out there Trump believes he is in control. He has what we want and all we have to do to get what we want is to go along. That's one of the arts of the deal. The most important tactic Trump uses is NOT DELIVERING ON PROMISES. By not delivering he maintains control.
So what is Trump really negotiating for? Well, the answer to that brings us to another question - what does Bannon want?
If we ignore Trump's promises and the media stops showing up to cover his insane lies then we can wrest control back and possibly go back to leading normal lives again.
Which carrot are you after?

I am so glad to hear that we are finally going to have some new "railways" and airports and everything, all "gleaming."

For some reason I found that reference to "railways" riotously funny. Does Donald Trump have any idea how long it takes to get a "railway" legislated, financed, constructed and in operation in this country? A "railway" to where?

Not one word of what Donald Trump says is to be believed. I'm glad to see the New York Times hasn't changed its mind about that.

The biggest "B.S". artist or con artist East of the Pacific Ocean is Trump. Hillary knew how to write policy and budget for it, but that would not have happened. The Republican Party would have tied her up with one investigation after another. Clearly, this Party is not interested with investigating Trump and his connection with Russia. Whether discussing our environment or climate change or health care or education or women or abortion or ... we have a Party that only cares about tax cuts and the military (and where do they want to go to war next???). It is truly sad to listen to the Republicans reject the ACA with no proposal. It is extremely irritating to hear about a wall. Really? This is a Party that has no reverence for planet Earth or the American people.
"The fate of America cannot depend on any one man. The greatness of America is grounded in principles, and not on any single personality." ~ Franklin D. Roosevelt

He talked about better paying jobs. Seems like an easy lift. There are millions working at Walmart, fast food chains, and the like. Higher wages could get these employees and their employers off the dole.

Oh wait. Most of these workers are non-white. Sorry, higher wages won't be forthcoming for you. And if you try to form a union, the NLRB will fight it.

Trumps' address is full of empty words and has no specific plans. Given his track record of lying and distortion of truths, why should anyone take what he says seriously? Mr. Trump, American people are not so easily fooled, or dazzled by your Trumptopia, we know what you have done and fail to do and we are watching what you will do.

The Democratic response by Governor Steven Beshear was exactly right. For me, it is pretty cut and dry.
During eight years of the Obama administration I never that my intelligence was insulted by meaningless drivel -- not once.

There is no reality to tonight's charade, and seeing the likes of Pence and Ryan mindlessly applaud does nothing more than send shivers up my spine.

As an example: today the majority Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee refused to investigate Trump's (and his trolls) ties to Russia.

So tomorrow morning, what will CNN and the NYT be analyzing? The address to Congress or the collusion between Trump, the Republicans and Russia?

Stay on target. Don't be fooled.

A lot of talk but action speaks louder than words. So far all he's shown us is chaos and disorganization. Don't tell me what you think I want to hear, deliver results.

Currently we've seen properly vetted people from countries that have never harmed us denied entry to our country. Thankfully the ACLU, everyday Americans, state leaders, and the judiciary put a stop to it.

People are afraid to travel to our country. The son of Muhammad Ali, a halocaust professor, and a children's author were hassled and detained by TSA agents.

Jewish cemeteries are being violated. Their community centers are being threatened. Two Indian men were shot after being told to get out of our country.

Trump showed tonight that he can read from a teleprompter and give a pretty speech that someone else wrote. I'm not looking for him to sound presidential, I'd like him to act presidential. Don't make promises without details, give me a working plan.

About the only thing he did right was call on both sides to work together for the American people. I agree with that 100%. Please put country before party and work together on bipartisan solutions.

How nice that the Trump regime has found some decent speechwriters and that he can stick to a TelePrompTer.
I guess everything he has said and done unto to now should be forgotten!
Folly to take any of this seriously.

"Over 43 million are living in poverty".  Yes, and Mr. President, what percentage of those living in poverty are medically or psychologically disabled and UNABLE to be employed?  What percentage will be added TO those in poverty if they do have affordable healthcare so that they CAN become/remain employed?

The one place that both sides of the aisle rose was regarding the increase in military spending, ignoring the fact that our budget is larger that of the next seven nations combined. Oh, and no mention about what he proposes to do to help the poor rise out of poverty or get a fair chance. And not a word about his gutting the EPA and State Department.

My guess is that the Trump administration is doing somersaults because President Trump gave a speech that managed to be as banal as his predecessors' similar speeches. A laundry list of vague promises always gets the ruling party applauding while those out of power look on with their hands tucked in their pockets. It is ever the same. Frankly, given President Trump's penchant for creative destruction, I was hoping for more. Still, he provided few details so the opportunity remains for him to disrupt things once the details of his proposals are made known.

If he manages spectacular growth in the GDP, perhaps we can actually afford his proposed spending. Perhaps he could get Congress to offer some kind of tax holiday and get all of those trillions of corporate dollars held overseas back in the land of the free? Now that could give us a jolt and, in turn, fund his proposals!
Good speech but he should stop badmouthing the previous administration in order to make himself look good.

Make no mistake about it, what we witnessed tonight is the kind of president Trump he needs to remain or fear getting 'fired.' But to his peril, with those twitchy Twitter fingers he has, this is going to be one tough act to follow.

Headlines are screaming that Trump became presidential tonight. Don't forget that he has set the bar so low that anytime he is not screaming nonsense or foaming at mouth we are apt to say "Presidential."

I would wait for definite actions in motion before using the P word. Don't fall in the same trap as an abused spouse who forgives her husband the moment he says "But honey, I love you."

Don't be fooled.

This was a feint by Trump and the Republicans to take the opposition's eyes off the ball. Their goal: change the discussion from Trump's collusion with Russia during the campaign; instead, talk about all the all the great things they're going to do (even though it's all Pie-in-The-Sky BS).

Example: today the majority Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee refused to investigate Trump's relationship with Russia.

So, don't be fooled. Keep digging, keep opposing, and keep protecting our Democracy.

Although Trump can occasionally stick to a TelePrompTer script, without veering maniacally, this doesn't begin to make him presidential. He seems constitutionally incapable of living up to the dignity of the office he holds,

Unless he magically moderates and starts actually promoting well-reasoned and detailed policies that promote our common good, I am all for this guy's personal failure. Sadly, however, his failures are likely to take our great nation down with him and that is not something any of us should root for. So I am incredibly torn....

Trump is all over the board. Today's  speech was "Donald the Great". One day the immigrants are in, one day they are out. Or, some are in and others are out. It's not clear. But it sounds good. Yesterday Obamacare was "unbelievably complicated" today "it's a total disaster but there is a plan about to be revealed.  If I didn't know any better I'd assume Irving Berlin was his speech writer.

We remain confronted with fundamentally different convictions about what benefits the “working people forsaken by the economy and Washington”. The left’s conviction is that all that benefits them is being handed a sufficiency divorced from hard work and prudent lives, while the right’s is that they benefit yugely from opportunities that they are left to exploit. Trump speaks a great deal about creating those opportunities, and the left merely dismisses what he says because it doesn’t conform to what THEY regard as a “benefit”.

So, we’re left with dissonance. Trump offered a great speech that likely encouraged millions of Americans with his challenge of coming together, but the editors regard it as fluff because it doesn’t address THEIR perception of relevancy. It’s clear that despite trying Trump failed to speak effectively to ALL Americans. I suppose he’ll just need to depend on an undivided Republican Congress to get things done, without the support of those who hear his words but can’t understand them for a lack of shared assumptions.

He also didn’t offer up a 100,000-line, fully-attributed project plan for how he was going to accomplish what he promises and has started to do both with executive orders and some legislation. It might occur to all of us that presidents rarely use this occasion to get into the weeds on anything, using the occasion to announce broad priorities.

“Trumptopia” strikes many of us as FAR more achievable than Obamatopia ever was.

Remember the old Wendy's commercial (a line even Reagan couldn't resist using against his opponents)?
45, "Where's the Beef?"
Ya, sure, 45 is serving up this thing that's all dressed up in fancy sauces, garnishes and such, but inside the big fake bun of lies and misdirection, there simply isn't any beef in this Bannon-Burger. Just the same old, stringy portion of tax cutting for the wealthy and empty promises to actually do something for regular Americans.
I'm starving.

If they happen,..Trumps infrasructure plans will be built mostly the same way they always have, with the blood, sweat and tears of the only people willing to do the brutally hard work required, in exchange for low wages, immigrants.

Most of Trump's speech was full of exaggeration and self-promotion, not unlike his campaign rallies.  The tone was more subdued and he condemned the violence against Jews and immigrants, which he helped foment with his previous incendiary rhetoric.  While I am very sympathetic and empathetic toward people who have suffered rare diseases and misfortune, I resent the fact that they are increasingly used as props and exploited by politicians who want to milk our emotions to make themselves look more human.  Most state-of-the-union speeches are aspirational but in Trump's case, not so much.

Near the end of his speech, Trump appealed to (mostly) Democrats to end 'trivial fights'. In 80 minutes, the only reference to the environment I heard was a meaningless throw-away line about 'clean water and clean air.' Climate change is not a trivial fight.
We have thousands of violent crimes each year, but the ones he chose to emphasize were committed by immigrants. That's scapegoating, and it is not a trivial matter.
He began his speech by once again decrying antisemitism and violence against Jewish cultural centers. Later, he promised a task force, VOICE, to deal with victims of immigrant violence. When will he direct AG Sessions to assemble a task force to investigate those behind the hate crimes? This is also not a trivial fight.
He returned again and again to a 'failed Obamacare' that would be repealed and replaced. But where are the wonderful plans that Republicans have been devising for 6 years? The trickle of information so far indicates that it will not be inexpensive and it will not cover all Americans with comprehensive care. This is not a trivial fight.
The only triviality in the room this evening were the half-baked platitudes emerging from our so-called president.

Unfortunate Mrs. Owens, suffering so much through Trump's using of her.

Hope Trump enjoyed his Chateaubriand during the dinner at Mar-a-Lago where he approved the mission that killed her husband.

The only things changing under Trump are Trump's points of view. Same old same old - he's been lassoed by Washington. His focus on infrastructure and defense spending as a 'yellow brick road' to winning was predictable with only short term gains likely if indeed he has the where-with-all to generate Congressional enthusiasm and finance. His 'wall' has failed to get off the ground if you'll pardon the expression and that's the most likely metaphor for most of his so-called plans. Also, I found his  parading and exploitation of victims of violent crime to be self-serving and utterly repulsive.

You know I have to say-- all (or a majority) of you are complaining that Trump made a lot of promises, so did Obama when he was in office.

Since when did you people of the NYT become fiscal conservatives? Our national debt doubled under Obama and all we did was spend away!

I think you can save you complaints of where the money will come from. Leave it to the Freedom Caucus to crow about where the funds will come from and which programs to cut.

Will you be happy then?

More vague promises from the Con Man in Chief.

A month into his Presidency and he's barely managed to put together a cabinet. Still some 2000 unfilled appointments in his Administration.

I guess he's too busy playing golf every weekend to actually accomplish anything.

At least he seems to be finally waking up to reality. "Nobody knew healthcare could be so complicated"?

Everyone who knows anything about the subject knows how complicated it is.

Only you, little Donny, didn't know how complicated it is.

Everyone knows it was all just talk at a visceral level. And, most presidents do this in their first year.  It is a shop worn technique in Washington. Tump, of course, mixed alternative-facts as is his habit in every speech. What bothers me most as an American is that the Democratic party is too much of a patsy and does not call it out loud and clear.  Showmanship needs to countered at the same level, not at a policy level as if we are in a debate at Harvard. Either Democratic party does not know it or unwilling or unable to do so. I am afraid it is the latter. Rank and file Democratic party need to raise up and revolutionize the party position and approach.

"The time for small thinking is over." (DJT)
Does this mean he is deactivating his Twitter account?

Trump set forth a better version of America than has graced the pages of the NYT.  Reading here one would think that the most critical problem facing America is transgendered bathroom access.  And as far as immigration, a get tough approach with possible compromise down the line is exactly what most of America wants - not the scofflaw approach of the NYT where open borders rule the day.

Where does one begin?
Each promise/ program was contradicted by the cutting of another program that would support the first promise:
Clean air and water accomplished by a gutted EPA." Country's builders and artists"- accomplished by eliminating or de-funding the National Endowment of the Arts. Massive military buildup as never seen before in the history of the nation: While others fight their own battles and America protects itself- only.
Everyone will be "Covered" morphs into greater healthcare "Access". Millions and Millions of jobs will be created while failing to acknowledge the investment in training for new skills.
Fallacy of eliminating "low-skilled" labor by purging low-skilled immigrant laborers (everyone will become middle-class).
All- reminding me of the 17 yr old who wakes up the following morning as an 18 yr old *adult*; creating a persona of what one believes looks and sounds like an adult.

I thought it was a good speech.  It sounded like a typical State of the Union address - broad strokes, little detail, focusing on individuals in the crowd, applause moments, etc.  I tuned in specifically to hear Trump's softened views on immigration as The Times declared in Breaking News yet he said nothing about that and instead doubled down on deporting people who are here illegally.  Has he changed, is this more fake news or something else?

If Congress does something, anything, on any issue — that's when you'll know what you're getting. Nothing Trump says either informs or comforts the american people, because none of it makes sense. It's contradictory, it's lackidaisical, its flippant and uninformed, but worst of all it's filled with bigotry and fear mongering. It will be up to Congress to do something, or not. Trump clearly isn't up to the job. I don't think he wants to work.

Donald started the speech condemning hate, but he (or his speechwriter) just couldn't help himself. Toward the end, he just had to hate on his favorite target: “illegal immigrants.”

Donald’s rabid supporters will no doubt respond that he was condemning *only* violent illegal immigrants and therefore that anybody who criticizes Donald for this condemnation clearly feels no concern for their victims.

It’s the right’s favorite trick - going back to Joe McCarthy and Ronald Reagan: highlight what is actually the vast exception, let the average human brain mistakenly infer that it is the norm, and then build a toxic policy (in this case, mass deportation) on this mistaken inference.

So the proper response to Donald's rabid supporters: by Donald's logic, we should deport all bald white men. After all, some of them are violent criminals as well.

More generally, don't just consider anecdotes. Do a more global cost/benefit balance. For every violent immigrant, there are millions more immigrants that make net-positive contributions to the American economy and culture.

Just as we shouldn't get rid of cars and roads because of one or two accidents, we shouldn't deport the many “good ones” just because of the few "bad ones."

Trump, perhaps most unsettlingly of all, lies compulsively not to advance any particular end but simply to draw attention to himself - like the boy who called wolf;  a thing which makes of his behaviour not just another serious problem among many that deserves close attention, but a crisis for America (and the world) of monumental proportions. Every presidency, even the most placid, will have its moment of truth.  When Trump's moment of truth arrives, after all his lies, why would anyone even believe him?

The one consistency of the Trump Presidency is it's inconsistency. He is the man whom longed to be President, but didn't know what to do once elected. His Presidency so far is a reflection of the man himself: uneducated in government, history,or the complexities of the modern World and economic interdependence. Not surprising as the man lacks an enquiringly mind, clearly evidenced in the fact that he hardly reads books, or even documents crucial to his Presidential duties.
Somewhere between La La Land, and One Flew Over The Cockoos Nest.
Terrible speech, still totally short on details. Taxes to be dropped "a big amount". So many promises. I thought the opposition speech by the ex Kentucky Governer was brilliant.

He had a chance to lay out concrete details for his great promises. He did not do so in this speech. He had the chance to quote further from the Bible, specifically Matthew 25:40 (...unto the least of these...). He did not. He had the chance to assure the world that his bloviating statements since taking office were nothing more than him venting. He did not. He had the chance to give me strong information that would have perhaps caused me to change my opinion of him. He did not. I would write "sad" at the end of this message, but that word does not lend itself to adequate expression. Perhaps fetid disgust is the more suitable phrase.

Like much of the press, the New York Times has been left speechless, offering aimless critique. (Van Jones of CNN even remarked that Trump 'became president' with the quality of this speech.)

Which intern selected the title of this editorial? Presidential addresses, since the advent of television, have been largely about rallying public opinion, which Trump accomplished here. It's entirely about vision.

It's not a forum for reading a line-item budget, or telling Congress what to write in legislation.

Democrats embarrassed themselves greatly tonight with their jeers (at the families of those killed by illegals), booing (at using American steel), and thumbs down, wearing those dopey, white straight jackets. Sad!

As a Trump voter (an independent who previously voted Democrat) I am quite pleased with his first month in office. The only chaotic thing about it has been the dismal NYT coverage of anything related to Trump and the Democrats' effort to deny him a cabinet. I

knew repealing Obama care would be hard because the entire Congress - Democrats and Republicans alike, save Bernie Sanders - are owned by healthcare lobbyists.

Trump now his last battle in front of him, he has to win the battle with the congress. I wish him luck!

Trump's speech was completely divorced from the reality of his actions.

He paraded the widow of Ryan Owens only hours after denying any responsibility for having ordered the ill-planned mission that killed him. He praised the same generals he had just blamed for the failure of the mission, and called the mission a success even though it retrieved intelligence of no value.

He spoke of clean air and water, only hours after removing environmental protections preventing companies from dumping waste into our rivers and streams.

He spoke of the importance of education a few hours after his own Secretary of Education compared the establishment of African-American colleges during Jim Crow to her own vision of a school voucher system that helps white families keep their kids away from public schools.

He divorced himself from any responsibility for recent incidents of anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim hate crimes despite having run a 20 month campaign openly appealing to bigotry and white nationalism.

I would guess that Trump's base feel really good about themselves and their president today, happy in the denial of the reality of his actions, his ties to Russia, both political and financial, his appointment of cabinet members with no experience in their positions except a disdain for the departments go which they were appointed, and the presence of Steve Bannon in the White House- a man whose agenda is at odds with every lofty ideal put forth in this speech.

In Trumpland miracles abound
Just listen to the Donald's sound,
But no details rise
To gladden one's eyes
It's pie in the sky whirling 'round.

Trump gets an A for tone, staying disciplined, and basically not falling on his face while reading from a teleprompter.

But, in terms of substance and inaccuracies, tonight was no different from any of his other speeches. Still attacking healthcare, sticking with "radical Islamic terrorists" despite better counsel from his own new national security advisor, scaring people with immigrant hating dog whistles "cannot allow a beachhead of terrorism to form inside America"...

Beneath the lofty vision were no details on how we will be able to pay fror all his prior proposals, or any new policy proposal despite the earlier leak of Trump being ready to make a deal on immigration.

Not to forget the whoppers from MSU (Make Stuff Up): 94 million Americans looking for jobs?

Still, the bar is low for a Trump speech, and Trump gave enough reassurance to his primary target audience: the Republicans in Congress.

But the Resistance remains focused on what truly matters: an investigation of Trump's ties with Russia. That cloud wasn't lifted by tonight.
So heartening to read (almost) everyone's insightful comments.  Not enough that this guy has been giving people ulcers; now he wants to give us whiplash.

Should come as no surprise.  Trump has no vision or direction on any item of substance.  In order to get elected he wildly over-promised everything in simple terms, while providing no details.  And now, he has no idea how to move forward on a plan he never had.

Watching Trump speak tonight left me feeling like I was watching "The March of the Zombies" reality TV show --- Trump's voice droning on in monotonous unison with the coordinated bobbing heads of Pence and Ryan in the background --- hitting all the right cues at the absolutely correct scripted moment --- with a relentlessly long dead clapping of hands from the Republican side of the aisle.

A total lack of statesmanship and believability. Absolutely no credibility.

What will we be subjected to next?

Traditionally, the first speech to Congress is short on details and long on ambition. Obama took office in the throes of recession. In February 2009, he passed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, designed to put Americans back to work. The bill was widely considered a success, but Obama grossly oversold it:

"Over the next two years, this plan will save or create 3.5 million jobs. More than 90% of these jobs will be in the private sector - jobs rebuilding our roads and bridges; constructing wind turbines and solar panels; laying broadband and expanding mass transit."

In fact, two years after his speech, 2 million more lost jobs. Gradually, the economy turned and many jobs were created, but the quick fix that Obama promised was wishful thinking. In my opinion, that's ok. We expect our Presidents to be optimistic in hard times and we don't hold them to their word if they deliver us relief in time. The Board is asking for precision from Trump when it should not.

Listening to Trump is like meeting a total stranger at a bar that says all the right things. Deep inside, you know something is up. It all sounds too good. Nevertheless, you make plans to meet later. You enthusiastically show up at the designated meeting place and the new love of your life never shows.

But it all sounded so good. All the items on your checklist were mentioned. How could this go wrong?

It went wrong because talk is cheap. Anyone can say anything. Trump has been doing a lot of talking for nearly two years now. The promises keep coming. Sooner or later, his date (that would be his supporters) will expect something to happen.

It's only been an eternity of 40 days. They are already punting on healthcare, or at least that is the latest talk. Tomorrow, a new plan will be announced that is just about to be revealed. Tax reform is just around the corner. And, all those millions of factory jobs that require low and unskilled workers will be popping up all over the place. Utilities will start building coal plants that cost twice as much to build as gas plants and more to fuel.

Gullible and stupid are two different things. Most of Trumps supporters are far more gullible than stupid. Eventually, they will question why utopia has not visited them. Their sages on Fox News will attempt to pacify and console, but reality will eventually set in. Unfortunately, many will keep coming back to that bar looking for Trump and all those words.

"....promised a new era of rising wages, bustling factories and coal mines, sparkling air and water, and cheaper and better health care, all behind a “great great wall.”

I have my doubts about the sparkling air and water, now that he's rolled back EPA regulations about chemical dumping into our rivers and streams, and rescinding carbon emissions. Pollution, here we come!

And yes, the biggest compliment for Mr. Trump tonight was that he abandoned his dark dystopia of American carnage. And he read form a teleprompter, and he didn't mispronounce names. Nor did he go off script to tell some whoppers that he really believes but hadn't felt free enough to spout.

Every time he rolls out another promise, I hear the ka-ching! of Paul Ryan's adding machine. As I read one of the Times commentators remark during the speech, Trump is acting like Santa Clause.

Sooner or later, reality will hit and Trump will wake up to the fact that negotiating down his expectations with the only branch of government that can actually spend a dime towards Trump's goals is really hard. And really complicated.

Just as complicated as Trump remarked he found the whole business of repealing the ACA. Perhaps if he had taken the time to educate himself on some of the intricacies of the policies he wants to repeal, he might have been less determined to repeal and replace them the very day he walked into the Oval Office.

“Crumbling infrastructure,” he said, “will be replaced with new roads, bridges, tunnels, airports and railways, gleaming across our very, very beautiful land.” Sounds great. What’s the plan? How will we pay for it? He wasn’t saying. He also renewed his promise of “massive tax relief” for the middle class — but once again there are no details in sight."

The answer to how we will pay for infrastructure is explained by the "massive tax relief" bit: the "massive tax relief" will really be the tax incentives for private corporations to do all of the infrastructure work . . . for which you, Mr. and Mrs. Trump Voter -- surprise surprise -- will be paying tolls and fees to use, on top of the continued taxes you will be paying for that $54B military beef-up. The transfer of money from the poor to the rich will be fantastic to watch.

The famous words of John M. Keynes come to mind:

"Practical men, who believe themselves to be quite exempt from any intellectual influences, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist. Madmen in authority, who hear voices in the air, are distilling their frenzy from some academic scribbler of a few years back."

One of the major arguments for a border adjustment tax from those calling themselves economists, is based on a misunderstanding of the purpose and intent of value added taxes. Peter Navarro, director of President Donald Trump's new National Trade Council, argued recently in favor of the border adjustment tax "We as an economy cannot succeed putting our people back to work in Ohio and Pennsylvania, Michigan and Indiana if those countries keep treating us unfairly with respect to that VAT tax system."

Value added taxes are a form of sales taxes with specific procedures to insure that consumption is taxed but not sales of intermediate goods used in the production of goods intended for final sales to consumers. Their purpose is to raise revenue, any impact on international trade is incidental. ..."

Donald Trump is the epitome of a snake oil salesman. He has made great promises to cure all the things that ail us, real or imagined, with his "secret elixir", the ingredients of which of course cannot be revealed. He is right off the sound lot of any run of the mill western, complete with the stench of horse droppings, and yet this is no fiction - he is the President.

Even more horrifying than that is that he is unassailable and unaccountable - the Republican-controlled Congress will certainly not reign him in. And as the media finally, belatedly, has begun to hold him accountable for what he says, he has taken the course of all dictators in denouncing them as liars, and using the Big Lie - or "Alternate Facts" as he has re-christened the term, to deflect, deny, and dissemble. And if that isn't enough, he bars reporters who challenge him from gaining access.

We have placed our nation in the hands of a neo-dictator, whose only goal is to feed his own monstrous ego, and expand his power. It is like giving matches and gasoline to Nero.

The Trump address was quite well assembled as a continuation of the Trump campaign to inspire his acolytes, touch some emotional heartstrings, exaggerate facts and, as with many such speeches of the past, cause the speaker's side of the chamber to rise and to applaud after nearly every sentence. As this editorial notes, however, the Devil is in the details, and the fewer the details the greater is the Devil's absence. Surely some Republican legislators are wondering how even minor parts of the Trump agenda can be accomplished, although it now may be a cinch to give massive tax breaks to corporations and the top one-percenters. At least we are assured that militrary spending and battlefield casualties will both continue to rise. At some point, those whose spirits were lifted by this speech may wonder what hit them when reality shows up at the door.
Doug Giebel
Big Sandy, Montana

Possibly, concerned mother, you need to do some research on Ellis Island.  For all the tired, your pour (which represented the views of a liberal Manhattan poet, not the government in Washington), those who were likely to be a charge on society were sent back, the diseased, those who could not work, those diagnosed as below a certain standard intellectually. The US sought those who could build this country without a safety net. We did not accept people who would need expensive medical treatment and no funds for such treatment were available.

Yes, they gave IQ tests to illiterate, non-English speaking, exhausted, confused, malnourished travelers who had just. endured weeks of crossing an ocean in a heaving, overcrowded ship's hold.

The natural conclusion of the American eugenics movement was, of course, that such immigrants (Eastern European, Jewish, Irish, Mediterranean, and Middle Eastern) were innately defective and could never reach Aryan intellectual standards. And in 1924, the flow of these "defectives" was sharply curtailed, a policy maintained throughout the war, when we denied the 1942 visa application of one Otto Frank for his two teenage daughters.

Today, Anne Frank would likely be an award-winning American author, a retired college professor and great-grandmother, holding children on her lap and telling them stories. She embodies the "huddled masses" and "wretched refuse." I see her face among the Syrians, Iraqis, Somalis and Colombians fleeing deaths not so different than the one she died.

Tax credits  return cash to people in the form of tax refunds, often when those people do not pay taxes. The earned income credit is a prime example of this. Acutally, to give you a budget primer, the process, since 1974 anyway has been (1) the President submits a detailed budget request for the coming fiscal year (begins Oct 1 of each year) (2) next, Congress generally holds hearings to question Administration officials about their requests and then develops its own budget plan, called a “budget resolution.” (3) following adoption of the budget resolution, Congress considers the annual appropriations bills that are needed to fund discretionary programs in the coming fiscal year and legislation to enact changes to mandatory spending or revenue levels as specified in the budget resolution.
So while you are correct that Congress is culpable, the President is the one that gets the ball rolling, but Congress certainly has the right to enact whatever budget it wants, and I say pox on both their houses because both the GOP and the DEMS do not do a very good job.

The problem is that the text of the TPP made clear the environmental and labor accords were nonbinding, going as far to effectively state they could be disregarded if they conflicted with the stated goals of the trade agreement itself.

Meanwhile, the ISDS mechanism would have empowered corporate America to sue to prevent the enactment of any environmental or labor regulations that cut into a company's anticipated profit.

How does this do anything to raise standards?
Sorry, but you can't claim the TPP required tougher environmental and labor standards when both accords were nonbinding.  The end.

It is important to highlight this moral paradox of the TPP deal.  The choice seems to have been either to do the damage explained by this article or to penalize U. S. workers -- some of whom may have been already victimized via forced U. S. military service in Vietnam during their own youth -- or to hurt the next generation of such families.

The TPP didn't "require" anything because it had absolutely no enforcement provisions.  None.  The purported requirements were just window dressing to mollify the public, while corporations carried on with business as usual.  How disappointing that the NYT avoids this issue.

TPP encompassed a lot of components. Many were of dubious value to anybody but large multi-national corporations. Others, however, like some of the things mentioned in this article, were positive. It actually created leverage against China to force them to end currency manipulation, because now a lot of their trade partners might be able to actually reduce dealing with China without shooting themselves in the foot. It would have made US agricultural products more competitive in places like Korea and Japan. It would provided explicit requirements for labor protection in places like Vietnam.

But, nationally, we were in full-blown knee-jerk mode in 2016. It became heresy to even suggest that start with full disclosure TPP terms and then try to re-negotiate the negative parts. We were talking about trade agreements in Manichean, good-vs-evil, almost religious terms. The only acceptable outcome for both Herr Trump and Saint Bernie was blow it all up. I think in the coming months and years, we will that when we leap to drastic measures, what we get are drastic outcomes.

Something sadly lacking from the debate about the TPP and trade -- evidence and careful thinking.

Here is a Columbia Univ. study hot off the press. It finds that US firms exposed to Chinese competition created MORE, not fewer, manufacturing and other jobs: "More exposed firms expanded employment by 2 percent more per year as they hired more (i) production workers in manufacturing, whom they paid higher wages, and (ii) in services complementary to high-skilled and high-tech manufacturing, such as R&D, design, engineering, and headquarters services. In other words, although Chinese imports may have reduced employment within some establishments, these losses were more than offset by gains in employment within the same firms. Contrary to conventional wisdom, firms exposed to greater Chinese imports created more manufacturing and nonmanufacturing jobs than non-exposed firms." http://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2017/03/dissent-china-t...

Scrapping the TPP will have major consequences for farmer's in America's bread basket. This does not bode well for many, many farmers from Ohio to Montana.

It also puts China in the driver's seat when it comes to influence in Asia.

Decisions have consequences.

If Japan were truly concerned about the corrosive influence of China, one might expect that Japan would try a little harder bringing the other countries to the table. Besides, Japan is fighting a stagnant economy at home; Japan really should be trying to forge closer ties with its neighbors if it wants to give its economy a meaningful jolt. This is a perfect example of cause and effect due to globalization. Prior to globalization, what happened in one's country stayed in one's country. The ripple effects of actions in one country took time to trickle over to another or such effects were hardly apparent. Now, the ripple effects are apparent to all of us on some level and sometimes far more quickly than we may anticipate.

Yes, we do have a problem with wages in this country. And yes, people need to earn more money in order to keep up with rising costs. No human being should have to struggle for the basic necessities of life nor should one human being have to work two or three jobs to make ends meet. And so the logic behind getting out of TPP makes sense on that level.

But the reality is that we live in a new world where globalization exists. Nations depend on each other far more than ever before. This fact not be erased or conveniently ignored in the name of nationalism.

We need new solutions to new problems. I have no clue what those solutions are but what I do know is that we cannot go back to a time where globalization did not exist. It is like trying to remove all computers and go back to snail mail as a form of communication.

We need to adapt to our current reality and come up new solutions. Trying to back to 1950s is not a feasible economic or foreign policy.
